has called "kill.bat" for stopping services, disabling services and killing processes.
[EKANS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0605) stops database, data backup solution, antivirus, and ICS-related processes.
[Indrik Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0119)
has used [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) to stop services prior to the execution of ransomware.
[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) has stopped the MSExchangeIS service to render Exchange contents inaccessible to users.
[MegaCortex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0576)
can stop and disable services on the system.
[Conti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0575) can stop up to 146 Windows services related to security, backup, database, and email solutions through the use of "net stop".
[Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) has used taskkill.exe and net.exe to stop backup, catalog, cloud, and other services prior to network encryption.
[LookBack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0582) can kill processes and delete services.

For [Operation Ghost](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0023), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used new strains of malware including [FatDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0512), [MiniDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0051), [RegDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0511), and [PolyglotDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0518).

For the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used numerous pieces of malware that were likely developed for or by the group, including [SUNBURST](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0559), [SUNSPOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0562), [Raindrop](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0565), and [TEARDROP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0560).

For [Operation Dream Job](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0022), [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) developed custom tools such as Sumarta, DBLL Dropper, [Torisma](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0678), and [DRATzarus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0694) for their operations.
[Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) has developed custom malware that allowed them to maintain persistence on victim networks.
[TeamTNT](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0139) has developed custom malware such as [Hildegard](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0601).

[Aoqin Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1007) has used custom malware, including [Mongall](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1026) and [Heyoka Backdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1027), in their operations.
[Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has developed its own unique malware for use in operations.
For [Operation Sharpshooter](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0013), the threat actors used the [Rising Sun](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0448) modular backdoor.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has developed its own unique malware such as MailFetch.py for use in operations.

For [C0010](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0010), UNC3890 actors used unique malware, including [SUGARUSH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1049) and [SUGARDUMP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1042).
[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) has developed custom malware for use in their operations.

[Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) has developed malware for its operations, including malicious mobile applications and destructive malware such as [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) and [Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365).
[FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) has developed malware for use in operations, including the creation of infected removable media.
[LuminousMoth](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1014) has used unique malware for information theft and exfiltration.
During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), threat actors developed their own custom webshells to upload to compromised servers.

[Moses Staff](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1009) has built malware, such as [DCSrv](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1033) and [PyDCrypt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1032), for targeting victims' machines.
[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has used unique malware in many of their operations.

For [CostaRicto](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0004), the threat actors used custom malware, including [PS1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0613), [CostaBricks](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0614), and [SombRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0615).
[Cleaver](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0003)

has created customized tools and payloads for functions including ARP poisoning, encryption, credential dumping, ASP.NET shells, web backdoors, process enumeration, WMI querying, HTTP and SMB communications, network interface sniffing, and keystroke logging.
[Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) has a plugin to detect active drivers of some security products.
[HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) can enumerate device drivers located in the registry at "HKLM\Software\WBEM\WDM".
[LAPSUS$](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1004) has used the AD Explorer tool to enumerate users on a victim's network.
[BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has used "net user /domain" to identify account information.
[MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used "cmd.exe net user /domain" to enumerate domain users.
[Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) has the ability to identify domain administrator accounts.
[Net](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0039) commands used with the "/domain" flag can be used to gather information about and manipulate user accounts on the current domain.
[Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used "net user /domain" to enumerate domain accounts.
[Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) can acquire local and domain user account information.
[Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) enumerates user accounts of the domain.

During [Operation CuckooBees](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0012), the threat actors used the "dsquery" and "dsget" commands to get domain environment information and to query users in administrative groups.
[SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) can use "System.Security.AccessControl" namespaces to retrieve domain user information.
[menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has used the Microsoft administration tool csvde.exe to export Active Directory data.
[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) can determine if the user on an infected machine is in the admin or domain admin group.
[Poseidon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0033) searches for administrator accounts on both the local victim machine and the network.

During [Operation Dream Job](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0022), [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) queried compromised victim's active directory servers to obtain the list of employees including administrator accounts.
[Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) can use LDAP queries, "net group "Domain Admins" /domain" and "net user /domain" for discovery.
[BlackCat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1068) can utilize "net use" commands to identify domain users.
[CrackMapExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0488) can enumerate the domain user accounts on a targeted system.
[Valak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0476) has the ability to enumerate domain admin accounts.
During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), threat actors used the "net" command to retrieve information about domain accounts.
[Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) has identified domain admins through the use of “net group ‘Domain admins’” commands.
[Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) gathers domain and account names/information through process monitoring.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used Metasploit’s [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) NTDSGRAB module to obtain a copy of the victim's Active Directory database.
The [IceApple](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1022) Active Directory Querier module can perform authenticated requests against an Active Directory server.
[AdFind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0552) can enumerate domain users.
[Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) performs account discovery using commands such as "net localgroup administrators" and "net group "REDACTED" /domain" on specific permissions groups.

[OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has run "net user", "net user /domain", "net group “domain admins” /domain", and "net group “Exchange Trusted Subsystem” /domain" to get account listings on a victim.

[Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) may use "net group "domain admins" /domain" to display accounts in the "domain admins" permissions group and "net localgroup "administrators"" to list local system administrator group membership.
[OSInfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0165) enumerates local and domain users
[Chimera](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0114) has has used "net user /dom" and "net user Administrator" to enumerate domain accounts including administrator accounts.
[Dragonfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0035) has used batch scripts to enumerate users on a victim domain controller.

During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used PowerShell to discover domain accounts by exectuing "Get-ADUser" and "Get-ADGroupMember".
[BoomBox](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0635) has the ability to execute an LDAP query to enumerate the distinguished name, SAM account name, and display name for all domain users.
[dsquery](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0105) can be used to gather information on user accounts within a domain.
[POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may collect user account information by running "net user /domain" or a series of other commands on a victim.
[IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483)
can query LDAP to identify additional users on the network to infect.
[Fox Kitten](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0117) has used the Softerra LDAP browser to browse documentation on service accounts.
[SoreFang](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0516) can enumerate domain accounts via "net.exe user /domain".
[BloodHound](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0521) can collect information about domain users, including identification of domain admin accounts.
[PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) can enumerate local and domain user account information.
[Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) has used a tool to query Active Directory using LDAP, discovering information about usernames listed in AD.
[PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) creates a Registry key in the Active Setup pointing to a malicious executable.
[Bundlore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0482) uses the "mktemp" utility to make unique file and directory names for payloads, such as "TMP_DIR="mktemp -d -t x".
[DarkTortilla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1066) has used "%HiddenReg%" and "%HiddenKey%" as part of its persistence via the Windows registry.
[WarzoneRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0670) can masquerade the Process Environment Block on a compromised host to hide it's attempts to elevate privileges through "IFileOperation".

[OSX/Shlayer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0402) has used the "mktemp" utility to make random and unique filenames for payloads, such as "export tmpDir="$(mktemp -d /tmp/XXXXXXXXXXXX)"" or "mktemp -t Installer".
[Tarrask](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1011) is able to create “hidden” scheduled tasks by deleting the Security Descriptor ("SD") registry value.

[Chaes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0631) requires the user to click on the malicious Word document to execute the next part of the attack.
[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) has attempted to get users to launch a malicious Microsoft Word attachment delivered via a spearphishing email.
[REvil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0496) has been executed via malicious MS Word e-mail attachments.
[APT30](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0013) has relied on users to execute malicious file attachments delivered via spearphishing emails.
[Naikon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0019) has convinced victims to open malicious attachments to execute malware.
During [Operation Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0006), threat actors relied on a victim to enable macros within a malicious Word document.
[Sidewinder](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0121) has lured targets to click on malicious files to gain execution in the target environment.
[Lokibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0447) has tricked recipients into enabling malicious macros by getting victims to click "enable content" in email attachments.
[OutSteel](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1017) has relied on a user to execute a malicious attachment delivered via spearphishing.

[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has used various forms of spearphishing attempting to get a user to open attachments, including, but not limited to, malicious Microsoft Word documents, .pdf, and .lnk files.
[CURIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1012) has lured users into opening malicious files delivered via social media.
[Tonto Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0131) has relied on user interaction to open their malicious RTF documents.
[Squirrelwaffle](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1030) has relied on users enabling malicious macros within Microsoft Excel and Word attachments.
[Ember Bear](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1003) has attempted to lure victims into executing malicious files.
[Elderwood](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0066) has used multiple types of spearphishing in order to attempt to get a user to open attachments.
[Metamorfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0455) requires the user to double-click the executable to run the malicious HTA file or to download a malicious installer.
[Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has relied upon users clicking on a malicious attachment delivered through spearphishing.
[BoomBox](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0635)
has gained execution through user interaction with a malicious file.
[BADFLICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0642) has relied upon users clicking on a malicious attachment delivered through spearphishing.
[Grandoreiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0531)
has infected victims via malicious attachments.
[KOCTOPUS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0669) has relied on victims clicking a malicious document for execution.
[Confucius](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0142) has lured victims to execute malicious attachments included in crafted spearphishing emails related to current topics.
The [GuLoader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0561) executable has been retrieved via embedded macros in malicious Word documents.
A Word document delivering [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) prompts the user to enable macro execution.
During [Operation Dust Storm](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0016), the threat actors relied on potential victims to open a malicious Microsoft Word document sent via email.
[OSX/Shlayer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0402)
has relied on users mounting and executing a malicious DMG file.
[Kerrdown](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0585) has gained execution through victims opening malicious files.
[Nomadic Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0133) as attempted to lure victims into clicking on malicious attachments within spearphishing emails.
[JCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0389)
has achieved execution by luring users to click on a file that appeared to be an Adobe Flash Player update installer.
[NativeZone](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0637) can display an RTF document to the user to enable execution of [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) stage shellcode.
[Molerats](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0021) has sent malicious files via email that tricked users into clicking Enable Content to run an embedded macro and to download malicious archives.
During [Operation Sharpshooter](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0013), the threat actors relied on victims executing malicious Microsoft Word or PDF files.
[APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has sent spearphishing emails in an attempt to lure users to click on a malicious attachment.
[Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) has tricked unwitting recipients into clicking on spearphishing attachments and enabling malicious macros embedded within files.
[Ferocious Kitten](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0137) has attempted to convince victims to enable malicious content within a spearphishing email by including an odd decoy message.
[CSPY Downloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0527)
has been delivered via malicious documents with embedded macros.
[EXOTIC LILY](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1011) has gained execution through victims clicking on malicious LNK files contained within ISO files, which can execute hidden DLLs within the ISO.
[Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) has attempted to get users to click on Office attachments with malicious macros embedded.
[APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) has sent spearphishing attachments attempting to get a user to open them.
[APT12](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0005) has attempted to get victims to open malicious Microsoft Word and PDF attachment sent via spearphishing.
[Gorgon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0078) attempted to get users to launch malicious Microsoft Office attachments delivered via spearphishing emails.
Some [SUGARDUMP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1042) variants required a user to enable a macro within a malicious .xls file for execution.
[OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has delivered macro-enabled documents that required targets to click the "enable content" button to execute the payload on the system.
[Bad Rabbit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0606) has been executed through user installation of an executable disguised as a flash installer.
[Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has lured victims into opening malicious files containing malware.
[DnsSystem](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1021)
has lured victims into opening macro-enabled Word documents for execution.
[Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) has relied upon users clicking on a malicious attachment delivered through spearphishing.
[Clambling](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0660) has gained execution through luring victims into opening malicious files.
[Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) has lured victims into executing malware via malicious e-mail attachments.
[APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has attempted to lure users to execute a malicious dropper delivered via a spearphishing attachment.
[Flagpro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0696) has relied on users clicking a malicious attachment delivered through spearphishing.
[IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483)
has been executed through Word documents with malicious embedded macros.
[FIN4](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0085) has lured victims to launch malicious attachments delivered via spearphishing emails (often sent from compromised accounts).
[Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) used a virus that propagates by infecting executables stored on shared drives.
[H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) has functionality to copy itself to network shares.
[Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) can spread itself by infecting other portable executable files on networks shared drives.
[BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has placed malware on file shares and given it the same name as legitimate documents on the share.
[Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has copied itself to and infected files in network drives for propagation.
[Conti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0575) can spread itself by infecting other remote machines via network shared drives.
[Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) has injected malicious macros into all Word and Excel documents on mapped network drives.

[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can replace legitimate software or documents in the compromised network with their trojanized versions, in an attempt to propagate itself within the network.
[Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) infects remote servers via network shares and by infecting WinCC database views with malicious code.
[Miner-C](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0133) copies itself into the public folder of Network Attached Storage (NAS) devices and infects new victims who open the file.
[AADInternals](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0677
) can create a backdoor by converting a domain to a federated domain which will be able to authenticate any user across the tenant.
[AADInternals](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0677) can also modify DesktopSSO information.

During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) changed domain federation trust settings using Azure AD administrative permissions to configure the domain to accept authorization tokens signed by their own SAML signing certificate.
[Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) encrypts some C2 traffic with the Blowfish cipher.
[NDiskMonitor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0272) uses AES to encrypt certain information sent over its C2 channel.
Several [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware families encrypt C2 traffic using custom code that uses XOR with an ADD operation and XOR with a SUB operation.
Another [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware sample XORs C2 traffic.
Other [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware uses Caracachs encryption to encrypt C2 payloads.
[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) has also used AES to encrypt C2 traffic.
[Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) C2 traffic is encrypted using bitwise NOT and XOR operations.
[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) uses variations of a simple XOR encryption routine for C&C communications.
[Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) has used AES-256 and 3DES for C2 communications.
[xCaon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0653) has encrypted data sent to the C2 server using a XOR key.
[SombRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0615) has encrypted its C2 communications with AES.
[FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381)
has used SEAL encryption during the initial C2 handshake.
[Bonadan](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0486) can XOR-encrypt C2 communications.
[ChChes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0144)
can encrypt C2 traffic with AES or RC4.
[RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) encrypts C2 traffic with a custom RC4 variant.
[TSCookie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0436) has encrypted network communications with RC4.
[Pandora](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0664) has the ability to encrypt communications with D3DES.
[PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) uses the Camellia cipher to encrypt communications.
[Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) encodes C2 traffic with single-byte XOR keys.
[RainyDay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0629) can use RC4 to encrypt C2 communications.
[Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) has encrypted traffic with RC4.
[ZeroT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0230) has used RC4 to encrypt C2 traffic.
[NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) will decrypt resources it downloads with HTTP requests by using RC4 with the key "ScoutEagle."
[Torisma](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0678)
has encrypted its C2 communications using XOR and VEST-32.

[TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) uses a custom crypter using Microsoft’s CryptoAPI to encrypt C2 traffic.Newer versions of [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) have been known
to
use "bcrypt" to encrypt and digitally sign responses to their C2 server.
[BADCALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0245) encrypts C2 traffic using an XOR/ADD cipher.
[SodaMaster](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0627) can use RC4 to encrypt C2 communications.
[Downdelph](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0134) uses RC4 to encrypt C2 responses.
[BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has used RC4 encryption (for Datper malware) and AES (for xxmm malware) to obfuscate HTTP traffic.
[BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has also used a tool called RarStar that encodes data with a custom XOR algorithm when posting it to a C2 server.
[Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) uses a simple XOR cipher to encrypt traffic and files.
[WarzoneRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0670) can encrypt its C2 with RC4 with the password "warzone160\x00".
[PipeMon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0501) communications are RC4 encrypted.
[Rifdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0433) has encrypted command and control (C2) communications with a stream cipher.
[Winnti for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0430) has used a custom TCP protocol with four-byte XOR for command and control (C2).
[RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) has encrypted C2 traffic with RC4, previously using keys of 88888888 and babybear.
[Mustang Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0129) has encrypted C2 communications with RC4.
[HyperStack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0537)
has used RSA encryption for C2 communications.
[ZIRCONIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0128) has used AES encrypted communications in C2.
[LookBack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0582)
uses a modified version of RC4 for data transfer.
[Stealth Falcon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0038) malware encrypts C2 traffic using RC4 with a hard-coded key.
[SNUGRIDE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0159) encrypts C2 traffic using AES with a static key.
[KEYMARBLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0271) uses a customized XOR algorithm to encrypt C2 communications.
[CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) encrypts C2 communications with RC4.
[H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) encrypts C2 traffic using an RC4 key.
[More_eggs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0284) has used an RC4-based encryption method for its C2 communications.
[PLEAD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0435) has used RC4 encryption to download modules.
[PLAINTEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0254) encodes C2 beacons using XOR.
[metaMain](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1059)
can encrypt the data that it sends and receives from the C2 server using an RC4 encryption algorithm.

[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) has the ability to use AES-256 symmetric encryption in CBC mode with HMAC-SHA-256 to encrypt task commands and XOR to encrypt shell code and configuration data.
[POWERTON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0371) has used AES for encrypting C2 traffic.
[SysUpdate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0663) has used DES to encrypt all C2 communications.
[Mafalda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1060) can encrypt its C2 traffic with RC4.
[Kobalos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0641)'s post-authentication communication channel uses a 32-byte-long password with RC4 for inbound and outbound traffic.
[Bandook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0234) has used AES encryption for C2 communication.

[PingPull](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1031) can use AES, in cipher block chaining (CBC) mode padded with PKCS5, to encrypt C2 server communications.
[Hi-Zor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0087) encrypts C2 traffic with a double XOR using two distinct single-byte keys.
[NETWIRE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0198) can use AES encryption for C2 data transferred.
[Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344)
can encrypt C2 traffic using XOR.
[SMOKEDHAM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0649) has encrypted its C2 traffic with RC4.
[Dipsind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0200) encrypts C2 data with AES256 in ECB mode.
[HiddenWasp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0394)
uses an RC4-like algorithm with an already computed PRGA generated key-stream for network communication.
[Comnie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0244)
encrypts command and control communications with RC4.
[Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439)
uses AES to encrypt network traffic.
The key can be hardcoded or negotiated with the C2 server in the registration phase.
[Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) uses a secret key with a series of XOR and addition operations to encrypt C2 traffic.
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) installed a Delphi backdoor that used a custom algorithm for C2 communications.
[BBSRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0127)
uses a custom encryption algorithm on data sent back to the C2 server over HTTP.
The [Komplex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0162) C2 channel uses an 11-byte XOR algorithm to hide data.
[HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) has compressed network communications and encrypted them with a custom stream cipher.
[Winnti for Windows](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0141) can XOR encrypt C2 traffic.
During [Operation Dream Job](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0022), [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) used an AES key to communicate with their C2 server.
[Explosive](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0569) has encrypted communications with the RC4 method.
Some versions of [UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275) have used the hard-coded string “this is the encrypt key” for Blowfish encryption when communicating with a C2.
Later versions have hard-coded keys uniquely for each C2 address.
[BLINDINGCAN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0520) has encrypted its C2 traffic with RC4.
[Inception](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0100) has encrypted network communications with AES.
[Taidoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0011) uses RC4 to encrypt the message body of HTTP content.

The C2 server response to a beacon sent by a variant of [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) contains a 36-character GUID value that is used as an encryption key for subsequent network communications.
Some variants of [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) use various XOR operations to encrypt C2 data.
[Metamorfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0455) has encrypted C2 commands with AES-256.
[TAINTEDSCRIBE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0586) uses a Linear Feedback Shift Register (LFSR) algorithm for network encryption.
[Lurid](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0010) performs XOR encryption.
[Mongall](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1026) has the ability to RC4 encrypt C2 communications.
[FoggyWeb](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0661)
has used a dynamic XOR key and custom XOR methodology for C2 communications.
[Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) can send C2 communications with XOR encryption.
The [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) command and control protocol's data stream can be encrypted with AES-CBC.
[FatDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0512) can AES encrypt C2 communications.
[APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has used AES for encryption of command and control traffic.

The original variant of [FakeM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0076) encrypts C2 traffic using a custom encryption cipher that uses an XOR key of “YHCRA” and bit rotation between each XOR operation.
Some variants of [FakeM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0076) use RC4 to encrypt C2 traffic.
[Bisonal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0268) variants reported on in 2014 and 2015 used a simple XOR cipher for C2.
Some [Bisonal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0268) samples encrypt C2 communications with RC4.
A variant of [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) encrypts some C2 with 3DES.
[PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) can use RC4 encryption in C2 communications.
[Bumblebee](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1039)
can encrypt C2 requests and responses with RC4
[WellMess](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0514) can encrypt HTTP POST data using RC6 and a dynamically generated AES key encrypted with a hard coded RSA public key.
[CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) contains a custom version of the RC4 algorithm that includes a programming error.
[CharmPower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0674) can send additional modules over C2 encrypted with a simple substitution cipher.
[Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081) encrypts exfiltrated data with RC4.
[SeaDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0053) C2 traffic has been encrypted with RC4 and AES.
[NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336) uses DES to encrypt the C2 traffic.
[XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) uses RC4 encryption over TCP to communicate with its C2 server.
[BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128)
encrypts C2 data with a ROR by 3 and an XOR by 0x23.
[QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) can RC4 encrypt strings in C2 communication.
[Sliver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0633) can use AES-GCM-256 to encrypt a session key for C2 message exchange.
[httpclient](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0068) encrypts C2 content with XOR using a single byte, 0x12.
[Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091)
encrypts commands from the C2 server using a hardcoded key.
[StrifeWater](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1034) can encrypt C2 traffic using XOR with a hard coded key.
[Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) has encrypted C2 traffic using the client IP address, then encoded it as a hexadecimal string.
[gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) uses RC4 and XOR to encrypt C2 traffic.
[CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) C2 messages are encrypted with custom stream ciphers using six-byte or eight-byte keys.
[Nebulae](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0630) can use RC4 and XOR to encrypt C2 communications.
[Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) has used AES to exfiltrate documents.
During [Frankenstein](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0001), the threat actors communicated with C2 via an encrypted RC4 byte stream and AES-CBC.
[Hikit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0009) performs XOR encryption.
[Lucifer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0532) can perform a decremental-xor encryption on the initial C2 request before sending it over the wire.
[Higaisa](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0126) used AES-128 to encrypt C2 traffic.
[MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used AES to encrypt C2 responses.
[Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168)
uses custom encryption for C2 that uses 3DES.
[SideTwist](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0610)
can encrypt C2 communications with a randomly generated key.
[Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256) uses a custom encryption algorithm, which consists of XOR and a stream that is similar to the Blum Blum Shub algorithm.
[Chaos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0220)
provides a reverse shell connection on 8338/TCP, encrypted via AES.
[Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) obfuscates C2 traffic with variable 4-byte XOR keys.
[GrimAgent](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0632) can use an AES key to encrypt C2 communications.
[KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) has used AES to encrypt C2 traffic.
[GreyEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0342)
encrypts communications using AES256.
[Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) uses RC4 encryption to obfuscate HTTP traffic.
Some [Felismus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0171) samples use a custom encryption method for C2 traffic that utilizes AES and multiple keys.
[Sys10](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0060) uses an XOR 0x1 loop to encrypt its C2 domain.
[Woody RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1065) can use AES-CBC to encrypt data sent to its C2 server.
[MoonWind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0149)
encrypts C2 traffic using RC4 with a static key.
[Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) encrypts data sent to its C2 server over HTTP with RC4.
[LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) uses AES to encrypt C2 traffic.
[Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) encrypts the message body of HTTP traffic with RC2 (in CBC mode).
[Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) also uses XOR with random keys for its communications.
[Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) has encrypted data symmetrically using a randomly generated Blowfish (OFB) key which is encrypted with a public RSA key.
[FALLCHILL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0181) encrypts C2 data with RC4 encryption.
[down_new](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0472) has the ability to AES encrypt C2 communications.
[SUNBURST](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0559) encrypted C2 traffic using a single-byte-XOR cipher.
[BendyBear](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0574)
communicates to a C2 server over port 443 using modified RC4 and XOR-encrypted chunks.
The [IceApple](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1022) Result Retriever module can AES encrypt C2 responses.

Before being appended to image files, [HAMMERTOSS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0037) commands are encrypted with a key composed of both a hard-coded value and a string contained on that day's tweet.
To decrypt the commands, an investigator would need access to the intended malware sample, the day's tweet, and the image file containing the command.
[4H RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0065) obfuscates C2 communication using a 1-byte XOR with the key 0xBE.
[Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) encodes the payload of system information sent to the command and control servers using a one byte 0xFF XOR key.
[Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603)
also uses a 31-byte long static byte string to XOR data sent to command and control servers.
The servers use a different static key to encrypt replies to the implant.

[3PARA RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0066) command and control commands are encrypted within the HTTP C2 channel using the DES algorithm in CBC mode with a key derived from the MD5 hash of the string HYF54&%9&jkMCXuiS.
[3PARA RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0066) will use an 8-byte XOR key derived from the string HYF54&%9&jkMCXuiS if the DES decoding fails
[RDAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0495) has used AES ciphertext to encode C2 communications.
[APT12](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0005) has used the [RIPTIDE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0003) RAT, which communicates over HTTP with a payload encrypted with RC4.
[CallMe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0077)
uses AES to encrypt C2 traffic.

During the [2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0025), [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) used an arbitrary system service to load at system boot for persistence for [Industroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0604).
They also replaced the ImagePath registry value of a Windows service with a new backdoor binary.
[TA505](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092) has used fast flux to mask botnets by distributing payloads across multiple IPs.
[menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has used dynamic DNS service providers to host malicious domains.
[njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) has used a fast flux DNS for C2 IP resolution.
[Amadey](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1025)
has used fast flux DNS for its C2.
[gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) operators have used dynamic DNS to mask the true location of their C2 behind rapidly changing IP addresses.
[PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) checks if VMware tools is running in the background by searching for any process named "vmtoolsd".
[SynAck](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0242) checks its directory location in an attempt to avoid launching in a sandbox.
[WhisperGate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0689) can stop its execution when it recognizes the presence of certain monitoring tools.
[PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) checked the size of the hard drive to determine if it was being run in a sandbox environment.
In the event of sandbox detection, it would delete itself by overwriting the malware scripts with the contents of "License.txt" and exiting.
[P8RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0626) can check the compromised host for processes associated with VMware or VirtualBox environments.
[Grandoreiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0531)
can detect VMWare via its I/O port and Virtual PC via the "vpcext" instruction.
[Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439)'s loader can check the amount of physical memory and terminates itself if the host has less than 1.5 Gigabytes of physical memory in total.

[Saint Bot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1018) has run several virtual machine and sandbox checks, including checking if "Sbiedll.dll" is present in a list of loaded modules, comparing the machine name to "HAL9TH" and the user name to "JohnDoe", and checking the BIOS version for known virtual machine identifiers.
[GuLoader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0561) has the ability to perform anti-VM and anti-sandbox checks using string hashing, the API call "EnumWindows", and checking for Qemu guest agent.
[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can check for artifacts of VirtualBox, Virtual PC and VMware environment, and terminate itself if they are detected.
[Bumblebee](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1039) has the ability to search for designated file paths and Registry keys that indicate a virtualized environment from multiple products.
[Shark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1019) can stop execution if the screen width of the targeted machine is not over 600 pixels.
[OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used macros to verify if a mouse is connected to a compromised machine.
[UBoatRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0333) checks for virtualization software such as VMWare, VirtualBox, or QEmu on the compromised machine.
[MegaCortex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0576)
has checked the number of CPUs in the system to avoid being run in a sandbox or emulator.
During [Frankenstein](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0001), the threat actors used a script that ran WMI queries to check if a VM or sandbox was running, including VMWare and Virtualbox.
The script would also call WMI to determine the number of cores allocated to the system; if less than two the script would stop execution.
[macOS.OSAMiner](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1048) can parse the output of the native "system_profiler" tool to determine if the machine is running with 4 cores.
[Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) can check for Windows product ID's used by sandboxes and usernames and disk serial numbers associated with analyst environments.
[BLUELIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0657) can check to see if the infected machine has VM tools running.

[FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) obtains the hardware device list and checks if the MD5 of the vendor ID is equal to a predefined list in order to check for sandbox/virtualized environments.
[RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270)
uses WMI to check BIOS version for VBOX, bochs, qemu, virtualbox, and vm to check for evidence that the script might be executing within an analysis environment.
[GoldMax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0588) will check if it is being run in a virtualized environment by comparing the collected MAC address to "c8:27:cc:c2:37:5a".
[Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) can detect commonly used and generic virtualization platforms based primarily on drivers and file paths.
[ObliqueRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0644) can halt execution if it identifies processes belonging to virtual machine software or analysis tools.
[SVCReady](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1064) has the ability to determine if its runtime environment is virtualized.
[Ferocious](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0679)
can run anti-sandbox checks using the Microsoft Excel 4.0 function "GET.WORKSPACE" to determine the OS version, if there is a mouse present, and if the host is capable of playing sounds.
[NativeZone](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0637)
has checked if Vmware or VirtualBox VM is running on a compromised host.
[Black Basta](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1070) can check system flags and libraries, process timing, and API's to detect code emulation or sandboxing.
[yty](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0248) has some basic anti-sandbox detection that tries to detect Virtual PC, Sandboxie, and VMware.
[Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024)
can detect sandbox analysis environments by inspecting the process list and Registry.

[CSPY Downloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0527) can search loaded modules, PEB structure, file paths, Registry keys, and memory to determine if it is being debugged or running in a virtual environment.
[Evilnum](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0120) has used a component called TerraLoader to check certain hardware and file information to detect sandboxed environments.
[DarkTortilla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1066)
can search a compromised system's running processes and services to detect Hyper-V, QEMU, Virtual PC, Virtual Box, and VMware, as well as Sandboxie.

During [Operation Dream Job](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0022), [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) used tools that conducted a variety of system checks to detect sandboxes or VMware services.

[GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) uses WMI to check the BIOS and manufacturer information for strings like "VMWare", "Virtual", and "XEN" and another WMI request to get the current temperature of the hardware to determine if it's a virtual machine environment.
[SUNBURST](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0559) checked the domain name of the compromised host to verify it was running in a real environment.
[Denis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0354) ran multiple system checks, looking for processor and register characteristics, to evade emulation and analysis.
[Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) has a module that checks a number of indicators on the system to determine if its running on a virtual machine.
[SodaMaster](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0627) can check for the presence of the Registry key "HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\\Applications\\VMwareHostOpen.exe" before proceeding to its main functionality.
[Lucifer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0532)
can check for specific usernames, computer names, device drivers, DLL's, and virtual devices associated with sandboxed environments and can enter an infinite loop and stop itself if any are detected.
[Remcos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0332) searches for Sandboxie and VMware on the system.
[QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650)
can check the compromised host for the presence of multiple executables associated with analysis tools and halt execution if any are found.
[Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) scans processes to perform anti-VM checks.

[Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) malware has used a series of checks to determine if it's being analyzed; checks include the length of executable names, if a filename ends with ".Md5.exe", and if the program is executed from the root of the C:\ drive, as well as checks for sandbox-related libraries.
[BadPatch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0337) attempts to detect if it is being run in a Virtual Machine (VM) using a WMI query for disk drive name, BIOS, and motherboard information.
[OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264)
performs several anti-VM and sandbox checks on the victim's machine.
One technique the group has used was to perform a WMI query "SELECT * FROM MSAcpi_ThermalZoneTemperature" to check the temperature to see if it’s running in a virtual environment.

[EvilBunny](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0396)'s dropper has checked the number of processes and the length and strings of its own file name to identify if the malware is in a sandbox environment.
[WastedLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0612) checked if UCOMIEnumConnections and IActiveScriptParseProcedure32 Registry keys were detected as part of its anti-analysis technique.

[OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0352) has variants that check a number of system parameters to see if it is being run on real hardware or in a virtual machine environment, such as "sysctl hw.model".
[ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) can check for VMware-related files and DLLs related to sandboxes.

[Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) can detect whether it is executed in some virtualized or emulated environment by searching for specific artifacts, such as communication with I/O ports and using VM-specific instructions.
[Kinsing](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0599) has used crontab to download and run shell scripts every minute to ensure persistence.
The [GoldMax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0588) Linux variant has used a crontab entry with a "@reboot" line to gain persistence.
[Janicab](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0163) used a cron job for persistence on Mac devices.
[Exaramel for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0401) uses crontab for persistence if it does not have root privileges.
[SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) uses cron tasks to ensure persistence.
[Anchor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0504) can install itself as a cron job.
[Rocke](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0106) installed a cron job that downloaded and executed files from the C2.
[Skidmap](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0468)
has installed itself via crontab.
[Xbash](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0341) can create a cronjob for persistence if it determines it is on a Linux system.
[NETWIRE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0198)
can use crontabs to establish persistence.
[Penquin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0587) can use Cron to create periodic and pre-scheduled background jobs.
[APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) has used cron to create pre-scheduled and periodic background jobs on a Linux system.
[OSInfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0165) specifically looks for Domain Admins and power users within the domain.
[Inception](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0100) has used specific malware modules to gather domain membership.
[Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) performs discovery of permission groups "net group /domain".

[OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used "net group /domain", "net group “domain admins” /domain", and "net group “Exchange Trusted Subsystem” /domain" to find domain group permission settings.
[AdFind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0552) can enumerate domain groups.

During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used [AdFind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0552) to enumerate domain groups.

[Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) has checked for the domain admin group and Exchange Trusted Subsystem groups using the commands "net group Exchange Trusted Subsystem /domain" and "net group domain admins /domain".
[dsquery](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0105) can be used to gather information on permission groups within a domain.
[CrackMapExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0488) can gather the user accounts within domain groups.
[Egregor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0554) can conduct Active Directory reconnaissance using tools such as Sharphound or [AdFind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0552).
[WellMess](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0514) can identify domain group membership for the current user.
[Dragonfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0035) has used batch scripts to enumerate administrators and users in the domain.
[SoreFang](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0516) can enumerate domain groups by executing "net.exe group /domain".
[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) can identify targets by querying account groups on a domain contoller.
[GRIFFON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0417) has used a reconnaissance module that can be used to retrieve Windows domain membership information.
[POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may collect domain group information by running "net group /domain" or a series of other commands on a victim.
[Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used "net group "Domain Admins" /domain" to identify domain administrators.
[BlackCat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1068) can determine if a user on a compromised host has domain admin privileges.
Commands such as "net group /domain" can be used in [Net](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0039) to gather information about and manipulate groups.
[REvil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0496) can identify the domain membership of a compromised host.
[Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) can use "net group" for discovery on targeted domains.
[LAPSUS$](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1004) has used the AD Explorer tool to enumerate groups on a victim's network.
[Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects a list of domain groups with the command "net localgroup /domain".
During [C0015](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0015), the threat actors use the command "net group "domain admins" /dom" to enumerate domain groups.
[SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) can use "System.DirectoryServices" namespace to retrieve domain group information.
[BloodHound](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0521)
can collect information about domain groups and members.

has sent phishing emails with malicious Microsoft Word attachments to victims.
[Elderwood](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0066) has delivered zero-day exploits and malware to victims via targeted emails containing malicious attachments.

[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) has targeted victims with spearphishing emails containing malicious Microsoft Word documents.

[Ember Bear](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1003) has sent spearphishing emails containing malicious attachments in the form of PDFs, Word documents, JavaScript files, and Control Panel File (CPL) executables.
[Saint Bot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1018) has been distributed as malicious attachments within spearphishing emails.
[Nomadic Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0133) has targeted victims with spearphishing emails containing malicious attachments.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) sent spearphishing emails with attachments such as compiled HTML (.chm) files to initially compromise their victims.

During [Operation Spalax](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0005), the threat actors sent phishing emails that included a PDF document that in some cases led to the download and execution of malware.
[Mofang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0103) delivered spearphishing emails with malicious documents, PDFs, or Excel files attached.
[RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0048) has used spearphishing attachments to distribute its malware.

[macOS.OSAMiner](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1048) has used run-only Applescripts, a compiled and stripped version of [AppleScript](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/002), to remove human readable indicators to evade detection.
[Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) malware can insert malicious macros into documents using a "Microsoft.Office.Interop" object.
[Milan](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1015) can use a COM component to generate scheduled tasks.
[Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) can use the Windows COM API to schedule tasks and maintain persistence.
[HermeticWizard](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0698) can execute files on remote machines using DCOM.
[POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can use DCOM (targeting the 127.0.0.1 loopback address) to execute additional payloads on compromised hosts.
[Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) droppers have used COM objects to execute the malware's full executable payload.

[FunnyDream](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1044) can use com objects identified with "CLSID_ShellLink"("IShellLink" and "IPersistFile") and "WScript.Shell"("RegWrite" method) to enable persistence mechanisms.
[Bumblebee](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1039) can use a COM object to execute queries to gather system information.
[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can use the "ITaskService", "ITaskDefinition" and "ITaskSettings" COM interfaces to schedule a task.
[Neoichor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0691) can use the Internet Explorer (IE) COM interface to connect and receive commands from C2.
[MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069)
has used malware that has the capability to execute malicious code via COM, DCOM, and Outlook.
[TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) used COM to setup scheduled task for persistence.
[Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) can use the "IARPUinstallerStringLauncher" COM interface are part of its UAC bypass process.
[DarkTortilla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1066) has used the "WshShortcut" COM object to create a .lnk shortcut file in the Windows startup folder.
[WastedLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0612) has performed DLL hijacking before execution.
[PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) contains a collection of Privesc-PowerUp modules that can discover and exploit DLL hijacking opportunities in services and processes.
[Hikit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0009) has used [DLL Search Order Hijacking](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1574/001) to load "oci.dll" as a persistence mechanism.
[Tonto Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0131) abuses a legitimate and signed Microsoft executable to launch a malicious DLL.
[Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) can launch itself via DLL Search Order Hijacking.
[Melcoz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0530) can use DLL hijacking to bypass security controls.
[Chaes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0631) has used search order hijacking to load a malicious DLL.
[menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has used DLL search order hijacking.
[BackdoorDiplomacy](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0135) has executed DLL search order hijacking.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) has used search order hijacking to execute malicious payloads, such as Winnti RAT.

[BOOSTWRITE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0415) has exploited the loading of the legitimate Dwrite.dll file by actually loading the gdi library, which then loads the gdiplus library and ultimately loads the local Dwrite dll.
A [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) variant uses DLL search order hijacking.

[Evilnum](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0120) has used the malware variant, TerraTV, to load a malicious DLL placed in the TeamViewer directory, instead of the original Windows DLL located in a system folder.
[MirageFox](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0280) is likely loaded via DLL hijacking into a legitimate McAfee binary.

[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can be launched by using DLL search order hijacking in which the wrapper DLL is placed in the same folder as explorer.exe and loaded during startup into the Windows Explorer process instead of the legitimate library.
[Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) can hijack outdated Windows application dependencies with malicious versions of its own DLL payload.
[Aquatic Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0143) has used DLL search-order hijacking to load "exe", "dll", and "dat" files into memory.

[Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) uses DLL search order hijacking for persistence by saving itself as ntshrui.dll to the Windows directory so it will load before the legitimate ntshrui.dll saved in the System32 subdirectory.
[Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has performed DLL search order hijacking to execute their payload.
[HTTPBrowser](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0070)
abuses the Windows DLL load order by using a legitimate Symantec anti-virus binary, VPDN_LU.exe, to load a malicious DLL that mimics a legitimate Symantec DLL, navlu.dll.
[RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0048) has used search order hijacking to force TeamViewer to load a malicious DLL.

[FoggyWeb](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0661)'s loader has used DLL Search Order Hijacking to load malicious code instead of the legitimate "version.dll" during the "Microsoft.IdentityServer.ServiceHost.exe" execution process.
[Crutch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0538) can persist via DLL search order hijacking on Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, or Microsoft OneDrive.
[Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363)
contains modules that can discover and exploit various DLL hijacking opportunities.
[RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) is launched through use of DLL search order hijacking to load a malicious dll.
Variants of [WEBC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0109) achieve persistence by using DLL search order hijacking, usually by copying the DLL file to "%SYSTEMROOT%" ("C:\WINDOWS\ntshrui.dll").
[PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) has the ability to use DLL search order hijacking for installation on targeted systems.
[Whitefly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0107) has used search order hijacking to run the loader Vcrodat.
[Downdelph](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0134) uses search order hijacking of the Windows executable sysprep.exe to escalate privileges.
[Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) has used search order hijacking to load a malicious payload DLL as a dependency to a benign application packaged in the same ISO.
[APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) used a batch script to perform a series of discovery techniques and saves it to a text file.
[Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) can automatically gather the username, domain name, machine name, and other information from a compromised system.
[Chimera](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0114) has used custom DLLs for continuous retrieval of data from memory.
[TajMahal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0467) has the ability to index and compress files into a send queue for exfiltration.
[FunnyDream](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1044)
can monitor files for changes and automatically collect them.
[AppleSeed](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0622) has automatically collected data from USB drives, keystrokes, and screen images before exfiltration.
During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), threat actors used a script to collect information about the infected system.
[Mythic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0699) supports scripting of file downloads from agents.
[PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378)
contains a module for recursively parsing through files and directories to gather valid credit card numbers.

[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used a script to iterate through a list of compromised PoS systems, copy and remove data to a log file, and to bind to events from the submit payment button.
[Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458)
can conduct an initial scan for Microsoft Word documents on the local system, removable media, and connected network drives, before tagging and collecting them.
It can continue tagging documents to collect with follow up scans.
[PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428)
used file system monitoring to track modification and enable automatic exfiltration.
[Crutch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0538) can automatically monitor removable drives in a loop and copy interesting files.
[Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) recursively generates a list of files within a directory and sends them back to the control server.
[VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) saves each collected file with the automatically generated format {0:dd-MM-yyyy}.txt .
[Comnie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0244) executes a batch script to store discovery information in %TEMP%\info.dat and then uploads the temporarily file to the remote C2 server.
[Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) ran a command to compile an archive of file types of interest from the victim user's directories.
[OutSteel](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1017) can automatically scan for and collect files with specific extensions.
[Mustang Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0129) used custom batch scripts to collect files automatically from a targeted system.

[Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) scans the system and automatically collects files with the following extensions: .doc, .docx, ,.xls, .xlsx, .pdf, .pptx, .rar, .zip, .jpg, .jpeg, .bmp, .tiff, .kum, .tlg, .sbx, .cr, .hse, .hsf, and .lhz.
[Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) developed a file stealer to search C:\ and collect files with certain extensions.
[Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) also executed a script to enumerate all drives, store them as a list, and upload generated files to the C2 server.
[ShimRatReporter](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0445)
gathered information automatically, without instruction from a C2, related to the user and host machine that is compiled into a report and sent to the operators.
[T9000](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0098) searches removable storage devices for files with a pre-defined list of file extensions (e.g. * .doc, *.ppt, *.xls, *.docx, *.pptx, *.xlsx).
Any matching files are encrypted and written to a local user directory.
[FIN5](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0053) scans processes on all victim systems in the environment and uses automated scripts to pull back the results.
[ccf32](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1043) can be used to automatically collect files from a compromised host.
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) used a publicly available tool to gather and compress multiple documents on the DCCC and DNC networks.
[WindTail](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0466) can identify and add files that possess specific file extensions to an array for archiving.
[menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has used the Csvde tool to collect Active Directory files and data.

[Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) executes an RAR tool to recursively archive files based on a predefined list of file extensions (*.xls, *.xlsx, *.csv, *.odt, *.doc, *.docx, *.ppt, *.pptx, *.pdf, *.mdb, *.accdb, *.accde, *.txt).
For all non-removable drives on a victim, [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) executes automated collection of certain files for later exfiltration.
[ROADTools](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0684) automatically gathers data from Azure AD environments using the Azure Graph API.
[StrongPity](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0491) has a file searcher component that can automatically collect and archive files based on a predefined list of file extensions.
[Proxysvc](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0238) automatically collects data about the victim and sends it to the control server.
A [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) VBScript receives a batch script to execute a set of commands in a command prompt.
[Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) has automatically collected data about the compromised system.
[Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) has deployed scripts on compromised systems that automatically scan for interesting documents.
[NETWIRE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0198) can automatically archive collected data.
[Valak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0476)
can download a module to search for and build a report of harvested credential data.

[GoldFinder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0597) logged and stored information related to the route or hops a packet took from a compromised machine to a hardcoded C2 server, including the target C2 URL, HTTP response/status code, HTTP response headers and values, and data received from the C2 node.

[MESSAGETAP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0443) checks two files, keyword_parm.txt and parm.txt, for instructions on how to target and save data parsed and extracted from SMS message data from the network traffic.
If an SMS message contained either a phone number, IMSI number, or keyword that matched the predefined list, it is saved to a CSV file for later theft by the threat actor.

[Confucius](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0142) has used a file stealer to steal documents and images with the following extensions: txt, pdf, png, jpg, doc, xls, xlm, odp, ods, odt, rtf, ppt, xlsx, xlsm, docx, pptx, and jpeg.
[Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) has performed frequent and scheduled data collection from victim networks.

During [Frankenstein](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0001), the threat actors used [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) to automatically gather the username, domain name, machine name, and other system information.
[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can sort and collect specific documents as well as generate a list of all files on a newly inserted drive and store them in an encrypted file.
[Rover](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0090) automatically collects files from the local system and removable drives based on a predefined list of file extensions on a regular timeframe.
[RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148)
monitors browsing activity and automatically captures screenshots if a victim browses to a URL matching one of a list of strings.
[LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) can be configured to automatically collect files under a specified directory.
[OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used automated collection.

[Metamorfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0455) has automatically collected mouse clicks, continuous screenshots on the machine, and set timers to collect the contents of the clipboard and website browsing.
[BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) monitors USB devices and copies files with certain extensions to a predefined directory.
[Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) has collected information automatically using the adversary's [USBferry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0452) attack.
[Sidewinder](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0121) has used tools to automatically collect system and network configuration information.
[Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) collects text from the clipboard.
