[RunningRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0253)
contains code to open and copy data from the clipboard.
[Grandoreiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0531) can capture clipboard data from a compromised host.
[Remcos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0332)
steals and modifies data from the clipboard.
[VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) collects data stored in the clipboard.
[RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) collects data from the clipboard.
[KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) had a feature to steal data from the clipboard.
During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), threat actors collected clipboard data in plaintext.
[Melcoz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0530) can monitor content saved to the clipboard.
[Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can steal data from the victim’s clipboard.
[Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) has a plugin that collects data stored in the Windows clipboard by using the OpenClipboard and GetClipboardData APIs.
[APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has used tools capable of stealing contents of the clipboard.
[DarkComet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0334) can steal data from the clipboard.
[Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) hijacks the clipboard data by creating an overlapped window that listens to keyboard events.
[ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240)
can extract clipboard data from a compromised host.
A [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) variant accesses a screenshot saved in the clipboard and converts it to a JPG image.
[MarkiRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0652)
can capture clipboard content.
[MacSpy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0282)
can steal clipboard contents.
[Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) can hook GetClipboardData function to watch for clipboard pastes to collect.
[Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) collects information from the clipboard by using the OpenClipboard() and GetClipboardData() libraries.
[TinyZBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0004) contains functionality to collect information from the clipboard.
[Catchamas](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0261) steals data stored in the clipboard.
[Cadelspy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0454) has the ability to steal data from the clipboard.
[APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) used a Trojan called KEYLIME to collect data from the clipboard.
[Clambling](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0660) has the ability to capture and store clipboard data.
[Explosive](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0569) has a function to use the OpenClipboard wrapper.
[TajMahal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0467) has the ability to steal data from the clipboard of an infected host.
[DarkTortilla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1066)
can download a clipboard information stealer module.
[Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) can retrieve the current content of the user clipboard.
[Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) can harvest clipboard data on both Windows and macOS systems.

[Metamorfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0455) has a function to hijack data from the clipboard by monitoring the contents of the clipboard and replacing the cryptocurrency wallet with the attacker's.
[CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) copies and exfiltrates the clipboard contents every 30 seconds.
[FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381)
can collect clipboard data.
[jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) can capture clipboard data.
[MimiPenguin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0179) can use the "<PID>/maps" and "<PID>/mem" file to search for regex patterns and dump the process memory.
[LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) can use the "<PID>/maps" and "<PID>/mem" files to identify regex patterns to dump cleartext passwords from the browser's process memory.
During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), threat actors accessed and collected credentials from password managers.
[Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) obtained a KeePass database from a compromised host.
[MarkiRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0652)
can gather information from the Keepass password manager.
[Fox Kitten](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0117) has used scripts to access credential information from the KeePass database.
[TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266)
can steal passwords from the KeePass open source password manager.
[Proton](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0279) gathers credentials in files for 1password.
[OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0352) uses the command "xattr -d com.apple.quarantine" to remove the quarantine file attribute used by Gatekeeper.
[MacMa](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1016) has removed the "com.apple.quarantineattribute" from the dropped file, "$TMPDIR/airportpaird".
[CoinTicker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0369) downloads the EggShell mach-o binary using curl, which does not set the quarantine flag.

[XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) has dropped a malicious applet into an app's ".../Contents/MacOS/" folder of a previously launched app to bypass Gatekeeper's security checks on first launch apps (prior to macOS 13).
If running with elevated privileges, [OSX/Shlayer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0402) has used the "spctl" command to disable Gatekeeper protection for a downloaded file.

[OSX/Shlayer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0402) can also use system links pointing to bash scripts in the downloaded DMG file to bypass Gatekeeper, a flaw patched in macOS 11.3 and later versions.
[OSX/Shlayer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0402) has been Notarized by Apple, resulting in successful passing of additional Gatekeeper checks.

For [C0010](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0010), the threat actors compromised the login page of a legitimate Israeli shipping company and likely established a watering hole that collected visitor information.
[Dragonfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0035) has compromised websites to redirect traffic and to host exploit kits.
[LuminousMoth](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1014) has redirected compromised machines to an actor-controlled webpage through HTML injection.

[APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has stood up websites containing numerous articles and content scraped from the Internet to make them appear legitimate, but some of these pages include malicious JavaScript to profile the potential victim or infect them via a fake software update.

[Transparent Tribe](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0134) has set up websites with malicious hyperlinks and iframes to infect targeted victims with [Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115), [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385), and other malicious tools.
[Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has embedded malicious code into websites to screen a potential victim's IP address and then exploit their browser if they are of interest.
[Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has gathered information about running services.
[S-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0085) runs the command "net start" on a victim.
[Chimera](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0114) has used "net start" and "net use" for system service discovery.
[Cuba](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0625) can query service status using "QueryServiceStatusEx" function.
[TeamTNT](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0139) has searched for services such as Alibaba Cloud Security's aliyun service and BMC Helix Cloud Security's bmc-agent service in order to disable them.
[SombRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0615) can enumerate services on a victim machine.
[Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203)
creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can monitor services.
The "net start" command can be used in [Net](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0039) to find information about Windows services.
[GreyEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0342)
enumerates all Windows services.

[Caterpillar WebShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0572) can obtain a list of the services from a system.
[HyperBro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0398)
can list all services and their configurations.
[Heyoka Backdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1027) can check if it is running as a service on a compromised host.
[Black Basta](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1070) can check whether the service name FAX is present.
[Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) uses the "tasklist /svc" command to list the services on the system.
[Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) has the capability to execute the command "net start" to interact with services.
During [Operation CuckooBees](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0012), the threat actors used the "net start" command as part of their initial reconnaissance.
[RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) uses "tasklist /svc" to display running tasks.
[Earth Lusca](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1006) has used [Tasklist](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0057) to obtain information from a compromised host.
[Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) performs service discovery using "net start" commands.
[GeminiDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0049) collects information on programs and services on the victim that are configured to automatically run at startup.
[jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) can list local services.
[SysUpdate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0663) can collect a list of services on a victim machine.
[SynAck](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0242) enumerates all running services.
[Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) surveys a system upon check-in to discover running services and associated processes using the "tasklist /svc" command.
[DarkTortilla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1066) can retrieve information about a compromised system's running services.
After compromising a victim, [Poseidon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0033) discovers all running services.
[Babuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0638) can enumerate all services running on a compromised host.
[Aquatic Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0143) has attempted to discover services for third party EDR products.
[RainyDay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0629) can create and register a service for execution.
[JPIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0201) can list running services.
[ZLib](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0086) has the ability to discover and manipulate Windows services.
[TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) collects a list of install programs and services on the system’s machine.
During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), threat actors used the "tasklist" command to search for one of its backdoors.
[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154)
can enumerate services on compromised hosts.
[APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) used the commands "net start" and "tasklist" to get a listing of the services on the system.
[GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) has a feature to list the available services on the system.
[Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) may use "net start" to display running services.
[Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024) has the ability to identify running services on a compromised host.
[PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378)
can enumerate service and service permission information.
[OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used "sc query" on a victim to gather information about services.
[BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has used TROJ_GETVERSION to discover system services.
[BitPaymer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0570)
can enumerate existing Windows services on the host that are configured to run as LocalSystem.
[SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) can search for modifiable services that could be used for privilege escalation.
[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can obtain running services on the victim.
[Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) queries the system to identify existing services.
[BBSRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0127) can query service configuration information.
[HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) has the ability to retrieve a list of services on the infected host.
[Comnie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0244) runs the command: "net start >> %TEMP%\info.dat" on a victim.
[Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081) executes "net start" after initial communication is made to the remote server.
[REvil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0496) can enumerate active services.

[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has used an instrumentor script to gather the names of all services running on a victim's system.
[SLOTHFULMEDIA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0533) has the capability to enumerate services.
[ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412)
can check the services on the system.
[WINERACK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0219) can enumerate services.
[LookBack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0582)

[admin@338](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0018) actors used the following command following exploitation of a machine with [LOWBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0042) malware to obtain information about services: "net start >> %temp%\download"
[Ixeshe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0015) can list running services.
[Tasklist](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0057) can be used to discover services running on a system.

[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) deployed the open source tool Responder to conduct NetBIOS Name Service poisoning, which captured usernames and hashed passwords that allowed access to legitimate credentials.
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) close-access teams have used Wi-Fi pineapples to intercept Wi-Fi signals and user credentials.
[MESSAGETAP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0443) uses the libpcap library to listen to all traffic and parses network protocols starting with Ethernet and IP layers.
It continues parsing protocol layers including SCTP, SCCP, and TCAP and finally extracts SMS message data and routing metadata.
[Impacket](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0357) can be used to sniff network traffic via an interface or raw socket.
[APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has used SniffPass to collect credentials by sniffing network traffic.

has been observed to hook network APIs to monitor network traffic.
[Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) can be used to conduct packet captures on target hosts.
[Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) appears to have functionality to sniff for credentials passed over HTTP, SMTP, and SMB.
[PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378)
contains a module for taking packet captures on compromised hosts.
[Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) has used intercepter-NG to sniff passwords in network traffic.

[FoggyWeb](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0661) can configure custom listeners to passively monitor all incoming HTTP GET and POST requests sent to the AD FS server from the intranet/internet and intercept HTTP requests that match the custom URI patterns defined by the actor.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has used the Nirsoft SniffPass network sniffer to obtain passwords sent over non-secure protocols.
[NBTscan](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0590)
can dump and print whole packet content.
[Penquin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0587) can sniff network traffic to look for packets matching specific conditions.
[Responder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0174) captures hashes and credentials that are sent to the system after the name services have been poisoned.
[DarkVishnya](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0105) used network sniffing to obtain login data.

[QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) can use signed loaders to evade detection.
[Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) has used Digicert code-signing certificates for some of its malware.
[Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) has installed a self-signed RPM package mimicking the original system package on RPM based systems.
For [C0015](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0015), the threat actors used DLL files that had invalid certificates.
[GreyEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0342)
digitally signs the malware with a code-signing certificate.

[Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) has used code-signing certificates on its malware that are either forged due to weak keys or stolen.
[Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) has also stolen certificates and signed backdoors and downloaders with them.
[CSPY Downloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0527)
has come signed with revoked certificates.

The [Black Basta](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1070) dropper has been digitally signed with a certificate issued by Akeo Consulting for legitimate executables used for creating bootable USB drives.
[menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has resized and added data to the certificate table to enable the signing of modified files with legitimate signatures.
The [HermeticWiper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0697) executable has been signed with a legitimate certificate issued to Hermetica Digital Ltd.
During [Operation Dream Job](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0022), [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) digitally signed their own malware to evade detection.

[PipeMon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0501), its installer, and tools are signed with stolen code-signing certificates.
[Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has used stolen code signing certificates to sign malware.
[Molerats](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0021) has used forged Microsoft code-signing certificates on malware.
[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) has digitally signed malware and utilities to evade detection.

Some [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) samples were signed with a stolen digital certificate.

[Nerex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0210) drops a signed Microsoft DLL to disk.

[RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) samples have been signed with a code-signing certificates.

[LuminousMoth](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1014) has signed their malware with a valid digital signature.

[Clop](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0611) can use code signing to evade detection.

[Clop](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0611) can enumerate network shares.

[Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) can enumerate shared drives on the domain.

[Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) has used the “net view” command to locate mapped network shares.
[APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has used the post exploitation tool [CrackMapExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0488) to enumerate network shares.

[FIVEHANDS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0618)

[Cuba](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0625) can discover shared resources using the "NetShareEnum" API call.
[Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) can scan for network drives which may contain documents for collection.
[QuietSieve](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0686) can identify and search networked drives for specific file name extensions.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used the "net share" command as part of network reconnaissance.
[DarkVishnya](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0105) scanned the network for public shared folders.
[Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363)
can find shared drives on the local system.

has the capability to retrieve information about shares on remote hosts.

[WastedLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0612)
can identify network adjacent and accessible drives.
[Babuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0638) has the ability to enumerate network shares.

[Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) can scan for removable media which may contain documents for collection.
[SVCReady](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1064) can check for the number of devices plugged into an infected host.

can collect the OS, and build version on a compromised host.

A [Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) file stealer can gather the victim's computer name and drive serial numbers to send to a C2 server.
[AuTo Stealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1029)
has the ability to collect the hostname and OS information from an infected host.
[Bumblebee](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1039) can enumerate the OS version and domain on a targeted system.
[Pay2Key](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0556) has the ability to gather the hostname of the victim machine.
[Carberp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0484) has collected the operating system version from the infected system.
[Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) collects the hostname of the target computer.
[SMOKEDHAM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0649) has used the "systeminfo" command on a compromised host.
[ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) can gather the hostname and the OS version to ensure it doesn’t run on a Windows XP or Windows Server 2003 systems.
[Brave Prince](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0252) collects hard drive content and system configuration information.
[HermeticWiper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0697) can determine the OS version, bitness, and enumerate physical drives on a targeted host.
[ZeroT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0230)
gathers the victim's computer name, Windows version, and system language, and then sends it to its C2 server.
[Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) can gather system information, the computer name, OS version, drive and serial information from the victim's machine.
[Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) malware has used a PowerShell command to check the victim system architecture to determine if it is an x64 machine.
Other malware has obtained the OS version, UUID, and computer/host name to send to the C2 server.
[PinchDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0048) gathers system configuration information.
[More_eggs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0284) has the capability to gather the OS version and computer name.
[Milan](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1015)
can enumerate the targeted machine's name and GUID.
[BackConfig](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0475) has the ability to gather the victim's computer name.
[SombRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0615) can execute "getinfo" to enumerate the computer name and OS version of a compromised system.
[Winnti for Windows](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0141) can determine if the OS on a compromised host is newer than Windows XP.
[DustySky](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0062) extracts basic information about the operating system.
[ZxxZ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1013) has collected the host name and operating system product name from a compromised machine.
[Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) surveys a system upon check-in to discover operating system configuration details using the "systeminfo" and "set" commands.
[Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115) contains a command to collect the victim PC name, disk drive information, and operating system.
[JPIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0201) can obtain system information such as OS version and disk space.
[Valak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0476) can determine the Windows version and computer name on a compromised host.
[APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) has attempted to get detailed information about a compromised host, including the operating system, version, patches, hotfixes, and service packs.
[Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024) has the ability to identify the computer name, OS version, and hardware configuration on a compromised host.

[Aria-body](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0456) has the ability to identify the hostname, computer name, Windows version, processor speed, machine GUID, and disk information on a compromised host.
[FatDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0512)
can collect the user name, Windows version, computer name, and available space on discs from a compromised host.
[Unknown Logger](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0130) can obtain information about the victim computer name, physical memory, country, and date.
[Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) can grab a system’s information including the OS version, architecture, etc.
[Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) collects the CPU information, OS information, and system language.
[Moses Staff](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1009) collected information about the infected host, including the machine names and OS architecture.
[Kevin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1020) can enumerate the OS version and hostname of a targeted machine.
[SDBbot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0461) has the ability to identify the OS version, OS bit information and computer name.
[Saint Bot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1018) can identify the OS version, CPU, and other details from a victim's machine.
[PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139)
has commands to get information about the victim's name, build, version, serial number, and memory usage.
[Action RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1028) has the ability to collect the hostname, OS version, and OS architecture of an infected host.
[SideCopy](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1008) has identified the OS version of a compromised host.
[TURNEDUP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0199) is capable of gathering system information.
[Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) collected the victim computer name, OS version, and architecture type and sent the information to its C2 server.
[Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) also enumerated all available drives on the victim's machine.
[Caterpillar WebShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0572) has a module to gather information from the compromrised asset, including the computer version, computer name, IIS version, and more.
[BoomBox](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0635) can enumerate the hostname, domain, and IP of a compromised host.
[Bundlore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0482)
will enumerate the macOS version to determine which follow-on behaviors to execute using "/usr/bin/sw_vers -productVersion".
[KARAE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0215) can collect system information.
[RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153)
can gather extended system information including the hostname, OS version number, platform, memory information, time elapsed since system startup, and CPU information.
[GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) collects the MAC address, computer name, and CPU information.
[TAINTEDSCRIBE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0586) can use "DriveList" to retrieve drive information.

[SynAck](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0242) gathers computer names, OS version info, and also checks installed keyboard layouts to estimate if it has been launched from a certain list of countries.
[IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483) has the ability to identify the computer name and OS version on a compromised host.
[Zox](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0672) can enumerate attached drives.
[NOKKI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0353) can gather information on drives and the operating system on the victim’s machine.
[SideTwist](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0610) can collect the computer name of a targeted system.
[SLOTHFULMEDIA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0533) has collected system name, OS version, adapter information, memory usage, and disk information from a victim machine.
[Gold Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0249) collects endpoint information using the "systeminfo" command.
[Higaisa](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0126) collected the system volume serial number, GUID, and computer name.
[POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can retrieve OS name/architecture and computer/domain name information from compromised hosts.
[UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275) has the capability to gather the system’s hostname and OS version.
[Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125)
can obtain the OS version information, computer name, processor architecture, machine role, and OS edition.
[XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains the getInstalledAPP function to run "ls -la /Applications" to gather what applications are installed.

[Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) collects system information from the victim, including CPU speed, computer name, volume serial number, ANSI code page, OEM code page identifier for the OS, Microsoft Windows version, and memory information.
[ObliqueRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0644) has the ability to check for blocklisted computer names on infected endpoints.
[AppleJeus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0584) has collected the victim host information after infection.
[Explosive](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0569) has collected the computer name from the infected host.
[HELLOKITTY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0617) can enumerate logical drives on a target system.
[STARWHALE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1037) can gather the computer name of an infected host.
[KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) can gather extended system information, such as information about the operating system, disks, and memory.
[Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176)
checks the victim OS version after executing to determine where to drop files based on whether the victim is 32-bit or 64-bit.
[PowerShower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0441)
has collected system information on the infected host.
[BlackCat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1068)
can obtain the computer name and UUID, and enumerate local drives.
[Blue Mockingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0108) has collected hardware details for the victim's system, including CPU and memory information.
[Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) performs operating system information discovery using "systeminfo" and has used implants to identify the system language and computer name.
[Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) gathers information on the system and local drives.
[Diavol](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0659) can collect the computer name and OS version from the system.
[MoleNet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0553) can collect information about the about the system.
[OSX/Shlayer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0402) has collected the IOPlatformUUID, session UID, and the OS version using the command "sw_vers -productVersion".
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that can obtain information about the local system.
[Egregor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0554) can perform a language check of the infected system and can query the CPU information (cupid).
[ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) will attempt to enumerate Windows version and system architecture.
[Netwalker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0457)
can determine the system architecture it is running on to choose which version of the DLL to use.
[Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) collects system information including computer and domain names, OS version, and S7P paths.
[DropBook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0547) has checked for the presence of Arabic language in the infected machine's settings.
[Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239)
gathers system information, network addresses, disk type, disk free space, and the operation system version.
[Heyoka Backdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1027) can enumerate drives on a compromised host.

[KEYMARBLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0271) has the capability to collect the computer name, language settings, the OS version, CPU information, disk devices, and time elapsed since system start.
A system info module in [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046) gathers information on the victim host’s configuration.
[Meteor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0688) has the ability to discover the hostname of a compromised host.
[Ixeshe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0015) collects the computer name of the victim's system during the initial infection.
[CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) collects hostname, volume serial number and OS version data from the victim and sends the information to its C2 server.
[XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658)
identifies the macOS version and uses "ioreg" to determine serial number.
[FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) collects the victim’s computer name, processor architecture, OS version, volume serial number, and system type.
[Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used [Systeminfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0096) to gather system information.
[Confucius](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0142) has used a file stealer that can examine system drives, including those other than the C drive.
[Avenger](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0473) has the ability to identify the host volume ID and the OS architecture on a compromised host.
[Skidmap](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0468) has the ability to check whether the infected system’s OS is Debian or RHEL/CentOS to determine which cryptocurrency miner it should use.
[Chimera](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0114) has used "fsutil fsinfo drives", "systeminfo", and "vssadmin list shadows" for system information including shadow volumes and drive information.
[ZIRCONIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0128) has used a tool to capture the processor architecture of a compromised host in order to register it with C2.

[HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) has the ability to determine if the current user is an administrator, Windows product name, processor name, screen resolution, and physical RAM of the infected host.
[Linfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0211)
creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve system information.

[Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects OS version information such as registered owner details, manufacturer details, processor type, available storage, installed patches, hostname, version info, system date, and other system information by using the commands "systeminfo", "net config workstation", "hostname", "ver", "set", and "date /t".
[BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089)
has used [Systeminfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0096) to gather the OS version, as well as information on the system configuration, BIOS, the motherboard, and the processor.
[Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021)
gathers the name of the local host, version of GNU Compiler Collection (GCC), and the system information about the CPU, machine, and operating system.
[AppleSeed](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0622)
can identify the OS version of a targeted system.
[SysUpdate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0663)
can collect a system's architecture, operating system version, hostname, and drive information.
[Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) has collected the computer name and OS architecture information from the system.
[LitePower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0680) has the ability to list local drives and enumerate the OS architecture.
[Orz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0229) can gather the victim OS version and whether it is 64 or 32 bit.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has enumerated drives, OS type, OS version, and other information using a script or the "systeminfo" command.
[LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) gathers the victim computer name using the Win32 API call "GetComputerName".
[cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106) can be used to find information about the operating system.
[NDiskMonitor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0272) obtains the victim computer name and encrypts the information to send over its C2 channel.
[Denis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0354)
collects OS information and the computer name from the victim’s machine.
[QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) can collect system information including the OS version and domain on a compromised host.
[Pasam](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0208) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve information such as hostname and free disk space.
[POORAIM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0216)
can identify system information, including battery status.
[Windigo](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0124) has used a script to detect which Linux distribution and version is currently installed on the system.
[HALFBAKED](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0151) can obtain information about the OS, processor, and BIOS.
[MiniDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0051)
can gather the hostname on a compromised machine.
[StreamEx](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0142) has the ability to enumerate system information.
[Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) collects the machine name and keyboard language from the system.
[Rocke](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0106) has used uname -m to collect the name and information about the infected system's kernel.
[Shark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1019) can collect the GUID of a targeted machine.
[Metamorfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0455) has collected the hostname and operating system version from the compromised host.
[KGH_SPY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0526) can collect drive information from a compromised host.

[admin@338](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0018) actors used the following commands after exploiting a machine with [LOWBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0042) malware to obtain information about the OS: "ver >> %temp%\download" "systeminfo >> %temp%\download"
[Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) can collect the hostname, Microsoft Windows version, and processor architecture from a victim machine.
[DarkComet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0334) can collect the computer name, RAM used, and operating system version from the victim’s machine.
[REvil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0496)
can identify the username, machine name, system language, keyboard layout, OS version, and system drive information on a compromised host.

During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used "fsutil" to check available free space before executing actions that might create large files on disk.
[OceanSalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0346)
can collect the computer name from the system.
[jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) collects information about the OS (version, build type, install date) as well as system up-time upon receiving a connection from a backdoor.
[BabyShark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0414) has executed the "ver" command.
[Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) has used “systeminfo” and similar commands to acquire detailed configuration information of a victim machine.
[SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) can collect information related to a compromised host, including OS version and a list of drives.
[Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) collects information about the OS and computer name.
[TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) can gather the disk volume information.
[TajMahal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0467) has the ability to identify hardware information, the computer name, and OS information on an infected host.
[Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) gathers the hostname and OS version from the victim’s machine.
[Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) used a backdoor to enumerate information about the infected system's operating system.
[PingPull](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1031)
can retrieve the hostname of a compromised host.
[Turian](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0647)
can retrieve system information including OS version, memory usage, local hostname, and system adapter information.

[BLINDINGCAN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0520) has collected from a victim machine the system name, processor information, OS version, and disk information, including type and free space available.
[MacMa](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1016)
can collect information about a compromised computer, including: Hardware UUID, Mac serial number, macOS version, and disk sizes.
[Neoichor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0691) can collect the OS version and computer name from a compromised host.
[ZLib](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0086) has the ability to enumerate system information.
[Ryuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0446)
has called "GetLogicalDrives" to emumerate all mounted drives, and "GetDriveTypeW" to determine the drive type.
[WINERACK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0219) can gather information about the host.
[Kobalos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0641)
can record the hostname and kernel version of the target machine.
[KillDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0607) retrieves the hard disk name by calling the "CreateFileA to \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE0" API.
[Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351)
can gather system information from the victim’s machine such as the OS version, machine name, and drive information.
[KOCTOPUS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0669) has checked the OS version using "wmic.exe" and the "find" command.
[Kasidet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0088) has the ability to obtain a victim's system name and operating system version.
[SslMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0058) sends information to its hard-coded C2, including OS version, service pack information, processor speed, system name, and OS install date.
[ThreatNeedle](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0665) can collect system profile information from a compromised host.
[Mustang Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0129) has gathered system information using "systeminfo".
[PLAINTEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0254) collects general system enumeration data about the infected machine and checks the OS version.
[FALLCHILL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0181) can collect operating system (OS) version information, processor information, system name, and information about installed disks from the victim.
[Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) can determine the operating system and whether a targeted machine has a 32 or 64 bit architecture.

During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), threat actors discovered the local disks attached to the system and their hardware information including manufacturer and model, as well as the OS versions of systems connected to a targeted network.
During [Frankenstein](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0001), the threat actors used [Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) to obtain the compromised machine's name.
[SUNBURST](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0559) collected hostname, OS version, and device uptime.

[KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) can gather the OS version, architecture information, connected drives, hostname, RAM size, and disk space information from the victim’s machine and has used "cmd /c systeminfo" command to get a snapshot of the current system state of the target machine.
[QuasarRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0262) can gather system information from the victim’s machine including the OS type.
[JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) obtains a build identifier as well as victim hard drive information from Windows registry key "HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\Disk\Enum".
Another [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) variant gathers the victim storage volume serial number and the storage device name.
[OSInfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0165) discovers information about the infected machine.
[FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) checks if the victim OS is 32 or 64-bit.

[SoreFang](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0516) can collect the hostname, operating system configuration, product ID, and disk space on victim machines by executing [Systeminfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0096).
[APT18](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0026) can collect system information from the victim’s machine.
[Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) has collected the hostname, OS version, service pack version, and the processor architecture from the victim’s machine.
[HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376)
has been observed collecting victim machine information like OS version, volume information, and more.
The [IceApple](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1022) Server Variable Dumper module iterates over all server variables present for the current request and returns them to the adversary.
[PUNCHBUGGY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0196)
can gather system information such as computer names.
[WellMess](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0514) can identify the computer name of a compromised host.
[Sys10](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0060)
collects the computer name, OS versioning information, and OS install date and sends the information to the C2.
[Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) monitors the free disk space on the system.
The initial beacon packet for [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) contains the operating system version of the victim.
A module in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) collects information from the victim about Windows OS version, computer name, battery info, and physical memory.
[Mongall](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1026)
can identify drives on compromised hosts and retrieve the hostname via "gethostbyname".
[Cadelspy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0454) has the ability to discover information about the compromised host.
[Sowbug](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0054) obtained OS version and hardware configuration from a victim.
[OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has run "hostname" and "systeminfo" on a victim.
[MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069)
has used malware that can collect the victim’s OS version and machine name.
[Bonadan](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0486) has discovered the OS version, CPU model, and RAM size of the system it has been installed on.
[Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081) executes "systeminfo" after initial communication is made to the remote server.
[HEXANE](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1001) has collected the hostname of a compromised machine.
[Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203)
creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve information such as computer name, OS version, processor speed, memory size, and CPU speed.
[ChChes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0144)
collects the victim hostname, window resolution, and Microsoft Windows version.
[Lucifer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0532)
can collect the computer name, system architecture, default language, and processor frequency of a compromised host.
[TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) gathers the OS version, machine name, CPU type, amount of RAM available, and UEFI/BIOS firmware information from the victim’s machine.
[4H RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0065) sends an OS version identifier in its beacons.
[Royal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1073) can use "GetNativeSystemInfo" and "GetLogicalDrives" to enumerate system processors and logical drives.
[SpicyOmelette](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0646) can identify the system name of a compromised host.
[Proxysvc](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0238) collects the OS version, country name, MAC address, computer name, physical memory statistics, and volume information for all drives on the system.
[Dtrack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0567)
can collect the victim's computer name, hostname and adapter information to create a unique identifier.
[Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363)
can enumerate host system information like OS, architecture, domain name, applied patches, and more.
[OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0352) collects processor information, memory information, computer name, hardware UUID, serial number, and operating system version.
[OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0352) has used the "ioreg" command to gather some of this information.
[PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378)
contains modules, such as "Get-ComputerInfo", for enumerating common system information.

can collect system information, including computer name, system manufacturer, IsDebuggerPresent state, and execution path.

The [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) malware platform supports many standard protocols, including SMB.
[Rocke](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0106) issued wget requests from infected systems to the C2.
[Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038)
uses a custom command and control protocol that communicates over commonly used ports, and is frequently encapsulated by application layer protocols.
[Hildegard](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0601) has used an IRC channel for C2 communications.
[TeamTNT](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0139) has used an IRC bot for C2 communications.
[Dragonfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0035) has used SMB for C2.
[Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) malware has used IRC for C2.
[Clambling](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0660) has the ability to use Telnet for communication.
[Lucifer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0532)
can use the Stratum protocol on port 10001 for communication between the cryptojacking bot and the mining server.
[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) can conduct peer-to-peer communication over Windows named pipes encapsulated in the SMB protocol.
All protocols use their standard assigned ports.
[Siloscape](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0623) connects to an IRC server for C2.
Adversaries can also use [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) to establish an RDP connection with a controller over TCP/7519.

[Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has moved staged encrypted archives to Internet-facing servers that had previously been compromised with [China Chopper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0020) prior to exfiltration.
[Chimera](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0114) has staged stolen data on designated servers in the target environment.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) actors have compressed data from remote systems and moved it to another staging system before exfiltration.
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has staged archives of collected data on a target's Outlook Web Access (OWA) server.
[ccf32](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1043) has copied files to a remote machine infected with [Chinoxy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1041) or another backdoor.
[menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has staged data on remote MSP systems or other victim networks prior to exfiltration.
During [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0002), threat actors copied files to company web servers and subsequently downloaded them.
[Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has staged data remotely prior to exfiltration.

During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) staged data and files in password-protected archives on a victim's OWA server.
[FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) aggregates staged data from a network into a single location.
[Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) schedules the execution one of its modules by creating a new scheduler task.
[Lokibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0447)'s second stage DLL has set a timer using “timeSetEvent” to schedule its next execution.

[DEADEYE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1052) has used the scheduled tasks "\Microsoft\Windows\PLA\Server Manager Performance Monitor", "\Microsoft\Windows\Ras\ManagerMobility", "\Microsoft\Windows\WDI\SrvSetupResults", and "\Microsoft\Windows\WDI\USOShared" to establish persistence.
[StrifeWater](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1034) has create a scheduled task named "Mozilla\Firefox Default Browser Agent 409046Z0FF4A39CB" for persistence.

[AppleJeus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0584) has been installed via MSI installer.

[ZIRCONIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0128) has used the msiexec.exe command-line utility to download and execute malicious MSI files.

[Strider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0041) has registered its persistence module on domain controllers as a Windows LSA (Local System Authority) password filter to acquire credentials any time a domain, local user, or administrator logs in or changes a password.

[Aria-body](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0456) has the ability to launch files using "ShellExecute".

) used several Windows API functions to gather information from the infected system.

has used a variety of Windows API calls, including "GetComputerNameA", "GetUserNameA", and "CreateProcessA".

can use Native API including "GetProcAddress" and "ShellExecuteW".

can use Native API for defense evasion, discovery, and collection.

can invoke Apple APIs "contentsOfDirectoryAtPath", "pathExtension", and (string) "compare"
[Chrommme](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0667) can use Windows API including "WinExec" for execution.

[OnionDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0052) can use a custom decryption algorithm to decrypt strings.
[Proton](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0279) uses an encrypted file to store commands and configuration values.
[Mafalda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1060) can decrypt files and data.

[Amadey](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1025) has decoded antivirus name strings.

[Egregor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0554) has been decrypted before execution.

[NOKKI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0353) uses a unique, custom de-obfuscation technique.

[Chrommme](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0667)
can decrypt its encrypted internal code.
[BBK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0470) has the ability to decrypt AES encrypted payloads.
[Conti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0575) has decrypted its payload using a hardcoded AES-256 key.
[Torisma](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0678) has used XOR and Base64 to decode C2 data.
[RainyDay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0629) can decrypt its payload via a XOR key.
[PipeMon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0501)
can decrypt password-protected executables.
[Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) decrypts ciphertext using an XOR cipher and a base64-encoded string.
[BackConfig](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0475) has used a custom routine to decrypt strings.
[FoggyWeb](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0661) can be decrypted in memory using a Lightweight Encryption Algorithm (LEA)-128 key and decoded using a XOR key.
[POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) can deobfuscate the main backdoor code.
[PowGoop](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1046) can decrypt PowerShell scripts for execution.
[ABK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0469) has the ability to decrypt AES encrypted payloads.
[Ruler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0358) can be used to automate the abuse of Outlook Rules to establish persistence.
[Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) has disabled LSA protection on compromised hosts using ""reg" add HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\LSA /v RunAsPPL /t REG_DWORD /d 0 /f".
[Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) reduces the integrity level of objects to allow write actions.
[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has used residential proxies, including Azure Virtual Machines, to obfuscate their access to victim environments.
[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has compromised email accounts to further enable phishing campaigns and taken control of dormant accounts.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has compromised email accounts to send spearphishing e-mails.
[HEXANE](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1001) has used compromised accounts to send spearphishing emails.
[Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) has compromised personal email accounts through the use of legitimate credentials and gathered additional victim information.
[IndigoZebra](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0136) has compromised legitimate email accounts to use in their spearphishing operations.
[LAPSUS$](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1004) has payed employees, suppliers, and business partners of target organizations for credentials.
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has used compromised email accounts to send credential phishing emails.
[Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has compromised email accounts to conduct social engineering attacks.
[Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has hosted malicious payloads on Dropbox.
[APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has hosted malicious payloads in Dropbox, Amazon S3, and Google Drive for use during targeting.
[TeamTNT](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0139) has uploaded backdoored Docker images to Docker Hub.
[Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) has registered domains to stage payloads.
For [C0021](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0021), the threat actors uploaded malware to websites under their control.
[EXOTIC LILY](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1011) has uploaded malicious payloads to file-sharing services including TransferNow, TransferXL, WeTransfer, and OneDrive.
For [Operation Dream Job](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0022), [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) used compromised servers to host malware.
[Earth Lusca](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1006) has staged malware and malicious files on compromised web servers, GitHub, and Google Drive.
[SideCopy](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1008) has used compromised domains to host its malicious payloads.
For [C0010](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0010), UNC3890 actors staged malware on their infrastructure for direct download onto a compromised system.
[Mustang Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0129)
has hosted malicious payloads on DropBox including [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013).
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094)
has used Blogspot to host malicious content such as beacons, file exfiltrators, and implants.
[HEXANE](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1001) has staged malware on fraudulent websites set up to impersonate targeted organizations.
[TA505](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092) has staged malware on actor-controlled domains.
[LuminousMoth](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1014) has hosted malicious payloads on Dropbox.
For [Operation Sharpshooter](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0013), the threat actors staged malicious files on Dropbox and other websites.
[LazyScripter](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0140) has hosted open-source remote access Trojans used in its operations in GitHub.
For [Operation Spalax](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0005), the threat actors staged malware and malicious files in legitimate hosting services such as OneDrive or MediaFire.
During [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0002), threat actors uploaded commonly available hacker tools to compromised web servers.
[BITTER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1002) has registered domains to stage payloads.
For [C0011](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0011), [Transparent Tribe](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0134) hosted malicious documents on domains registered by the group.
[Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) has compromised networks by exploiting Internet-facing applications, including vulnerable Microsoft Exchange and SharePoint servers.

[Earth Lusca](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1006) has compromised victims by directly exploiting vulnerabilities of public-facing servers, including those associated with Microsoft Exchange and Oracle GlassFish.
[Havij](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0224) is used to automate SQL injection.

[Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) has exploited the Log4j utility (CVE-2021-44228), on-premises MS Exchange servers via "ProxyShell" (CVE-2021-34473, CVE-2021-34523, CVE-2021-31207), and Fortios SSL VPNs (CVE-2018-13379).

During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) exploited CVE-2020-0688 against the Microsoft Exchange Control Panel to regain access to a network.

[Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has exploited the Microsoft SharePoint vulnerability CVE-2019-0604 and CVE-2021-26855, CVE-2021-26857, CVE-2021-26858, and CVE-2021-27065 in Exchange Server.

During [C0018](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0018), the threat actors exploited VMWare Horizon Unified Access Gateways that were vulnerable to several Log4Shell vulnerabilities, including CVE-2021-44228, CVE-2021-45046, CVE-2021-45105, and CVE-2021-44832.
[Siloscape](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0623) is executed after the attacker gains initial access to a Windows container using a known vulnerability.
[ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) has been dropped through exploitation of CVE-2011-2462, CVE-2013-3163, and CVE-2014-0322.
[menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has used vulnerabilities in Pulse Secure VPNs to hijack sessions.
[Moses Staff](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1009) has exploited known vulnerabilities in public-facing infrastructure such as Microsoft Exchange Servers.
[Axiom](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0001) has been observed using SQL injection to gain access to systems.
During [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0002), threat actors used SQL injection exploits against extranet web servers to gain access.
[Dragonfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0035)
has conducted SQL injection attacks, exploited vulnerabilities CVE-2019-19781 and CVE-2020-0688 for Citrix and MS Exchange, and CVE-2018-13379 for Fortinet VPNs.
[BackdoorDiplomacy](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0135) has exploited CVE-2020-5902, an F5 BIP-IP vulnerability, to drop a Linux backdoor.
[BackdoorDiplomacy](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0135) has also exploited mis-configured Plesk servers.
During [Operation CuckooBees](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0012), the threat actors exploited multiple vulnerabilities in externally facing servers.

[BlackTech](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0098) has exploited a buffer overflow vulnerability in Microsoft Internet Information Services (IIS) 6.0, CVE-2017-7269, in order to establish a new HTTP or command and control (C2) server.
[Fox Kitten](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0117) has exploited known vulnerabilities in Fortinet, PulseSecure, and Palo Alto VPN appliances.
[Blue Mockingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0108) has gained initial access by exploiting CVE-2019-18935, a vulnerability within Telerik UI for ASP.NET AJAX.
During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), threat actors gained initial access by exploiting vulnerabilities in JBoss webservers.
[sqlmap](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0225) can be used to automate exploitation of SQL injection vulnerabilities.

[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has exploited CVE-2019-19781 for Citrix, CVE-2019-11510 for Pulse Secure VPNs, CVE-2018-13379 for FortiGate VPNs, and CVE-2019-9670 in Zimbra software to gain access.

[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) exploited CVE-2020-10189 against Zoho ManageEngine Desktop Central, and CVE-2019-19781 to compromise Citrix Application Delivery Controllers (ADC) and gateway devices.

[HAFNIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0125) has exploited CVE-2021-26855, CVE-2021-26857, CVE-2021-26858, and CVE-2021-27065 to compromise on-premises versions of Microsoft Exchange Server, enabling access to email accounts and installation of additional malware.
[Rocke](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0106) exploited Apache Struts, Oracle WebLogic (CVE-2017-10271), and Adobe ColdFusion (CVE-2017-3066) vulnerabilities to deliver malware.
[Volatile Cedar](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0123) has targeted publicly facing web servers, with both automatic and manual vulnerability discovery.

[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has used a variety of public exploits, including CVE 2020-0688 and CVE 2020-17144, to gain execution on vulnerable Microsoft Exchange; they have also conducted SQL injection attacks against external websites.
[SoreFang](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0516) can gain access by exploiting a Sangfor SSL VPN vulnerability that allows for the placement and delivery of malicious update binaries.
[MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069)
has exploited the Microsoft Exchange memory corruption vulnerability (CVE-2020-0688).
[GALLIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) exploited a publicly-facing servers including Wildfly/JBoss servers to gain access to the network.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has exploited various vulnerabilities for initial access, including Microsoft Exchange vulnerability CVE-2020-0688.
[GOLD SOUTHFIELD](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0115) has exploited Oracle WebLogic vulnerabilities for initial compromise.

During [C0017](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0017), [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) exploited CVE-2021-44207 in the USAHerds application and CVE-2021-44228 in Log4j, as well as other .NET deserialization, SQL injection, and directory traversal vulnerabilities to gain initial access.
[APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has used SQL injection for initial compromise.
[APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has used the Smartftp Password Decryptor tool to decrypt FTP passwords.

[MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has performed credential dumping with [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) and other tools, including by dumping passwords saved in victim email.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used the Stealer One credential stealer to target e-mail and file transfer utilities including FTP.

[Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) performs credential dumping to obtain account and password information useful in gaining access to additional systems and enterprise network resources.
It contains functionality to acquire information about credentials in many ways, including from the credential vault and DPAPI.
[Matryoshka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0167) is capable of stealing Outlook passwords.
[Stealth Falcon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0038) malware gathers passwords from multiple sources, including Windows Credential Vault and Outlook.

[OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used credential dumping tools such as [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.
[HEXANE](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1001) has run "cmdkey" on victim machines to identify stored credentials.
[Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) can use Lazagne for harvesting credentials.
[KGH_SPY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0526) can collect credentials from WINSCP.

can obtain credentials from databases, mail, and WiFi across multiple platforms.
[QuasarRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0262) can obtain passwords from common FTP clients.
[OLDBAIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0138) collects credentials from several email clients.
[Lokibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0447) has stolen credentials from multiple applications and data sources including Windows OS credentials, email clients, FTP, and SFTP clients.

[Carberp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0484)'s passw.plug plugin can gather account information from multiple instant messaging, email, and social media services, as well as FTP, VNC, and VPN clients.
[PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378)
can decrypt passwords stored in the RDCMan configuration file.
[Leafminer](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0077) used several tools for retrieving login and password information, including LaZagne.
[Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) uses an external software known as NetPass to recover passwords.
[Evilnum](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0120) can collect email credentials from victims.
A module in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) collects passwords stored in applications installed on the victim.
[PLEAD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0435) has the ability to steal saved passwords from Microsoft Outlook.
[PinchDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0048) steals credentials from compromised hosts.
[PinchDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0048)'s credential stealing functionality is believed to be based on the source code of the Pinch credential stealing malware (also known as LdPinch).

Credentials targeted by [PinchDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0048) include ones associated with many sources such as The Bat!, Yahoo!, Mail.ru, Passport.Net, Google Talk, and Microsoft Outlook.

[CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) collects user credentials, including passwords, for various programs including popular instant messaging applications and email clients as well as WLAN keys.
[Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) has the ability to steal credentials from FTP clients and wireless profiles.
[APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has used a variety of publicly available tools like [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) to gather credentials.
[NETWIRE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0198) can retrieve passwords from messaging and mail client applications.

During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used account credentials they obtained to attempt access to Group Managed Service Account (gMSA) passwords.
