can run shellcode it injects into a newly created process.
During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), threat actors injected code into a selected process, which in turn launches a command as a child process of the original.
[HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has injected into running processes.
[SLOTHFULMEDIA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0533) can inject into running processes on a compromised host.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has used Win7Elevate to inject malicious code into explorer.exe.
[ABK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0469) has the ability to inject shellcode into svchost.exe.
[Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) injects itself into explorer.exe.
[Bumblebee](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1039) can inject code into multiple processes on infected endpoints.
[HTRAN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0040) can inject into into running processes.
[Egregor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0554) can inject its payload into iexplore.exe process.
During [Operation Sharpshooter](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0013), threat actors used embedded shellcode to inject a downloader into the memory of Word.
[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) can inject a variety of payloads into processes dynamically chosen by the adversary.
[IronNetInjector](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0581) can use an IronPython scripts to load a .NET injector to inject a payload into its own or a remote process.
[REvil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0496) can inject itself into running processes on a compromised host.
[Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) injects into a newly spawned process created from a native Windows executable.
[Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) injects into the Internet Explorer process.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) malware TIDYELF loaded the main WINTERLOVE component by injecting it into the iexplore.exe process.
[WarzoneRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0670)
has the ability to inject malicious DLLs into a specific process for privilege escalation.

[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can inject itself into another process to avoid detection including use of a technique called ListPlanting that customizes the sorting algorithm in a ListView structure.
[Wiarp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0206)
creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can inject files into running processes.
[Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) contains multiple modules for injecting into processes, such as "Invoke-PSInject".
[Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176)
performs multiple process injections to hijack system processes and execute malicious code.
[Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can inject into known, vulnerable binaries on targeted hosts.
[Donut](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0695) includes a subproject "DonutTest" to inject shellcode into a target process.
[gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) can inject malicious code into process created by the “Command_Create&Inject” function.
[TSCookie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0436) has the ability to inject code into the svchost.exe, iexplorer.exe, explorer.exe, and default browser processes.
[SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) can inject shellcode directly into Excel.exe or a specific process.
[Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) has been injected directly into a running process, including "explorer.exe".

[Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has also used [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194)'s "Invoke-ReflectivePEInjection.ps1" to reflectively load a PowerShell payload into a random process on the victim system.
[Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080)
has injected code into trusted processes.
[APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) injects its malware variant, [ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240), into the cmd.exe process.
[NavRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0247) copies itself into a running Internet Explorer process to evade detection.
[Silence](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0091) has injected a DLL library containing a Trojan into the fwmain32.exe process.
[Pandora](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0664)
can start and inject code into a new "svchost" process.
[Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438)'s dispatcher can inject itself into running processes to gain higher privileges and to evade detection.
[JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) performs code injection injecting its own functions to browser processes.
[PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) contains multiple modules for injecting into processes, such as "Invoke-PSInject".
[ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) can use "VirtualAlloc", "WriteProcessMemory", and then "CreateRemoteThread" to execute shellcode within the address space of "Notepad.exe".
[Lizar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0681) can migrate the loader into another process.
The [PcShare](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1050) payload has been injected into the "logagent.exe" and "rdpclip.exe" processes.
[Clambling](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0660) can inject into the "svchost.exe" process for execution.
[metaMain](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1059) can inject the loader file, Speech02.db, into a process.
[Avenger](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0473) has the ability to inject shellcode into svchost.exe.
[Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) can inject code through calling "VirtualAllocExNuma".
[TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) has used "Nt*" [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) functions to inject code into legitimate processes such as "wermgr.exe".
[PLATINUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0068) has used various methods of process injection including hot patching.
[GuLoader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0561) has the ability to inject shellcode into a donor processes that is started in a suspended state.
[GuLoader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0561) has previously used RegAsm as a donor process.
[StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) has relied on injecting its payload directly into the process memory of the victim's preferred browser.
[Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168)
injects its communication module into an Internet accessible process through which it performs C2.
[Ryuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0446) has injected itself into remote processes to encrypt files using a combination of "VirtualAlloc", "WriteProcessMemory", and "CreateRemoteThread".
[Pandora](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0664) can identify if incoming HTTP traffic contains a token and if so it will intercept the traffic and process the received command.
[SYNful Knock](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0519) can be sent instructions via special packets to change its functionality.
Code for new functionality can be included in these messages.
[Penquin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0587) will connect to C2 only after sniffing a "magic packet" value in TCP or UDP packets matching specific conditions.
[Chaos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0220)
provides a reverse shell is triggered upon receipt of a packet with a special string, sent to any port.
[Umbreon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0221) provides additional access using its backdoor Espeon, providing a reverse shell upon receipt of a special packet.
[Ryuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0446) has used Wake-on-Lan to power on turned off systems for lateral movement.
[Kobalos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0641) is triggered by an incoming TCP connection to a legitimate service from a specific source port.

[Winnti for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0430) has used a passive listener, capable of identifying a specific magic value before executing tasking, as a secondary command and control (C2) mechanism.
[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) lnk files used for persistence have abused the Windows Update Client ("wuauclt.exe") to execute a malicious DLL.
[Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) extracts and writes driver files that match the times of other legitimate files.
[Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) has manipulated the time of last access to files and registry keys after they have been created or modified.
[Winnti for Windows](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0141) can set the timestamps for its worker and service components to match that of cmd.exe.

Several [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware families use timestomping, including modifying the last write timestamp of a specified Registry key to a random date, as well as copying the timestamp for legitimate .exe files (such as calc.exe or mspaint.exe) to its dropped files.
[BitPaymer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0570) can modify the timestamp of an executable so that it can be identified and restored by the decryption tool.

After creating a new service for persistence, [TDTESS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0164) sets the file creation time for the service to the creation time of the victim's legitimate svchost.exe file.
[POSHSPY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0150) modifies timestamps of all downloaded executables to match a randomly selected file created prior to 2013.
[Psylo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0078) has a command to conduct timestomping by setting a specified file’s timestamps to match those of a system file in the System32 directory.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has manipulated timestamps for creation or compilation dates to defeat anti-forensics.
[SEASHARPEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0185) can timestomp files on victims using a Web shell.
[APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050)
has used scheduled task raw XML with a backdated timestamp of June 2, 2016.
The group has also set the creation time of the files dropped by the second stage of the exploit to match the creation time of kernel32.dll.
Additionally, [APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has used a random value to modify the timestamp of the file storing the clientID.
[Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) modifies the time of a file as specified by the control server.
[Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) can timestomp any files or payloads placed on a target machine to help them blend in.
[TAINTEDSCRIBE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0586)
can change the timestamp of specified filenames.
[APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) has modified data timestamps to mimic files that are in the same folder on a compromised host.
[metaMain](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1059) can change the "CreationTime", "LastAccessTime", and "LastWriteTime" file time attributes when executed with "SYSTEM" privileges.
During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) modified timestamps of backdoors to match legitimate Windows files.
[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) can timestomp any files or payloads placed on a target machine to help them blend in.
[FALLCHILL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0181) can modify file or directory timestamps.
Many [Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) samples were programmed using Borland Delphi, which will mangle the default PE compile timestamp of a file.

[Kobalos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0641) can modify timestamps of replaced files, such as "ssh" with the added credential stealer or "sshd" used to deploy [Kobalos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0641).
[Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) can change the modified time for files to evade forensic detection.
[OwaAuth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0072)
has a command to timestop a file or directory.
[Chimera](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0114) has used a Windows version of the Linux "touch" command to modify the date and time stamp on DLLs.
[PowerStallion](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0393) modifies the MAC times of its local log files to match that of the victim's desktop.ini file.
[OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0352) can use the "touch -t" command to change timestamps.
[KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) time-stomped its DLL in order to evade detection.
[China Chopper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0020)'s server component can change the timestamp of files.
[USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) sets the timestamps of its dropper files to the last-access and last-write timestamps of a standard Windows library chosen on the system.
The [Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) malware supports timestomping.
For early [Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) versions, the compilation timestamp was faked.
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has performed timestomping on victim files.
[3PARA RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0066) has a command to set certain attributes such as creation/modification timestamps on files.
[Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081) performs timestomping of a CAB file it creates.
[Cyclops Blink](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0687) has the ability to use the Linux API function "utime" to change the timestamps of modified firmware update images.
[Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) has the ability to perform timestomping of files on targeted systems.
[EVILNUM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0568) has changed the creation date of files.
[MacMa](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1016) has the capability to create and modify file timestamps.
[Rocke](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0106) has changed the time stamp of certain files.
[TEMP.Veles](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0088) used timestomping to modify the $STANDARD_INFORMATION attribute on tools.
[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) samples were timestomped by the authors by setting the PE timestamps to all zero values.
[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) also has a built-in command to modify file times.
[PingPull](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1031) has the ability to timestomp a file.
[BLINDINGCAN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0520) has modified file and directory timestamps.
[Donut](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0695) can generate code modules that enable in-memory execution of VBScript, JScript, EXE, DLL, and dotNET payloads.
[IceApple](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1022) can use reflective code loading to load .NET assemblies into "MSExchangeOWAAppPool" on targeted Exchange servers.
[FoggyWeb](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0661)'s loader has reflectively loaded .NET-based assembly/payloads into memory.
[PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) reflectively loads a Windows PE file into a process.
[Lokibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0447) has reflectively loaded the decoded DLL into memory.
[WhisperGate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0689)'s downloader can reverse its third stage file bytes and reflectively load the file as a .NET assembly.

[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) has changed memory protection permissions then overwritten in memory DLL function code with shellcode, which was later executed via [KernelCallbackTable](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1574/013) hijacking.
[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032)
has also used shellcode within macros to decrypt and manually map DLLs into memory at runtime.
[Cuba](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0625) loaded the payload into memory using PowerShell.
[Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) can use custom shellcode to map embedded DLLs into memory.
[metaMain](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1059)
has reflectively loaded a DLL to read, decrypt, and load an orchestrator file.
[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154)'s "execute-assembly" command can run a .NET executable within the memory of a sacrificial process by loading the CLR.
[ThiefQuest](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0595) uses various API functions such as "NSCreateObjectFileImageFromMemory" to load and link in-memory payloads.
[Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) has used reflective loading to execute malicious DLLs.
[TeamTNT](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0139) has deployed privileged containers that mount the filesystem of victim machine.
[Hildegard](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0601) has used the BOtB tool that can break out of containers.
[Siloscape](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0623) maps the host’s C drive to the container by creating a global symbolic link to the host through the calling of "NtSetInformationSymbolicLink".
[Peirates](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0683)
can gain a reverse shell on a host node by mounting the Kubernetes hostPath.
[Doki](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0600)’s container was configured to bind the host root directory.
[RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) attempts to add a shortcut file in the Startup folder to achieve persistence.
[Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) establishes persistence by creating a shortcut.
[Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) adds a .lnk file to the Windows startup folder.
[Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373)'s initial payload is a malicious .LNK file.
[FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) creates a .LNK file for persistence.
[Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) can establish persistence by creating a .lnk shortcut to itself in the Startup folder.
[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can use a .lnk shortcut for the Control Panel to establish persistence.
[Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363)
can persist by modifying a .LNK file to include a backdoor.
[Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) creates a shortcut to maintain persistence.
[Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) can establish persistence by writing shortcuts to the Windows Startup folder.
[TinyZBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0004)
can create a shortcut in the Windows startup folder for persistence.
[SeaDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0053) is capable of persisting via a .lnk file stored in the Startup directory.
[SHIPSHAPE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0028) achieves persistence by creating a shortcut in the Startup folder.
A version of [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) drops a Windows shortcut on the victim’s machine to establish persistence.
[Comnie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0244) establishes persistence via a .lnk file in the victim’s startup path.
[MarkiRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0652)
can modify the shortcut that launches Telegram by replacing its path with the malicious payload to launch with the legitimate executable.
[Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) creates a shortcut file and saves it in a Startup folder to establish persistence.

To establish persistence, [SslMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0058) identifies the Start Menu Startup directory and drops a link to its own executable disguised as an “Office Start,” “Yahoo Talk,” “MSN Gaming Z0ne,” or “MSN Talk” shortcut.

[S-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0085) may create the file "%HOMEPATH%\Start Menu\Programs\Startup\Realtek {Unique Identifier}.lnk", which points to the malicious "msdtc.exe" file already created in the "%CommonFiles%" directory.
[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware has maintained persistence on a system by creating a LNK shortcut in the user’s Startup folder.
[Grandoreiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0531) can write or modify browser shortcuts to enable launching of malicious browser extensions.
[Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has used JavaScript to create a shortcut file in the Startup folder that points to its main backdoor.
[RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) establishes persistence by creating a shortcut (.LNK file) in the Windows startup folder to run a script each time the user logs in.
[Gorgon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0078) malware can create a .lnk file and add a Registry Run key to establish persistence.
[Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) can establish persistence by creating a .lnk file in the Start menu or by modifying existing .lnk files to execute the malware through cmd.exe.
[BACKSPACE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0031) achieves persistence by creating a shortcut to itself in the CSIDL_STARTUP directory.
[APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has modified LNK shortcuts.
The [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) 3 variant drops its main DLL component and then creates a .lnk shortcut to that file in the startup folder.
[SPACESHIP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0035) achieves persistence by creating a shortcut in the current user's Startup folder.
[DarkWatchman](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0673) reports window names along with keylogger information to provide application context.
[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware IndiaIndia obtains and sends to its C2 server the title of the window for each running process.
The KilaAlfa keylogger also reports the title of the window in the foreground.
[njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) gathers information about opened windows during the initial infection.
[Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) can monitor the titles of open windows to identify specific keywords.
[HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) has the ability to list the names of all open windows on the infected host.
[PLEAD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0435) has the ability to list open windows on the compromised host.
[NetTraveler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0033) reports window names along with keylogger information to provide application context.
[SOUNDBITE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0157) is capable of enumerating application windows.
[FunnyDream](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1044) has the ability to discover application windows via execution of "EnumWindows".
[Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265)
gathers information about opened windows.
[Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) can obtain application window titles and then determines which windows to perform Screen Capture on.
[Flagpro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0696) can check the name of the window displayed on the system.
[Cadelspy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0454) has the ability to identify open windows on the compromised host.
[Aria-body](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0456) has the ability to identify the titles of running windows on a compromised host.
[QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) has the ability to enumerate windows on a compromised host.
[HEXANE](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1001) has used a PowerShell-based keylogging tool to capture the window title.
[Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) saves the window names.
[Grandoreiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0531)
can identify installed security tools based on window names.
[PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) has a command to get text of the current foreground window.
[ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) can use the "GetForegroundWindow" and "GetWindowText" APIs to discover where the user is typing.
[NETWIRE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0198)
can discover and close windows on controlled systems.
[WINERACK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0219) can enumerate active windows.
[Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) has a command to capture active windows on the machine and retrieve window titles.
[SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) can enumerate the active Window during keylogging through execution of "GetActiveWindowTitle".
[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can enumerate windows and child windows on a compromised host.
[PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012)
captures window titles.
The discovery modules used with [Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) can collect information on open windows.
[Metamorfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0455) can enumerate all windows on the victim’s machine.
[Catchamas](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0261)
obtains application windows titles and then determines which windows to perform [Screen Capture](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1113) on.
[Grandoreiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0531) can parse Outlook .pst files to extract e-mail addresses.
[MailSniper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0413) can be used to obtain account names from Exchange and Office 365 using the "Get-GlobalAddressList" cmdlet.
[TA505](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092) has used the tool EmailStealer to steal and send lists of e-mail addresses to a remote server.
[Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) used malware to enumerate email settings, including usernames and passwords, from the M.E.Doc application.
[Lizar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0681) can collect email accounts from Microsoft Outlook and Mozilla Thunderbird.
[Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093)
collects address book information from Outlook.
[TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) collects email addresses from Outlook.
[Ruler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0358) can be used to enumerate Exchange users and dump the GAL.
[Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367)
has been observed using a module that can scrape email addresses from Outlook.
[Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) has used Powershell to discover email accounts.
[BoomBox](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0635) can execute an LDAP query to discover e-mail accounts for domain users.
[SVCReady](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1064) can enter a sleep stage for 30 minutes to evade detection.
[Bumblebee](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1039) has the ability to set a hardcoded and randomized sleep interval.
[Saint Bot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1018) has used the command "timeout 20" to pause the execution of its initial loader.
[BendyBear](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0574) can check for analysis environments and signs of debugging using the Windows API "kernel32!GetTickCountKernel32" call.
[Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) can use a timer to delay execution of core functionality.

[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) has compressed exfiltrated data with RAR and used RomeoDelta malware to archive specified directories in .zip format, encrypt the .zip file, and upload it to C2.
[KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) has encrypted data and files prior to exfiltration.
[TAINTEDSCRIBE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0586) has used "FileReadZipSend" to compress a file and send to C2.
The [Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) group has been known to compress data before exfiltration.
[Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) can ZIP directories on the target system.
[BLUELIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0657) can zip files before exfiltration.
[Gold Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0249) encrypts data using Base64 before being sent to the command and control server.
[XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) will compress entire "~/Desktop" folders excluding all ".git" folders, but only if the total data size is under 200MB.
[Proton](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0279) zips up files before exfiltrating them.
[Cadelspy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0454) has the ability to compress stolen data into a .cab file.
[Pillowmint](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0517) has encrypted stolen credit card information with AES and further encoded it with Base64.
After collecting documents from removable media, [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) compresses the collected files, and encrypts it with Blowfish.
[Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) stores zipped files with profile data from installed web browsers.
Following data collection, [FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has compressed log files into a ZIP archive prior to staging and exfiltration.
[Aria-body](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0456) has used ZIP to compress data gathered on a compromised host.
[Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) hides collected data in password-protected .rar archives.
[Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) has used a method similar to RC4 as well as AES for encryption and hexadecimal for encoding data before exfiltration.
[LuminousMoth](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1014) has manually archived stolen files from victim machines before exfiltration.
[WellMail](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0515) can archive files on the compromised host.
[Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) writes collected data to a temporary file in an encrypted form before exfiltration to a C2 server.
[Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091)
encrypts collected data using a public key framework before sending it over the C2 channel.
Some variants encrypt the collected data with AES and encode it with base64 before transmitting it to the C2 server.
[AppleSeed](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0622) has compressed collected data before exfiltration.
[Chrommme](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0667)
can encrypt and store on disk collected data before exfiltration.
[Dtrack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0567) packs collected data into a password protected archive.
[BloodHound](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0521) can compress data collected by its SharpHound ingestor into a ZIP file to be written to disk.
[Dragonfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0035) has compressed data into .zip files prior to exfiltration.
[ShimRatReporter](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0445) used LZ compression to compress initial reconnaissance reports before sending to the C2.
[QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) can use advanced web injects to steal web banking credentials.
[Melcoz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0530) can monitor the victim's browser for online banking sessions and display an overlay window to manipulate the session in the background.
[TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266)
uses web injects and browser redirection to trick the user into providing their login credentials on a fake or modified web page.
[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) can perform browser pivoting and inject into a user's browser to inherit cookies, authenticated HTTP sessions, and client SSL certificates.
[Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has injected HTML codes into banking sites to steal sensitive online banking information (ex: usernames and passwords).
[Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) has the ability to use form-grabbing to extract data from web data forms.

[Grandoreiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0531) can monitor browser activity for online banking actions and display full-screen overlay images to block user access to the intended site or present additional data fields.
[IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483) has used web injection attacks to redirect victims to spoofed sites designed to harvest banking and other credentials.

[IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483) can use a self signed TLS certificate in connection with the spoofed site and simultaneously maintains a live connection with the legitimate site to display the correct URL and certificates in the browser.
[Carberp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0484) has captured credentials when a user performs login through a SSL session.
[Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384) can perform browser attacks via web injects to steal information such as credentials, certificates, and cookies.
[Chaes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0631) has used the Puppeteer module to hook and monitor the Chrome web browser to collect user information from infected hosts.
[Kivars](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0437) has the ability to remotely trigger keyboard input and mouse clicks.
[Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) has the ability to use RPC for lateral movement.
[MacMa](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1016)
can manage remote screen sessions.
[Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) can propagate via peer-to-peer communication and updates using RPC.
[APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has used email for C2 via an Office macro.
[LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) uses SMTP for C2.
A [SUGARDUMP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1042) variant used SMTP for C2.
[Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) is capable of using SMTP for C2.
[Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) has used SMTP for C2 communications.
[NavRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0247) uses the email platform, Naver, for C2 communications, using SMTP.
[JPIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0201) can send email over SMTP.
[SilverTerrier](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0083) uses SMTP for C2 communications.
[Goopy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0477) has the ability to use a Microsoft Outlook backdoor macro to communicate with its C2.
[RDAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0495) can use email attachments for C2 communications.

[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has used IMAP, POP3, and SMTP for a communication channel in various implants, including using self-registered Google Mail accounts and later compromised email servers of its victims.
[Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351)
uses SMTP/S and POP3/S for C2 communications by sending and receiving emails.
[ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) can use email attachments for command and control.
[Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used multiple backdoors which communicate with a C2 server via email attachments.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has used e-mail to send exfiltrated data to C2 servers.
[CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) can communicate over SMTP and POP3 for C2.
[Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) uses SMTP and POP3 for C2.
[OLDBAIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0138) can use SMTP for C2.
[BadPatch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0337) uses SMTP for C2.
Various implementations of [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) communicate with C2 over SMTP and POP3.
[AADInternals](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0677) can inject a malicious DLL ("PTASpy") into the "AzureADConnectAuthenticationAgentService" to backdoor Azure AD Pass-Through Authentication.

[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has edited the "Microsoft.IdentityServer.Servicehost.exe.config" file to load a malicious DLL into the AD FS process, thereby enabling persistent access to any service federated with AD FS for a user with a specified User Principal Name.
[Volatile Cedar](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0123) has performed vulnerability scans of the target server.
[Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) has scanned network infrastructure for vulnerabilities as part of its operational planning.

[Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) has conducted widespread scanning to identify public-facing systems vulnerable to CVE-2021-44228 in Log4j and ProxyShell vulnerabilities; CVE-2021-26855, CVE-2021-26857, CVE-2021-26858, and CVE-2021-27065 in on-premises MS Exchange Servers; and CVE-2018-13379 in Fortinet FortiOS SSL VPNs.
[Aquatic Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0143) has used publicly accessible DNS logging services to identify servers vulnerable to Log4j (CVE 2021-44228).
[Earth Lusca](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1006) has scanned for vulnerabilities in the public-facing servers of their targets.
[TeamTNT](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0139) has scanned for vulnerabilities in IoT devices and other related resources such as the Docker API.
[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has conducted widespread scanning of target environments to identify vulnerabilities for exploit.
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has performed large-scale scans in an attempt to find vulnerable servers.
[Dragonfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0035) has scanned targeted systems for vulnerable Citrix and Microsoft Exchange services.
[TeamTNT](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0139) has used AWS CLI to enumerate cloud environments with compromised credentials.
[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has used the Microsoft Graph API to perform various actions across Azure and M365 environments.
They have also utilized AADInternals PowerShell Modules to access the API
[Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002)’s "LSADUMP::DCShadow" module can be used to make AD updates by temporarily setting a computer to be a DC.
[Hikit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0009) has attempted to disable driver signing verification by tampering with several Registry keys prior to the loading of a rootkit driver component.
[APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has used malware to turn off the "RequireSigned" feature which ensures only signed DLLs can be run on Windows.
[BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) has enabled the "TESTSIGNING" boot configuration option to facilitate loading of a driver component.
[Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has modified variables in kernel memory to turn off Driver Signature Enforcement after exploiting vulnerabilities that obtained kernel mode privileges.
[Pandora](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0664) can use CVE-2017-15303 to disable Windows Driver Signature Enforcement (DSE) protection and load its driver.
[Peirates](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0683) can deploy a pod that mounts its node’s root file system, then execute a command to create a reverse shell on the node.
[TeamTNT](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0139) has deployed different types of containers into victim environments to facilitate execution.
[TeamTNT](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0139) has also transferred cryptocurrency mining software to Kubernetes clusters discovered within local IP address ranges.
[Kinsing](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0599) was run through a deployed Ubuntu container.
[Doki](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0600) was run through a deployed container.
[Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has modify Registry values to store payloads.
[PLAINTEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0254) uses "reg add" to add a Registry Run key for persistence.
[Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can achieve persistence by modifying Registry key entries.
[HyperStack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0537) can add the name of its communication pipe to "HKLM\SYSTEM\\CurrentControlSet\\Services\\lanmanserver\\parameters\NullSessionPipes".
[FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has deleted Registry keys during post compromise cleanup activities.
[Avaddon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0640)
modifies several registry keys for persistence and UAC bypass.
[ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) has modified Registry values to store encrypted orchestrator code and payloads.
[APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) uses a tool called CLEANTOAD that has the capability to modify Registry keys.
[Prestige](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1058) has the ability to register new registry keys for a new extension handler via "HKCR\.enc" and "HKCR\enc\shell\open\command".

[SUNBURST](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0559) had commands that allow an attacker to write or delete registry keys, and was observed stopping services by setting their "HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\services\\[service_name]\\Start" registry entries to value 4.
It also deleted previously-created Image File Execution Options (IFEO) Debugger registry values and registry keys related to HTTP proxy to clean up traces of its activity.
[ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) is capable of setting and deleting Registry values.
During [Operation Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0006), the threat actors used batch files that modified registry keys.
[GreyEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0342)
modifies conditions in the Registry and adds keys.
[Waterbear](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0579) has deleted certain values from the Registry to load a malicious DLL.

A [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) payload deletes Resiliency Registry keys created by Microsoft Office applications in an apparent effort to trick users into thinking there were no issues during application runs.
[Neoichor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0691) has the ability to configure browser settings by modifying Registry entries under "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Internet Explorer".
[PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) creates a Registry subkey that registers a new system device.
[Pillowmint](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0517) has modified the Registry key "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\DRM" to store a malicious payload.

[BADCALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0245) modifies the firewall Registry key "SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\SharedAccess\Parameters\FirewallPolicy\StandardProfileGloballyOpenPorts\\List".
[Mafalda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1060) can manipulate the system registry on a compromised host.
[WastedLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0612) can modify registry values within the "Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings\ZoneMap" registry key.
[RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148)
can delete all Registry entries created during its execution.
[RCSession](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0662) can write its configuration file to the Registry.
[Mori](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1047) can write data to "HKLM\Software\NFC\IPA" and "HKLM\Software\NFC\" and delete Registry values.
[RegDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0511) can create seemingly legitimate Registry key to store its encryption key.
[Rover](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0090) has functionality to remove Registry Run key persistence as a cleanup procedure.
[TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266)
can modify registry entries.
[Orz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0229) can perform Registry operations.
[WarzoneRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0670)
can create "HKCU\Software\Classes\Folder\shell\open\command" as a new registry key during privilege escalation.

During [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0002), threat actors used [zwShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0350) to establish full remote control of the connected machine and manipulate the Registry.
[CharmPower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0674)
can remove persistence-related artifacts from the Registry.
[LuminousMoth](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1014) has used malware that adds Registry keys for persistence.
[Silence](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0091) can create, delete, or modify a specified Registry key or value.
[ShimRat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0444) has registered two registry keys for shim databases.
Once [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) has access to a network share, it enables the RemoteRegistry service on the target system.

It will then connect to the system with RegConnectRegistryW and modify the Registry to disable UAC remote restrictions by setting "SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\System\LocalAccountTokenFilterPolicy" to 1.
[Clop](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0611) can make modifications to Registry keys.
[QuasarRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0262) has a command to edit the Registry on the victim’s machine.
[FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) deletes the Registry key "HKCU\Software\Classes\Applications\rundll32.exe\shell\open".
[gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) has altered the InstallTime subkey.
[Conficker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0608) adds keys to the Registry at "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services" and various other Registry locations.
[Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used Registry modifications as part of its installation routine.
[PcShare](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1050) can delete its persistence mechanisms from the registry.
[Blue Mockingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0108) has used Windows Registry modifications to specify a DLL payload.
[Valak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0476) has the ability to modify the Registry key "HKCU\Software\ApplicationContainer\Appsw64" to store information regarding the C2 server and downloads.

[metaMain](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1059) can write the process ID of a target process into the "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\DDE\tpid" Registry value as part of its reflective loading activity.
[Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256) can modify Registry keys under "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\[dllname]" to store configuration values.
[Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256) also modifies Registry keys under "HKCR\CLSID\...\InprocServer32" with a path to the launcher.

[TajMahal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0467) can set the "KeepPrintedJobs" attribute for configured printers in "SOFTWARE\\Microsoft\\WindowsNT\\CurrentVersion\\Print\\Printers" to enable document stealing.
[KEYMARBLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0271) has a command to create Registry entries for storing data under "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\WABE\DataPath".
[DarkWatchman](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0673) can modify Registry values to store configuration strings, keylogger, and output of components.

[DarkComet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0334) adds a Registry value for its installation routine to the Registry Key "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\System Enable LUA=”0”" and "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\DC3_FEXEC".
[QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) can modify the Registry to store its configuration information in a randomly named subkey under "HKCU\Software\Microsoft".
[Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) can modify the Registry to store its components.
[Lokibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0447) has modified the Registry as part of its UAC bypass process.
[SynAck](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0242) can manipulate Registry keys.
[TinyTurla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0668)

[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) can modify Registry values within "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Office\<Excel Version>\Excel\Security\AccessVBOM\" to enable the execution of additional code.
[Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) has modified Registry settings for security tools.
[Clambling](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0660) can set and delete Registry keys.

[Pysa](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0583) has modified the registry key “SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies\System” and added the ransom note.
[KOCTOPUS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0669) has added and deleted keys from the Registry.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used a malware variant called GOODLUCK to modify the registry in order to steal credentials.
[ShadowPad](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0596) can modify the Registry to store and maintain a configuration block and virtual file system.
[Grandoreiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0531) can modify the Registry to store its configuration at "HKCU\Software\" under frequently changing names including "%USERNAME%" and "ToolTech-RM".
[njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) can create, delete, or modify a specified Registry key or value.
[Dragonfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0035) has modified the Registry to perform multiple techniques through the use of [Reg](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0075).
[BitPaymer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0570) can set values in the Registry to help in execution.
[PHOREAL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0158) is capable of manipulating the Registry.

[LoJax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0397) has modified the Registry key "‘HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\BootExecute’" from "‘autocheck autochk *’" to "‘autocheck autoche *’".

[PowerShower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0441) has added a registry key so future powershell.exe instances are spawned off-screen by default, and has removed all registry entries that are left behind during the dropper process.
[TEARDROP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0560) modified the Registry to create a Windows service for itself on a compromised host.
[Chaes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0631)
can modify Registry values to stored information and establish persistence.
[Amadey](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1025) has overwritten registry keys for persistence.
[NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336) has the capability to edit the Registry.
[SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) can modify registry keys, including to enable or disable Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP).
[Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) writes data into the Registry key "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Pniumj".
[Explosive](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0569) has a function to write itself to Registry values.
[REvil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0496) can modify the Registry to save encryption parameters and system information.
[Remcos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0332) has full control of the Registry, including the ability to modify it.
[Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) modifies the Registry to store an encoded configuration file in "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\WMI\Security".
[EVILNUM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0568) can make modifications to the Regsitry for persistence.
[Netwalker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0457) can add the following registry entry: "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\{8 random characters}".
[CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) may modify Registry keys to store RC4 encrypted configuration information.
[MegaCortex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0576) has added entries to the Registry for ransom contact information.
[zwShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0350) can modify the Registry.
[SLOTHFULMEDIA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0533) can add, modify, and/or delete registry keys.

During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), the threat actors enabled Wdigest by changing the "HKLM\SYSTEM\\ControlSet001\\Control\\SecurityProviders\\WDigest" registry value from 0 (disabled) to 1 (enabled).
A [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) tool has created new Registry keys under "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Classes\" and "HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\services".

[Black Basta](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1070) can modify the Registry to enable itself to run in safe mode and to modify the icons and file extensions for encrypted files.

[Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330)
modifies several Registry keys under "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Internet Explorer\ PhishingFilter\" to disable phishing filters.

[Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) sets "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\WindowsNT\CurrentVersion\Windows\Load" to point to its executable.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has modified Registry settings for default file associations to enable all macros and for persistence.

[ThreatNeedle](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0665) can modify the Registry to save its configuration data as the following RC4-encrypted Registry key: "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\GameCon".
[Pandora](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0664)
can write an encrypted token to the Registry to enable processing of remote commands.
[Gorgon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0078) malware can deactivate security mechanisms in Microsoft Office by editing several keys and values under "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Office\".
[Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) can create registry keys to load driver files.
[StreamEx](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0142) has the ability to modify the Registry.
[NETWIRE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0198) can modify the Registry to store its configuration information.
[HermeticWiper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0697)
has the ability to modify Registry keys to disable crash dumps, colors for compressed files, and pop-up information about folders and desktop items.
[SysUpdate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0663) can write its configuration file to "Software\Classes\scConfig" in either "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE" or "HKEY_CURRENT_USER".
[HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has modified Managed Object Format (MOF) files within the Registry to run specific commands and create persistence on the system.
[BACKSPACE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0031) is capable of deleting Registry keys, sub-keys, and values on a victim system.
[DarkTortilla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1066)
has modified registry keys for persistence.
[AADInternals](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0677)
can modify registry keys as part of setting a new pass-through authentication agent.
[ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) can create Registry entries to enable services to run.
[SOUNDBITE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0157) is capable of modifying the Registry.

[Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) has modified the Registry key "HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurityProviders\WDigest" by setting the "UseLogonCredential" registry value to "1" in order to force credentials to be stored in clear text in memory.
[Ember Bear](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1003) has used an open source batch script to modify Windows Defender registry keys.
[Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438)'s dispatcher can modify the Run registry key.
[KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) has modified registry keys of ComSysApp, Svchost, and xmlProv on the machine to gain persistence.
[PipeMon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0501) has modified the Registry to store its encrypted payload.
[Sibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0589) has modified the Registry to install a second-stage script in the "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\sibot".
[DCSrv](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1033) has created Registry keys for persistence.
[Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) creates a Registry subkey to register its created service, and can also uninstall itself later by deleting this value.
[Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203)'s backdoor also enables remote attackers to modify and delete subkeys.
[Ferocious](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0679) has the ability to add a Class ID in the current user Registry hive to enable persistence mechanisms.
[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) has a command to create, set, copy, or delete a specified Registry key or value.
[PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has made registry modifications to alter its behavior upon execution.
[Bisonal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0268) has deleted Registry keys to clean up its prior activity.
[Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) appears to have functionality to modify remote Registry information.
[Nerex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0210) creates a Registry subkey that registers a new service.
[SMOKEDHAM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0649) has modified registry keys for persistence, to enable credential caching for credential access, and to facilitate lateral movement via RDP.
[CrackMapExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0488)
can create a registry key using wdigest.
[Reg](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0075) may be used to interact with and modify the Windows Registry of a local or remote system at the command-line interface.
[Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115) can set a Registry key to determine how long it has been installed and possibly to indicate the version number.
[Tarrask](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1011) is able to delete the Security Descriptor ("SD") registry subkey in order to “hide” scheduled tasks.

[Earth Lusca](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1006) modified the registry using the command "reg add “HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Environment” /v UserInitMprLogonScript /t REG_SZ /d “[file path]”" for persistence.
[PolyglotDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0518) can write encrypted JSON configuration files to the Registry.
[Naid](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0205)
creates Registry entries that store information about a created service and point to a malicious DLL dropped to disk.

[QUADAGENT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0269) modifies an HKCU Registry key to store a session identifier unique to the compromised system as well as a pre-shared key used for encrypting and decrypting C2 communications.
[ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) can modify the "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Office\" registry key so it can bypass the VB object model (VBOM) on a compromised host.
[Taidoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0011) has the ability to modify the Registry on compromised hosts using "RegDeleteValueA" and "RegCreateKeyExA".
[PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013)
has a module to create, delete, or modify Registry keys.
[Catchamas](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0261) creates three Registry keys to establish persistence by adding a [Windows Service](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1543/003).
[Caterpillar WebShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0572) has a command to modify a Registry key.
[APT19](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0073) uses a Port 22 malware variant to modify several Registry keys.
[Metamorfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0455) has written process names to the Registry, disabled IE browser features, deleted Registry keys, and changed the ExtendedUIHoverTime key.
[TA505](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092) has used malware to disable Windows Defender through modification of the Registry.

[TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) can install encrypted configuration data under the Registry key "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\ShellCompatibility\Applications\laxhost.dll" and "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\PrintConfigs".
If running with "root" permissions, [OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0352) can create a persistence file in the folder "/Library/LaunchDaemons".
[Green Lambert](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0690) can add a plist file in the "Library/LaunchDaemons" to establish persistence.
[Dacls](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0497) can establish persistence via a Launch Daemon.
[Bundlore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0482)
can persist via a LaunchDaemon.
[XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) uses the ssh launchdaemon to elevate privileges, bypass system controls, and enable remote access to the victim.

When running with root privileges after a [Launch Agent](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1543/001) is installed, [ThiefQuest](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0595) installs a plist file to the "/Library/LaunchDaemons/" folder with the "RunAtLoad" key set to "true" establishing persistence as a Launch Daemon.

[LoudMiner](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0451) adds plist files with the naming format "com.[random_name].plist" in the "/Library/LaunchDaemons" folder with the RunAtLoad and KeepAlive keys set to "true".
[AppleJeus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0584) has placed a plist file within the "LaunchDaemons" folder and launched it manually.
[QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) has collected usernames and passwords from Firefox and Chrome.
[Molerats](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0021) used the public tool BrowserPasswordDump10 to dump passwords saved in browsers on victims.
[Unknown Logger](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0130) is capable of stealing usernames and passwords from browsers on the victim machine.
[ZIRCONIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0128) has used a tool to steal credentials from installed web browsers including Microsoft Internet Explorer and Google Chrome.
[jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) can capture passwords from common web browsers such as Internet Explorer, Google Chrome, and Firefox.
[BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089)
has used a plug-in to gather credentials from web browsers including FireFox, Google Chrome, and Internet Explorer.
[RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) can gather browser usernames and passwords.
[RainyDay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0629) can use tools to collect credentials from web browsers.
[CookieMiner](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0492)
can steal saved usernames and passwords in Chrome as well as credit card credentials.
[Lizar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0681) has a module to collect usernames and passwords stored in browsers.
[Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115) contains a module to steal credentials from Web browsers on the victim machine.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has used browser extensions including Google Chrome to steal passwords and cookies from browsers.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has also used Nirsoft's WebBrowserPassView tool to dump the passwords obtained from victims.
[PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has used a Python tool named Browdec.exe to steal browser credentials.
[Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) contains a module that tries to obtain stored credentials from web browsers.
[Imminent Monitor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0434) has a PasswordRecoveryPacket module for recovering browser passwords.
[NETWIRE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0198)
has the ability to steal credentials from web browsers including Internet Explorer, Opera, Yandex, and Chrome.
[KGH_SPY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0526)
has the ability to steal data from the Chrome, Edge, Firefox, Thunderbird, and Opera browsers.
[Chaes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0631) can steal login credentials and stored financial information from the browser.
[SUGARDUMP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1042) variants have harvested credentials from browsers such as Firefox, Chrome, Opera, and Edge.
[APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) has used a credential stealer known as ZUMKONG that can harvest usernames and passwords stored in browsers.

A module in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) gathers logins and passwords stored in applications on the victims, including Google Chrome, Mozilla Firefox, and several other browsers.
[Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) can use modules that extract passwords from common web browsers such as Firefox and Chrome.
[Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) collects stored credentials from several web browsers.
[OLDBAIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0138)
collects credentials from Internet Explorer, Mozilla Firefox, and Eudora.
[Stealth Falcon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0038) malware gathers passwords from multiple sources, including Internet Explorer, Firefox, and Chrome.
[APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has used a variety of publicly available tools like [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) to gather credentials.
[Grandoreiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0531) can steal cookie data and credentials from Google Chrome.
[H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) dumps usernames and passwords from Firefox, Internet Explorer, and Outlook.
During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) stole users' saved passwords from Chrome.
[PinchDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0048) steals credentials from compromised hosts.
[PinchDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0048)'s credential stealing functionality is believed to be based on the source code of the Pinch credential stealing malware (also known as LdPinch).

Credentials targeted by [PinchDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0048) include ones associated with many sources such as Netscape Navigator, Mozilla Firefox, Mozilla Thunderbird, and Internet Explorer.
[Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094)
can steal data and credentials from browsers.
[ChChes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0144)
steals credentials stored inside Internet Explorer.
[Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) can use Lazagne for harvesting credentials.
[LAPSUS$](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1004) has obtained passwords and session tokens with the use of the Redline password stealer.
[ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) can steal credentials stored in Web browsers by querying the sqlite database.

[Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) performs credential dumping to obtain account and password information useful in gaining access to additional systems and enterprise network resources.
It contains functionality to acquire information about credentials in many ways, including from DPAPI.
[CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050)
collects user credentials, including passwords, for various programs including Web browsers.
[SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) can collect clear text web credentials for Internet Explorer/Edge.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has used tools to dump passwords from browsers.
[KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) attempts to collect passwords from browsers.
[MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has run tools including Browser64 to steal passwords saved in victim web browsers.
[KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) can steal profiles (containing credential information) from Firefox, Chrome, and Opera.
[PLEAD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0435) can harvest saved credentials from browsers such as Google Chrome, Microsoft Internet Explorer, and Mozilla Firefox.
[Melcoz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0530) has the ability to steal credentials from web browsers.
[Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can gather credentials from a number of browsers.
[Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can steal credentials from the victim's browser.
[TA505](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092) has used malware to gather credentials from Internet Explorer.
[Javali](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0528) can capture login credentials from open browsers including Firefox, Chrome, Internet Explorer, and Edge.
[BLUELIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0657) can collect passwords stored in web browers, including Internet Explorer, Edge, Chrome, and Naver Whale.
[TSCookie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0436) has the ability to steal saved passwords from the Internet Explorer, Edge, Firefox, and Chrome browsers.
[Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034)'s CredRaptor tool can collect saved passwords from various internet browsers.
[Ajax Security Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0130) has used FireMalv custom-developed malware, which collected passwords from the Firefox browser storage.
[LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) can obtain credentials from web browsers such as Google Chrome, Internet Explorer, and Firefox.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used the Stealer One credential stealer to target web browsers.
[njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) has a module that steals passwords saved in victim web browsers.
[QuasarRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0262) can obtain passwords from common web browsers.
Some [Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) samples contain a publicly available Web browser password recovery tool.
[Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367)
has been observed dropping browser password grabber modules.

[OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used credential dumping tools such as [LaZagne](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0349) to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.
[OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has also used tool named PICKPOCKET to dump passwords from web browsers.
[WarzoneRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0670)
has the capability to grab passwords from numerous web browsers as well as from Outlook and Thunderbird email clients.
[Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) searches for credentials stored from web browsers.
[Carberp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0484)'s passw.plug plugin can gather passwords saved in Opera, Internet Explorer, Safari, Firefox, and Chrome.

[Lokibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0447) has demonstrated the ability to steal credentials from multiple applications and data sources including Safari and the Chromium and Mozilla Firefox-based web browsers.
[Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) has the capability to upload dumper tools that extract credentials from web browsers and store them in database files.
[HEXANE](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1001) has used a [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002)-based tool and a PowerShell script to steal passwords from Google Chrome.
[XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains the getFirefoxPassword function to attempt to locate Firefox passwords.

[TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) can obtain passwords stored in files from web browsers such as Chrome, Firefox, Internet Explorer, and Microsoft Edge, sometimes using [esentutl](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0404).
[Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) dumped the login data database from "\AppData\Local\Google\Chrome\User Data\Default\Login Data".
[Leafminer](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0077) used several tools for retrieving login and password information, including LaZagne.
[Proton](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0279) gathers credentials for Google Chrome.
[Inception](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0100) used a browser plugin to steal passwords and sessions from Internet Explorer, Chrome, Opera, Firefox, Torch, and Yandex.
[Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363)
contains modules that can discover and exploit search order hijacking vulnerabilities.
[PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) contains a collection of Privesc-PowerUp modules that can discover and exploit search order hijacking vulnerabilities.
[FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) contains junk code in its functions in an effort to confuse disassembly programs.
[Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) can use junk code to hide functions and evade detection.
[Grandoreiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0531) has added BMP images to the resources section of its Portable Executable (PE) file increasing each binary to at least 300MB in size.
[Javali](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0528) can use large obfuscated libraries to hinder detection and analysis.

[Maze](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0449) has inserted large blocks of junk code, including some components to decrypt strings and other important information for later in the encryption process.
[QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) can use large file sizes to evade detection.
[yty](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0248) contains junk code in its binary, likely to confuse malware analysts.
[WastedLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0612) contains junk code to increase its entropy and hide the actual code.
[FatDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0512) has been packed with junk code and strings.
[Black Basta](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1070) had added data prior to the Portable Executable (PE) header to prevent automatic scanners from identifying the payload.
[SamSam](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0370) has used garbage code to pad some of its malware components.
[Goopy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0477) has had null characters padded in its malicious DLL payload.
Before writing to disk, [Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) inserts a randomly generated string into the middle of the decrypted payload in an attempt to evade hash-based detections.
[Comnie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0244) appends a total of 64MB of garbage data to a file to deter any security products in place that may be scanning files on disk.
[Ember Bear](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1003) has added extra spaces between JavaScript code characters to increase the overall file size.
[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used large size files to avoid detection by security solutions with hardcoded size limits.
[CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) contains unused machine instructions in a likely attempt to hinder analysis.
[Rifdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0433) has added four additional bytes of data upon launching, then saved the changed version as "C:\ProgramData\Initech\Initech.exe".
[Mustang Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0129) has used junk code within their DLL files to hinder analysis.
[GrimAgent](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0632) has the ability to add bytes to change the file hash.
[CostaBricks](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0614) has added the entire unobfuscated code of the legitimate open source application Blink to its code.
[Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) has obfuscated .NET executables by inserting junk code.
[ZeroT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0230)
has obfuscated DLLs and functions using dummy API calls inserted between real instructions.
[BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) downloader code has included "0" characters at the end of the file to inflate the file size in a likely attempt to evade anti-virus detection.
A version of [XTunnel](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0117) introduced in July 2015 inserted junk code into the binary in a likely attempt to obfuscate it and bypass security products.
[POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) has used useless code blocks to counter analysis.
[Moafee](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0002) has been known to employ binary padding.
[TAINTEDSCRIBE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0586) can execute "FileRecvWriteRand" to append random bytes to the end of a file received from C2.
[APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) includes garbage code to mislead anti-malware software and researchers.
[Bisonal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0268) has appended random binary data to the end of itself to generate a large binary.
[Higaisa](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0126) performed padding with null bytes before calculating its hash.

[Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) apparently altered [NDiskMonitor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0272) samples by adding four bytes of random letters in a likely attempt to change the file hashes.
[Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has inserted garbage characters into code, presumably to avoid anti-virus detection.

A variant of [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) appends junk data to the end of its DLL file to create a large file that may exceed the maximum size that anti-virus programs can scan.
[TEMP.Veles](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0088) has planted Web shells on Outlook Exchange servers.
[Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) has started a web service in the target host and wait for the adversary to connect, acting as a web shell.
[APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) has used web shells for persistence or to ensure redundant access.
[Volatile Cedar](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0123) can inject web shell code into a server.

[HAFNIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0125) has deployed multiple web shells on compromised servers including SIMPLESEESHARP, SPORTSBALL, [China Chopper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0020), and [ASPXSpy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0073).
[Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) has used multiple web shells to gain execution.
[Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has used a variety of Web shells.
[APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has used Web shells to maintain access to victim websites.
[Fox Kitten](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0117) has installed web shells on compromised hosts to maintain access.
[GALLIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used Web shells to persist in victim environments and assist in execution and exfiltration.
[BackdoorDiplomacy](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0135) has used web shells to establish an initial foothold and for lateral movement within a victim's system.
[Deep Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0009) uses Web shells on publicly accessible Web servers to access victim networks.
[ASPXSpy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0073) is a Web shell.
The ASPXTool version used by [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has been deployed to accessible servers running Internet Information Services (IIS).
[China Chopper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0020)'s server component is a Web Shell payload.
[SEASHARPEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0185) is a Web shell.
[P.A.S. Webshell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0598) can gain remote access and execution on target web servers.

[Dragonfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0035) has commonly created Web shells on victims' publicly accessible email and web servers, which they used to maintain access to a victim network and download additional malicious files.
During [C0017](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0017), [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) deployed JScript web shells through the creation of malicious ViewState objects.

During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), threat actors used their own web shells, as well as those previously placed on target systems by other threat actors, for reconnaissance and lateral movement.
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has used a modified and obfuscated version of the reGeorg web shell to maintain persistence on a target's Outlook Web Access (OWA) server.
[Moses Staff](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1009) has dropped a web shell onto a compromised system.
[APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has installed ANTAK and ASPXSPY web shells.
[OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used web shells, often to maintain access to a victim network.
[Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) relies on web shells for an initial foothold as well as persistence into the victim's systems.
