[Rover](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0090) automatically searches for files on local drives based on a predefined list of file extensions.

During [Operation Dream Job](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0022), [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) conducted word searches within documents on a compromised host in search of security and financial matters.
[OutSteel](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1017)
can search for specific file extensions, including zipped files.
[BlackCat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1068) can enumerate files for encryption.
[BackConfig](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0475) has the ability to identify folders and files related to previous infections.
[CharmPower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0674) can enumerate drives and list the contents of the C: drive on a victim's computer.
[Avaddon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0640) has searched for specific files prior to encryption.
[BACKSPACE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0031) allows adversaries to search for files.
During [C0015](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0015), the threat actors conducted a file listing discovery against multiple hosts to ensure locker encryption was successful.
[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can list information about files in a directory and recently opened or used documents.
[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can also search for specific files by supplied file mask.
[SoreFang](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0516) has the ability to list directories.
[OSX/Shlayer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0402) has used the command "appDir="$(dirname $(dirname "$currentDir"))"" and "$(dirname "$(pwd -P)")" to construct installation paths.
[APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050)'s backdoor possesses the capability to list files and directories on a machine.
[Fysbis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0410) has the ability to search for files.

[Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) surveys a system upon check-in to discover files in specific locations on the hard disk %TEMP% directory, the current user's desktop, the Program Files directory, and Recent.
[Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) RPC backdoors have also searched for files matching the "lPH*.dll" pattern.
[Cryptoistic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0498) can scan a directory to identify files for deletion.
The [IceApple](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1022) Directory Lister module can list information about files and directories including creation time, last write time, name, and size.
[Metamorfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0455)
has searched the Program Files directories for specific folders and has searched for strings related to its mutexes.
[BLACKCOFFEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0069)
has the capability to enumerate files.
[P.A.S. Webshell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0598) has the ability to list files and file characteristics including extension, size, ownership, and permissions.
[Doki](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0600) has resolved the path of a process PID to use as a script argument.
[NETWIRE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0198) has the ability to search for files on the compromised host.
A [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) payload has searched all fixed drives on the victim for files matching a specified list of extensions.
[Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) malware can list a victim's logical drives and the type, as well the total/free space of the fixed devices.
Other malware can list a directory's contents.
[Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) can enumerate files and directories on a compromised host.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has a tool that looks for files and directories on the local file system.
[ccf32](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1043) can parse collected files to identify specific file extensions.
[PinchDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0048) searches for files created within a certain timeframe and whose file extension matches a predefined list.
[HTTPBrowser](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0070) is capable of listing files, folders, and drives on a victim.
[BoomBox](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0635) can search for specific files and directories on a machine.
[QuietSieve](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0686) can search files on the target host by extension, including doc, docx, xls, rtf, odt, txt, jpg, pdf, rar, zip, and 7z.
[DropBook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0547) can collect the names of all files and folders in the Program Files directories.
[Kasidet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0088) has the ability to search for a given filename on a victim.
[NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) allows adversaries to enumerate and modify the infected host's file system.
It supports searching for directories, creating directories, listing directory contents, reading and writing to files, retrieving file attributes, and retrieving volume information.
[REvil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0496) has the ability to identify specific files and directories that are not to be encrypted.
[ShimRat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0444) can list directories.
[Taidoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0011) can search for specific files.
[Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) has monitored files' modified time.

[SUGARDUMP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1042) can search for and collect data from specific Chrome, Opera, Microsoft Edge, and Firefox files, including any folders that have the string "Profile" in its name.
[Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) can obtain a list of directories.
[HermeticWiper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0697) can enumerate common folders such as My Documents, Desktop, and AppData.
[InnaputRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0259) enumerates directories and obtains file attributes on a system.
[Leafminer](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0077) used a tool called MailSniper to search for files on the desktop and another utility called Sobolsoft to extract attachments from EML files.
[Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) macros can scan for Microsoft Word and Excel files to inject with additional malicious macros.
[Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047)
has also used its backdoors to automatically list interesting files (such as Office documents) found on a system.
[FALLCHILL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0181) can search files on a victim.
[down_new](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0472) has the ability to list the directories on a compromised host.
[NDiskMonitor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0272) can obtain a list of all files and directories as well as logical drives.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has the ability to enumerate all files and directories on an infected system.
[Imminent Monitor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0434) has a dynamic debugging feature to check whether it is located in the %TEMP% directory, otherwise it copies itself there.
[SideTwist](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0610) has the ability to search for specific files.
[Aoqin Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1007) has run scripts to identify file formats including Microsoft Word.
[Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects a list of files and directories in C:\ with the command "dir /s /a c:\ >> "C:\windows\TEMP\[RANDOM].tmp"".
[Dtrack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0567) can list files on available disk volumes.
[RainyDay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0629) can use a file exfiltration tool to collect recently changed files with specific extensions.
[Industroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0604)’s data wiper component enumerates specific files on all the Windows drives.
[DarkWatchman](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0673) has the ability to enumerate file and folder names.
[POORAIM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0216) can conduct file browsing.
[WINERACK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0219) can enumerate files and directories.
[XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains the readFiles function to return a detailed listing (sometimes recursive) of a specified directory.
[XAgentOSX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0161) contains the showBackupIosFolder function to check for IOS device backups by running "ls -la ~/Library/Application\ Support/MobileSync/Backup/".
[Mafalda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1060) can search for files and directories.
[SUNBURST](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0559) had commands to enumerate files and directories.
[Psylo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0078) has commands to enumerate all storage devices and to find all files that start with a particular string.
[Dacls](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0497) can scan directories on a compromised host.
[SynAck](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0242) checks its directory location in an attempt to avoid launching in a sandbox.
[KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) has a command to launch a file browser or explorer on the system.
[Winnti for Windows](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0141) can check for the presence of specific files prior to moving to the next phase of execution.
[HAFNIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0125) has searched file contents on a compromised host.
[PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139)
has commands to get the current directory name as well as the size of a file.
It also has commands to obtain information about logical drives, drive type, and free space.
[UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275)
has the capability to gather the victim's current directory.
[APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) have enumerated files and directories, or searched in specific locations within a compromised host.
[KGH_SPY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0526) can enumerate files and directories on a compromised host.
[Rising Sun](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0448)
can enumerate information about files from the infected system, including file size, attributes, creation time, last access time, and write time.
[Rising Sun](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0448)
can enumerate the compilation timestamp of Windows executable files.
[USBferry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0452) can detect the victim's file or folder list.
[WarzoneRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0670)
can enumerate directories on a compromise host.
[Diavol](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0659) has a command to traverse the files and directories in a given path.

A module in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) collects information about the paths, size, and creation time of files with specific file extensions, but not the actual content of the file.
[XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) has used "mdfind" to enumerate a list of apps known to grant screen sharing permissions.
[PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) has a module to enumerate drives and find files recursively.
[Forfiles](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0193) can be used to locate certain types of files/directories in a system.(ex: locate all files with a specific extension, name, and/or age)
[OwaAuth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0072)
has a command to list its directory and logical drives.
[SombRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0615) can execute "enum" to enumerate files in storage on a compromised system.
[CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) searches attached and mounted drives for file extensions and keywords that match a predefined list.
[Saint Bot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1018) can search a compromised host for specific files.
[Chimera](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0114) has utilized multiple commands to identify data of interest in file and directory listings.
[FatDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0512)
can enumerate directories on target machines.
[TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) can search directories for files on the victim’s machine.
[Prestige](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1058) can traverse the file system to discover files to encrypt by identifying specific extensions defined in a hardcoded list.
[ELMER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0064) is capable of performing directory listings.
[POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may enumerate user directories on a victim.
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has used [Forfiles](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0193) to locate PDF, Excel, and Word documents during collection.
The group also searched a compromised DCCC computer for specific terms.
[BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089)
gathers a list of installed apps from the uninstall program Registry.
It also gathers registered mail, browser, and instant messaging clients from the Registry.
[BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089)
has searched for given file types.
[BLINDINGCAN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0520) can search, read, write, move, and execute files.
[Bisonal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0268)
can retrieve a file listing from the system.
[MegaCortex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0576)
can parse the available drives and directories to determine which files to encrypt.
A variant of [Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081) executes "dir C:\progra~1" when initially run.
[Turian](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0647) can search for specific files and list directories.
[MobileOrder](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0079)
has a command to upload to its C2 server information about files on the victim mobile device, including SD card size, installed app list, SMS content, contacts, and calling history.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) has executed "file /bin/pwd" on exploited victims, perhaps to return architecture related information.
[Fox Kitten](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0117) has used WizTree to obtain network files and directory listings.
[Confucius](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0142) has used a file stealer that checks the Document, Downloads, Desktop, and Picture folders for documents and images with specific extensions.
[Rclone](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1040) can list files and directories with the "ls", "lsd", and "lsl" commands.
[LookBack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0582)
can retrieve file listings from the victim machine.
[MiniDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0051) can enumerate local drives.
[MoonWind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0149)
has a command to return a directory listing for a specified directory.
[PLEAD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0435) has the ability to list drives and files on the compromised host.
[TINYTYPHON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0131) searches through the drive containing the OS, then all drive letters C through to Z, for documents matching certain extensions.
[Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) searches for files that are 60mb and less and contain the following extensions: .doc, .docx, .xls, .xlsx, .ppt, .pptx, .exe, .zip, and .rar.
[Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) also runs the "echo %APPDATA%" command to list the contents of the directory.
[Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) can obtain the current execution path as well as perform drive enumeration.
During [Operation CuckooBees](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0012), the threat actors used "dir c:\\" to search for files.
[Brave Prince](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0252) gathers file and directory information from the victim’s machine.

[TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) searches the system for all of the following file extensions: .avi, .mov, .mkv, .mpeg, .mpeg4, .mp4, .mp3, .wav, .ogg, .jpeg, .jpg, .png, .bmp, .gif, .tiff, .ico, .xlsx, and .zip.
It can also obtain browsing history, cookies, and plug-in information.
[StrifeWater](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1034) can enumerate files on a compromised host.
[BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128)
identifies files with certain extensions from USB devices, then copies them to a predefined directory.

[DustySky](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0062) scans the victim for files that contain certain keywords and document types including PDF, DOC, DOCX, XLS, and XLSX, from a list that is obtained from the C2 as a text file.
It can also identify logical drives for the infected machine.
[StrongPity](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0491) can parse the hard drive on a compromised host to identify specific file extensions.
[CrossRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0235)
can list all files on a system.
[Inception](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0100) used a file listing plugin to collect information about file and directories both on local and remote drives.
[BoxCaon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0651) has searched for files on the system, such as documents located in the desktop folder.
[ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) has the ability to gather a list of files and directories on the infected system.

[Woody RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1065) can list all files and their associated attributes, including filename, type, owner, creation time, last access time, last write time, size, and permissions.
[Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) finds a specified directory, lists the files and metadata about those files.
[Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) can walk through directories and recursively search for strings in files.
[Conti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0575) can discover files on a local system.
[Remcos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0332) can search for files on the infected machine.
[Octopus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0340)
can collect information on the Windows directory and searches for compressed RAR files on the host.
[yty](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0248) gathers information on victim’s drives and has a plugin for document listing.

[GeminiDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0049) collects information from the victim, including installed drivers, programs previously executed by users, programs and services configured to automatically run at startup, files and folders present in any user's home folder, files and folders present in any user's My Documents, programs installed to the Program Files folder, and recently accessed files, folders, and programs.
[3PARA RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0066) has a command to retrieve metadata for files on disk as well as a command to list the current working directory.
[Cuba](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0625) can enumerate files by using a variety of functions.
[Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) produces file listings in order to search for files to be exfiltrated.
[Denis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0354) has several commands to search directories for files.
[Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) is capable of running commands to obtain a list of files and directories, as well as enumerating logical drives.
[Nebulae](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0630) can list files and directories on a compromised host.

[MarkiRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0652) can look for files carrying specific extensions such as: .rtf, .doc, .docx, .xls, .xlsx, .ppt, .pptx, .pps, .ppsx, .txt, .gpg, .pkr, .kdbx, .key, and .jpb.
[Dark Caracal](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0070) collected file listings of all default Windows directories.
[AppleSeed](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0622) has the ability to search for .txt, .ppt, .hwp, .pdf, and .doc files in specified directories.
[metaMain](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1059) can recursively enumerate files in an operator-provided directory.
[FYAnti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0628) can search the "C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\" directory for files of a specified size.
[KEYMARBLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0271) has a command to search for files on the victim’s machine.

[GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) collects the volumes mapped on the system, and also steals files with the following extensions: .docx, .doc, .pptx, .ppt, .xlsx, .xls, .rtf, and .pdf.
[CORALDECK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0212) searches for specified files.
[CookieMiner](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0492) has looked for files in the user's home directory with "wallet" in their name using "find".
[FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) enumerates directories and scans for certain files.
[Avenger](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0473) has the ability to browse files in directories such as Program Files and the Desktop.

[RARSTONE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0055) obtains installer properties from Uninstall Registry Key entries to obtain information about installed applications and how to uninstall certain applications.
[Sliver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0633) can enumerate files on a target system.
[Peppy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0643) can identify specific files for exfiltration.
[Gold Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0249) lists the directories for Desktop, program files, and the user’s recently accessed files.
[Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) can collect directory and file lists.
[WinMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0059) sets a WH_CBT Windows hook to search for and capture files on the victim.
[Seasalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0345) has the capability to identify the drive type on a victim.
[AuditCred](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0347) can search through folders and files on the system.
[SysUpdate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0663) can search files on a compromised host.
[Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) has used malware that searched for files with specific patterns.
[FruitFly](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0277) looks for specific files and file types.
During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), threat actors gathered a recursive directory listing to find files and directories of interest.
[FLASHFLOOD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0036)
searches for interesting files (either a default or customized set of file extensions) on the local system and removable media.
[Winnti Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0044) has used a program named ff.exe to search for specific documents on compromised hosts.
[TAINTEDSCRIBE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0586) can use "DirectoryList" to enumerate files in a specified directory.
[Pasam](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0208) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve lists of files.
[Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344)
can recursively search for files in folders and collects files from the desktop with certain extensions.
An older version of [CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) has a module that monitors all mounted volumes for files with the extensions .doc, .docx, .pgp, .gpg, .m2f, or .m2o.
[ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) can list files and directories.
[KillDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0607) has used the "FindNextFile" command as part of its file deletion process.
[Action RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1028) has the ability to collect drive and file information on an infected machine.

During [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0002), threat actors used [zwShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0350) to establish full remote control of the connected machine and browse the victim file system.
[HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) has the ability to retrieve a list of files in a given directory as well as drives and drive types.
During [Operation Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0006), the threat actors used a malicious DLL to search for files with specific keywords.
[Ixeshe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0015) can list file and directory information.

[GoldenSpy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0493) has included a program "ExeProtector", which monitors for the existence of [GoldenSpy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0493) on the infected system and redownloads if necessary.
[jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) can browse file systems.
[WindTail](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0466) has the ability to enumerate the users home directory and the path to its own application bundle.
[Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) searches for files on the victim's machine.
[Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) can list directories on a victim.
[PingPull](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1031)
can enumerate storage volumes and folder contents of a compromised host.
[Babuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0638) has the ability to enumerate files on a targeted system.
[NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) searches for files ending with dozens of different file extensions prior to encryption.
[cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106) can be used to find files and directories with native functionality such as "dir" commands.
[Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) includes various modules for finding files of interest on hosts and network shares.
[Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) recursively searches for all .doc files on the system and collects a directory listing of the Desktop, %TEMP%, and %WINDOWS%\Temp directories.
[LuminousMoth](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1014) has used malware that scans for files in the Documents, Desktop, and Download folders and in other drives.
[menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has searched compromised systems for folders of interest including those related to HR, audit and expense, and meeting memos.
[QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) can identify whether it has been run previously on a host by checking for a specified folder.
[Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) can list directory entries.

[Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) can retrieve data from specific Windows directories, as well as open random files as part of [Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1497).
[Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) is capable of listing contents of folders on the victim.
[Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) also searches for custom network encryption software on victims.
[Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203)
creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can check for the existence of files, including its own components, as well as retrieve a list of logical drives.
[MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used malware that checked if the ProgramData folder had folders or files with the keywords "Kasper," "Panda," or "ESET."
[Aria-body](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0456) has the ability to gather metadata from a file and to search for file and directory names.
[PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has the ability to list files upon receiving the "ls" command from C2.
[Lokibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0447) can search for specific files on an infected host.
[ObliqueRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0644) has the ability to recursively enumerate files on an infected endpoint.
[Caterpillar WebShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0572) can search for files in directories.
[FunnyDream](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1044) can identify files with .doc, .docx, .ppt, .pptx, .xls, .xlsx, and .pdf extensions and specific timestamps for collection.
[FIVEHANDS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0618)
has the ability to enumerate files on a compromised host in order to encrypt files with specific extensions.
[RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) can check for specific files and directories associated with virtualization and malware analysis.
[SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) has several modules, such as "ls.py", "pwd.py", and "recentFiles.py", to enumerate directories and files.
[Skidmap](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0468) has checked for the existence of specific files including "/usr/sbin/setenforce" and " /etc/selinux/config".
It also has the ability to monitor the cryptocurrency miner file and process.

[AutoIt backdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0129) is capable of identifying documents on the victim with the following extensions: .doc; .pdf, .csv, .ppt, .docx, .pst, .xls, .xlsx, .pptx, and .jpeg.

A version of [KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) searches for filenames created with a previous version of the malware, suggesting different versions targeted the same victims and the versions may work together.
[zwShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0350) can browse the file system.
[Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) uses a driver to scan for specific filesystem driver objects.
[4H RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0065) has the capability to obtain file and directory listings.
[Kinsing](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0599) has used the find command to search for specific files.
[BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has collected a list of files from the victim and uploaded it to its C2 server, and then created a new list of specific files to steal.

During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) obtained information about the configured Exchange virtual directory using "Get-WebServicesVirtualDirectory".
[USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) searches victim drives for files matching certain extensions (“.skr”,“.pkr” or “.key”) or names.
[Royal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1073)
can identify specific files and directories to exclude from the encryption process.
[MESSAGETAP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0443) checks for the existence of two configuration files (keyword_parm.txt and parm.txt) and attempts to read the files every 30 seconds.
[Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) searches for specific directories on the victim’s machine.
[Linfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0211) creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can list contents of drives and search for files.
[SHOTPUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0063) has a command to obtain a directory listing.
[Dragonfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0035) has used a batch script to gather folder and file names from victim hosts.
[Clop](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0611) has searched folders and subfolders for files to encrypt.
[Pteranodon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0147) identifies files matching certain file extension and copies them to subdirectories it created.
[Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351)
can obtain victim drive information as well as a list of folders in C:\Program Files.
[Cyclops Blink](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0687) can use the Linux API "statvfs" to enumerate the current working directory.
[APT18](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0026) can list files information for specific directories.
[TSCookie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0436) has the ability to discover drive information on the infected host.
[OceanSalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0346)
can extract drive information from the endpoint and search files on the system.
[Kivars](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0437) has the ability to list drives on the infected host.
[Pisloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0124) has commands to list drives on the victim machine and to list file information for a given directory.
[ThreatNeedle](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0665) can obtain file and directory information.
[Bandook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0234) has a command to list files on a system.
[Siloscape](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0623) searches for the Kubernetes config file and other related files using a regular expression.
[Sowbug](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0054) identified and extracted all Word documents on a server by using a command containing * .doc and *.docx.
The actors also searched for documents based on a specific date range and attempted to identify all installed software on a victim.
[Heyoka Backdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1027) has the ability to search the compromised host for files.
[GrimAgent](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0632) has the ability to enumerate files and directories on a compromised host.
[Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) uses command-line interaction to search files and directories.
[WhisperGate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0689)
can locate files based on hardcoded file extensions.
[BBSRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0127) can list file and directory information.
[SDBbot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0461) has the ability to get directory listings or drive information on a compromised host.

[WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) searches for variety of user files by file extension before encrypting them using RSA and AES, including Office, PDF, image, audio, video, source code, archive/compression format, and key and certificate files.
[SUNSPOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0562) enumerated the Orion software Visual Studio solution directory path.
[CaddyWiper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0693) can enumerate all files and directories on a compromised host.
[ZLib](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0086) has the ability to enumerate files and drives.

[Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) can perform a recursive directory listing for all volume drives available on the victim's machine and can also fetch specific files by their paths.
[Penquin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0587) can use the command code "do_vslist" to send file names, size, and status to C2.
[njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) can browse file systems using a file manager module.
[CrackMapExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0488)
can discover specified filetypes and log files on a targeted system.
[Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115) contains commands to list files and directories, as well as search for files matching certain extensions from a defined list.
[Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) is capable of obtaining directory, file, and drive listings.
[TeamTNT](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0139) has used a script that checks "/proc/*/environ" for environment variables related to AWS.
[StreamEx](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0142) has the ability to enumerate drive types.
[TajMahal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0467) has the ability to index files from drives, user profiles, and removable drives.
[BADFLICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0642)
has searched for files on the infected host.
[Mustang Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0129) has searched the entire target system for DOC, DOCX, PPT, PPTX, XLS, XLSX, and PDF files.
[Clambling](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0660) can browse directories on a compromised host.
[APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has used tools with the ability to search for files on a compromised host.
[RemoteUtilities](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0592)
can enumerate files and directories on a target machine.
[Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) has a plugin that enumerates files with specific extensions on all hard disk drives and stores file information in encrypted log files.
[PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378)
can enumerate files on the local file system and includes a module for enumerating recently accessed files.
[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) can explore files on a compromised system.
[Zox](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0672) can enumerate files on a compromised host.
[Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) recursively searches through directories for files.

[Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) checks its current working directory upon execution and also contains watchdog functionality that ensures its executable is located in the correct path (else it will rewrite the payload).
[Ryuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0446) has enumerated files and folders on all mounted drives.

[Backdoor.Oldrea](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0093) collects information about available drives, default browser, desktop file list, My Documents, Internet history, program files, and root of available drives.
It also searches for ICS-related software files.
[BLUELIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0657) can enumerate files and collect associated metadata.
[DDKONG](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0255) lists files on the victim’s machine.
[SLOTHFULMEDIA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0533) can enumerate files and directories.
[BlackMould](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0564) has the ability to find files on the targeted system.
[Proxysvc](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0238) lists files in directories.
[Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) can enumerate the victim's desktop.
[Amadey](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1025)
has searched for folders associated with antivirus software.
[SPACESHIP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0035) identifies files and directories for collection by searching for specific file extensions or file modification time.
[SOUNDBITE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0157) is capable of enumerating and manipulating files and directories.
[Black Basta](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1070) can enumerate specific files for encryption.
[AvosLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1053) has searched for files and directories on a compromised network.
[Windigo](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0124) has used a script to check for the presence of files created by OpenSSH backdoors.
[Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) has enumerated files on a compromised host.
[WastedLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0612) can enumerate files and directories just prior to encryption.

[admin@338](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0018) actors used the following commands after exploiting a machine with [LOWBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0042) malware to obtain information about files and directories: "dir c:\ >> %temp%\download" "dir "c:\Documents and Settings" >> %temp%\download" "dir "c:\Program Files\" >> %temp%\download" "dir d:\ >> %temp%\download"
[CreepyDrive](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1023) can specify the local file path to upload files from.
[BadPatch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0337)
searches for files with specific file extensions.
[Orz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0229) can gather victim drive information.
[MacMa](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1016)
can search for a specific file on the compromised computer and can enumerate files in Desktop, Downloads, and Documents folders.
[Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) searches for files on the system.
[ChChes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0144) collects the victim's %TEMP% directory path and version of Internet Explorer.
[ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412)
has a command to open a file manager and explorer on the system.

[Tomiris](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0671) has connected to a signalization server that provides a URL and port, and then [Tomiris](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0671) sends a GET request to that URL to establish C2.
[Maze](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0449)
has forged POST strings with a random choice from a list of possibilities including "forum", "php", "view", etc. while making connection with the C2, hindering detection efforts.
For [Operation Dust Storm](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0016), the threat actors used dynamic DNS domains from a variety of free providers, including No-IP, Oray, and 3322.
[SUNBURST](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0559) dynamically resolved C2 infrastructure for randomly-generated subdomains within a parent domain.
[Bisonal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0268)
has used a dynamic DNS service for C2.
[Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) can use dynamic DNS domain names in C2.
[BITTER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1002) has used DDNS for C2 communications.
[NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) can use HTTP to download resources that contain an IP address and port number pair to connect to for C2.

During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used dynamic DNS resolution to construct and resolve to randomly-generated subdomains for C2.

[RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) has resolved [Pony](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0453) C2 server IP addresses by either converting Bitcoin blockchain transaction data to specific octets, or accessing IP addresses directly within the Namecoin blockchain.
For [Operation Spalax](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0005), the threat actors used dynamic DNS services, including Duck DNS and DNS Exit, as part of their C2 infrastructure.
[Transparent Tribe](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0134) has used dynamic DNS services to set up C2.
During [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0002), threat actors used dynamic DNS services for C2.
[Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) has incorporated dynamic DNS domains in its infrastructure.
To establish persistence, [Truvasys](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0178) adds a Registry Run key with a value "TaskMgr" in an attempt to masquerade as the legitimate Windows Task Manager.

[Seasalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0345) has masqueraded as a service called "SaSaut" with a display name of "System Authorization Service" in an apparent attempt to masquerade as a legitimate service.

[SysUpdate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0663) has named their unit configuration file similarly to other unit files residing in the same directory, "/usr/lib/systemd/system/", to appear benign.
[GoldMax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0588)
has impersonated systems management software to avoid detection.
[Fox Kitten](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0117) has named the task for a reverse proxy lpupdate to appear legitimate.
[Egregor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0554) has masqueraded the svchost.exe process to exfiltrate data.
[Catchamas](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0261) adds a new service named NetAdapter in an apparent attempt to masquerade as a legitimate service.
[APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050)
has used hidden or non-printing characters to help masquerade service names, such as appending a Unicode no-break space character to a legitimate service name.
[APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has also impersonated the legitimate Flash installer file name "install_flashplayer.exe".
[Fysbis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0410) has masqueraded as the rsyncd and dbus-inotifier services.

[Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) can establish persistence by adding a new service NtmsSvc with the display name Removable Storage to masquerade as a legitimate Removable Storage Manager.
[Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102
has used scheduled tasks to install [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266), using task names to appear legitimate such as WinDotNet, GoogleTask, or Sysnetsf.
It has also used common document file names for other malware binaries.
[Green Lambert](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0690) has created a new executable named "Software Update Check" to appear legitimate.
[RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148)
has named the scheduled task it creates "Windows Update".
[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) has attempted to disguise itself by registering under a seemingly legitimate service name.

During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) named tasks "\Microsoft\Windows\SoftwareProtectionPlatform\EventCacheManager" in order to appear legitimate.
[ZIRCONIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0128) has created a run key named "Dropbox Update Setup" to mask a persistence mechanism for a malicious binary.
[BackdoorDiplomacy](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0135) has disguised their backdoor droppers with naming conventions designed to blend into normal operations.
In one instance, [menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) added [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) as a service with a display name of "Corel Writing Tools Utility."
[ShimRat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0444) can impersonate Windows services and antivirus products to avoid detection on compromised systems.
[OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0352) has disguised its app bundle by adding special characters to the filename and using the icon for legitimate Word documents.
[TinyTurla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0668) has mimicked an existing Windows service by being installed as "Windows Time Service".
[IronNetInjector](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0581) has been disguised as a legitimate service using the name PythonUpdateSrvc.
[Nebulae](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0630) has created a service named "Windows Update Agent1" to appear legitimate.
[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) has used a scheduled task named "SRCheck" to mask the execution of a malicious .dll.

[Maze](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0449) operators have created scheduled tasks masquerading as "Windows Update Security", "Windows Update Security Patches", and "Google Chrome Security Update" designed to launch the ransomware.
[ZxxZ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1013) has been disguised as a Windows security update service.
[Black Basta](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1070) has established persistence by creating a new service named "FAX" after deleting the legitimate service by the same name.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has renamed the "psexec" service name to "mstdc" to masquerade as a legitimate Windows service.
[StrongPity](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0491) has named services to appear legitimate.

[DEADEYE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1052) has used "schtasks /change" to modify scheduled tasks including "\Microsoft\Windows\PLA\Server Manager Performance Monitor", "\Microsoft\Windows\Ras\ManagerMobility, \Microsoft\Windows\WDI\SrvSetupResults", and "\Microsoft\Windows\WDI\USOShared".
[RainyDay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0629) has named services and scheduled tasks to appear benign including "ChromeCheck" and "googleupdate."
[Meteor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0688) has been disguised as the Windows Power Efficiency Diagnostics report tool.
[Heyoka Backdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1027) has been named "srvdll.dll" to appear as a legitimate service.
[KillDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0607) registers as a service under the Plug-And-Play Support name.
[Tarrask](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1011)
creates a scheduled task called “WinUpdate” to re-establish any dropped C2 connections.
[FunnyDream](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1044) has used a service named "WSearch" for execution.
[SVCReady](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1064) has named a task "RecoveryExTask" as part of its persistence activity.
[Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) has named a malicious script CacheTask.bat to mimic a legitimate task.
[Hildegard](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0601) has disguised itself as a known Linux process.
During [C0017](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0017), [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used "SCHTASKS /Change" to modify legitimate scheduled tasks to run malicious code.

[SUGARDUMP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1042)'s scheduled task has been named "MicrosoftInternetExplorerCrashRepoeterTaskMachineUA" or "MicrosoftEdgeCrashRepoeterTaskMachineUA", depending on the Windows OS version.
During [Frankenstein](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0001), the threat actors named a malicious scheduled task "WinUpdate" for persistence.
[APT-C-36](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0099) has disguised its scheduled tasks as those used by Google.
[PingPull](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1031)
can mimic the names and descriptions of legitimate services such as "iphlpsvc", "IP Helper", and "Onedrive" to evade detection.
[FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) has created a scheduled task named “AdobeFlashSync” to establish persistence.
[RDAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0495) has used Windows Video Service as a name for malicious services.

Some [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) variants add new services with display names generated by a list of hard-coded strings such as Application, Background, Security, and Windows, presumably as a way to masquerade as a legitimate service.
[build_downer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0471) has added itself to the Registry Run key as "NVIDIA" to appear legitimate.

[Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) establishes persistence by adding a new service with the display name "WMI Performance Adapter Extension" in an attempt to masquerade as a legitimate WMI service.
[Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0008) has copied legitimate service names to use for malicious services.
[Higaisa](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0126) named a shellcode loader binary "svchast.exe" to spoof the legitimate "svchost.exe".
[DCSrv](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1033) has masqueraded its service as a legitimate svchost.exe process.
[ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) has used a task name associated with Windows SQM Consolidator.
[Nidiran](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0118) can create a new service named msamger (Microsoft Security Accounts Manager), which mimics the legitimate Microsoft database by the same name.
[Naikon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0019) renamed a malicious service "taskmgr" to appear to be a legitimate version of Task Manager.

The [Exaramel for Windows](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0343) dropper creates and starts a Windows service named wsmprovav with the description “Windows Check AV” in an apparent attempt to masquerade as a legitimate service.

[Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) creates a new service named “ntssrv” that attempts to appear legitimate; the service's display name is “Microsoft Network Realtime Inspection Service” and its description is “Helps guard against time change attempts targeting known and newly discovered vulnerabilities in network time protocols.”
Newer versions create the "MaintenaceSrv" service, which misspells the word "maintenance."
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has disguised services to appear as benign software or related to operating system functions.
[POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) has created a scheduled task named "MicrosoftEdge" to establish persistence.
[BITTER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1002) has disguised malware as a Windows Security update service.
[SLOTHFULMEDIA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0533) has named a service it establishes on victim machines as "TaskFrame" to hide its malicious purpose.
[KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) has pretended to be the xmlProv Network Provisioning service.
[Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438)'s dispatcher disguises itself as a legitimate task (i.e., the task name and description appear legitimate).
[Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) renamed task names to masquerade as legitimate Google Chrome, Java, Dropbox, Adobe Reader and Python tasks.
[Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) can create a task named to appear benign.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) has created services to appear as benign system tools.
[CSPY Downloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0527) has attempted to appear as a legitimate Windows service with a fake description claiming it is used to support packed applications.
[Crutch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0538) has established persistence with a scheduled task impersonating the Outlook item finder.
[InnaputRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0259) variants have attempted to appear legitimate by adding a new service named OfficeUpdateService.
[PROMETHIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0056) has named services to appear legitimate.

New services created by [RawPOS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0169) are made to appear like legitimate Windows services, with names such as "Windows Management Help Service", "Microsoft Support", and "Windows Advanced Task Manager".
[Turian](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0647) can disguise as a legitimate service to blend into normal operations.
[Bumblebee](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1039)
can use asynchronous procedure call (APC) injection to execute commands received from C2.
[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can inject its code into a trusted process via the APC queue.
[Pillowmint](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0517) has used the NtQueueApcThread syscall to inject code into svchost.exe.
[Carberp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0484) has queued an APC routine to explorer.exe by calling ZwQueueApcThread.
[Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) performs the injection by attaching its code into the APC queue using NtQueueApcThread API.

[TURNEDUP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0199) is capable of injecting code into the APC queue of a created [Rundll32](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1218/011) process as part of an "Early Bird injection."

[Saint Bot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1018) has written its payload into a newly-created "EhStorAuthn.exe" process using "ZwWriteVirtualMemory" and executed it using "NtQueueApcThread" and "ZwAlertResumeThread".
[IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483) has used "ZwQueueApcThread" to inject itself into remote processes.
[FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has injected malicious code into a new svchost.exe process.

[XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) uses the "plutil" command to modify the "LSUIElement", "DFBundleDisplayName", and "CFBundleIdentifier" keys in the "/Contents/Info.plist" file to change how [XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) is visible on the system.
[PUNCHBUGGY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0196)
can establish using a AppCertDLLs Registry key.
[Silent Librarian](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0122) has set up auto forwarding rules on compromised e-mail accounts.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has set auto-forward rules on victim's e-mail accounts.
[LAPSUS$](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1004) has set an Office 365 tenant level mail transport rule to send all mail in and out of the targeted organization to the newly created account.
[Shark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1019) has stored information in folders named "U1" and "U2" prior to exfiltration.
[Kevin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1020) can create directories to store logs and other collected data.

[Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) has collected and staged credentials and network enumeration information, using the networkdll and psfin [TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) modules.

[Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) can use "netstat" to enumerate network connections.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) has enumerated IP addresses of network resources and used the "netstat" command as part of network reconnaissance.

[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154)

[Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects a list of active and listening connections by using the command "netstat -nao" as well as a list of available network mappings with "net use".

[QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) can use "netstat" to enumerate current network connections.
[NETWIRE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0198)

) has gathered information about local network connections using [netstat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0104).

During [FunnyDream](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0007), the threat actors used [netstat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0104) to discover network connections on remote systems.

An [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) downloader first establishes a SOCKS5 connection to 192.157.198[.]103 using TCP port 1913; once the server response is verified, it then requests a connection to 192.184.60[.]229 on TCP port 81.

During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used a WMI event filter to invoke a command-line event consumer at system boot time to launch a backdoor with "rundll32.exe".
[Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used WMI event filters and consumers to establish persistence.
[FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has used WMI event subscriptions for persistence.
During [Operation Ghost](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0023), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used WMI event subscriptions to establish persistence for malware.
[Blue Mockingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0108) has used mofcomp.exe to establish WMI Event Subscription persistence mechanisms configured from a *.mof file.
[TrailBlazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0682) has the ability to use WMI for persistence.
[POSHSPY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0150) uses a WMI event subscription to establish persistence.
[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has used WMI event subscriptions for persistence.

[Mustang Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0129)'s custom ORat tool uses a WMI event consumer to maintain persistence.
[Metador](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1013) has established persistence through the use of a WMI event subscription combined with unusual living-off-the-land binaries such as "cdb.exe".
[RegDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0511) can persist using a WMI consumer that is launched every time a process named WINWORD.EXE is started.
[POWERTON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0371) can use WMI for persistence.

can create a WMI Event to execute a payload for persistence.

[SeaDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0053) uses an event filter in WMI code to execute a previously dropped executable shortly after system startup.
[PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) has the ability to persist on a system using WMI events.
[FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) used images embedded into document lures that only activate the payload when a user double clicks to avoid sandboxes.
[Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) has used malware that repeatedly checks the mouse cursor position to determine if a real user is on the system.

[Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) loader only executes the payload after the left mouse button has been pressed at least three times, in order to avoid being executed within virtualized or emulated environments.
[Spark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0543) has used a splash screen to check whether an user actively clicks on the screen before running malicious code.
[APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) compromised McAfee ePO to move laterally by distributing malware as a software deployment task.
During [C0018](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0018), the threat actors used PDQ Deploy to move [AvosLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1053) and tools across the network.
[Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) has used the commercially available tool RemoteExec for agentless remote code execution.
[Silence](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0091) has used RAdmin, a remote software tool used to remotely control workstations and ATMs.
[Threat Group-1314](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0028) actors used a victim's endpoint management platform, Altiris, for lateral movement.

It is believed that a patch management system for an anti-virus product commonly installed among targeted companies was used to distribute the [Wiper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0041) malware.

One variant of [BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089) locates existing driver services that have been disabled and drops its driver component into one of those service's paths, replacing the legitimate executable.
The malware then sets the hijacked service to start automatically to establish persistence.

[Cobian RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0338) creates an autostart Registry key to ensure persistence.
[AvosLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1053) has been executed via the "RunOnce" Registry key to run itself on safe mode.

[SNUGRIDE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0159)
establishes persistence through a Registry Run key.
[QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650)
can maintain persistence by creating an auto-run Registry key.
[Heyoka Backdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1027) can establish persistence with the auto start function including using the value "EverNoteTrayUService".
[Nebulae](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0630) can achieve persistence through a Registry Run key.
[DnsSystem](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1021) can write itself to the Startup folder to gain persistence.

[PUNCHBUGGY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0196)
has been observed using a Registry Run key.

installs a registry Run key to establish persistence.
[Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256) establishes persistence under the Registry key "HKCU\Software\Run auto_update".

[Lucifer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0532) can persist by setting Registry key values "HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\QQMusic" and "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\QQMusic".
[Briba](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0204)
creates run key Registry entries pointing to malicious DLLs dropped to disk.
[Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367)
has been observed adding the downloaded payload to the "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" key to maintain persistence.
[Mustang Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0129) has created the registry key "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Wow6432Node\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\AdobelmdyU" to maintain persistence.

If establishing persistence by installation as a new service fails, one variant of [Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081) establishes persistence for the created .exe file by setting the following Registry key: "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\svchost : %APPDATA%\Microsoft\Network\svchost.exe".

Other variants have set the following Registry keys for persistence: "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\imejp : [self]" and "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\IAStorD".
[Carberp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0484) has maintained persistence by placing itself inside the current user's startup folder.

A [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) Javascript backdoor added a local_update_check value under the Registry key "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" to establish persistence.
Additionally, a [Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) custom executable containing Metasploit shellcode is saved to the Startup folder to gain persistence.
[LuminousMoth](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1014) has used malicious DLLs that setup persistence in the Registry Key "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\Current Version\Run".

[Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) used the startup folder for persistence.

[SharpStage](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0546) has the ability to create persistence for the malware using the Registry autorun key and startup folder.
[Bisonal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0268)
has added itself to the Registry key "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\CurrentVersion\Run\" for persistence.
[Taidoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0011) has modified the "HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" key for persistence.
[CrossRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0235) uses run keys for persistence on Windows
[GuLoader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0561)
can establish persistence via the Registry under "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce".
[Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) has created Registry Run keys to establish persistence.
[PowerShower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0441)
sets up persistence with a Registry run key.
[Vasport](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0207) copies itself to disk and creates an associated run key Registry entry to establish.
[Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) has added the path of its second-stage malware to the startup folder to achieve persistence.
One of its file stealers has also persisted by adding a Registry Run key.
[Aria-body](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0456)
has established persistence via the Startup folder or Run Registry key.
[LAPSUS$](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1004)
has accessed internet-facing identity providers such as Azure Active Directory and Okta to target specific organizations.

During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) gained access through compromised accounts at cloud solution partners, and used compromised certificates issued by Mimecast to authenticate to Mimecast customer systems.
[GOLD SOUTHFIELD](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0115) has breached Managed Service Providers (MSP's) to deliver malware to MSP customers.
[Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has compromised third party service providers to gain access to victim's environments.
[POLONIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1005) has used compromised credentials from an IT company to target downstream customers including a law firm and aviation company.
[menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has used legitimate access granted to Managed Service Providers in order to access victims of interest.
[Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) has used dedicated network connections from one victim organization to gain unauthorized access to a separate organization.
Once [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) gained access to the DCCC network, the group then proceeded to use that access to compromise the DNC network.
[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has compromised IT, cloud services, and managed services providers to gain broad access to multiple customers for subsequent operations.
[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) can create new users through Azure AD.
[LAPSUS$](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1004) has created global admin accounts in the targeted organization's cloud instances to gain persistence.
[AADInternals](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0677) can create new Azure AD users.
[Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used "net localgroup" and "net localgroup Administrators" to enumerate group information, including members of the local administrators group.
[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) can use "net localgroup" to list local groups on a system.
[JPIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0201) can obtain the permissions of the victim user.
[Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) gathers information about local groups and members.
During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), threat actors used the command "net localgroup administrators" to list all administrators part of a local group.
[OSInfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0165) has enumerated the local administrators group.
[OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used "net localgroup administrators" to find local administrators on compromised systems.
During [C0015](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0015), the threat actors used the command "net localgroup "adminstrator" " to identify accounts with local administrator rights.
[Sys10](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0060)
collects the group name of the logged-in user and sends it to the C2.
Commands such as "net group" and "net localgroup" can be used in [Net](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0039) to gather information about and manipulate groups.
[POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may collect local group information by running "net localgroup administrators" or a series of other commands on a victim.
[HEXANE](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1001) has run "net localgroup" to enumerate local groups.

[admin@338](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0018) actors used the following command following exploitation of a machine with [LOWBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0042) malware to list local groups: "net localgroup administrator >> %temp%\download"
[QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) can use "net localgroup" to enable discovery of local groups.
[PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378)
contains modules, such as "Get-LocAdm" for enumerating permission groups.
[SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) can obtain a list of local groups and members.
[Flagpro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0696) has been used to execute the "net localgroup administrators" command on a targeted system.
[Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) has the capability to execute the command "net localgroup administrators".
[Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) gathers information on local group names.

[Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects a list of users belonging to the local users and administrators groups with the commands "net localgroup administrators" and "net localgroup users".
[FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) enumerates the privilege level of the victim during the initial infection.
[Chimera](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0114) has used "net localgroup administrators" to identify accounts with local administrative rights.
[Caterpillar WebShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0572) can obtain a list of local groups of users from a system.
During [Operation CuckooBees](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0012), the threat actors used the "net group" command as part of their advanced reconnaissance.
[BloodHound](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0521) can collect information about local groups and members.
[Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) has checked the local administrators group.
[Tonto Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0131) has used the "ShowLocalGroupDetails" command to identify administrator, user, and guest accounts on a compromised host.

[Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) researched Ukraine's unique legal entity identifier (called an "EDRPOU" number), including running queries on the EDRPOU website, in preparation for the [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) attack.
[Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) has also researched third-party websites to help it craft credible spearphishing emails.
[Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) has added a user named DefaultAccount to the Administrators and Remote Desktop Users groups.
[HAFNIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0125) has granted privileges to domain accounts.
[Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) adds permissions and remote logins to all users.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has added accounts to specific groups with "net localgroup".
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) has added user accounts to the User and Admin groups.
[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware WhiskeyDelta-Two contains a function that attempts to rename the administrator’s account.
[SMOKEDHAM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0649) has added user accounts to local Admin groups.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has been known to add created accounts to local admin groups to maintain elevated access.
[ServHelper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0382) has added a user named "supportaccount" to the Remote Desktop Users and Administrators groups.

During the [2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0025), [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) used the "sp_addlinkedsrvlogin" command in MS-SQL to create a link between a created account and other servers in the network.
[Dragonfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0035) has added newly created accounts to the administrators group to maintain elevated access.
The [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) credential dumper has been extended to include Skeleton Key domain controller authentication bypass functionality.
The "LSADUMP::ChangeNTLM" and "LSADUMP::SetNTLM" modules can also manipulate the password hash of an account without knowing the clear text value.
[Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) connects to a predefined domain on port 443 to exfil gathered information.
[AADInternals](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0677) can directly download cloud user data such as OneDrive files.
[FrameworkPOS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0503) can use DNS tunneling for exfiltration of credit card data.
[Kobalos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0641)
can exfiltrate credentials over the network via UDP.
[Bundlore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0482) uses the "curl -s -L -o" command to exfiltrate archived data to a URL.
[PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has used a .NET tool named dog.exe to exiltrate information over an e-mail account.
[TeamTNT](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0139)
has sent locally staged files with collected credentials to C2 servers using cURL.
[Chaes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0631) has exfiltrated its collected data from the infected machine to the C2, sometimes using the MIME protocol.
[Skidmap](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0468) has the ability to install several loadable kernel modules (LKMs) on infected machines.
[Drovorub](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0502)
can use kernel modules to establish persistence.
During [Operation CuckooBees](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0012), attackers used a signed kernel rootkit to establish additional persistence.
[Dok](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0281) prompts the user for credentials.
[Metamorfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0455) has displayed fake forms on top of banking sites to intercept credentials from victims.
[FIN4](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0085) has presented victims with spoofed Windows Authentication prompts to collect their credentials.
[Bundlore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0482)
prompts the user for their credentials.
[SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692)'s "credphisher.py" module can prompt a current user for their credentials.
[iKitten](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0278) prompts the user for their credentials.

[XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) prompts the user to input credentials using a native macOS dialog box using the system process "/Applications/Safari.app/Contents/MacOS/SafariForWebKitDevelopment".
[Calisto](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0274) presents an input prompt asking for the user's login and password.
[Proton](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0279) prompts users for their credentials.
[Keydnap](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0276) prompts the users for credentials.
