[GoldenSpy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0493)'s uninstaller has base64-encoded its variables.
[Final1stspy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0355) obfuscates strings with base64 encoding.
[Cuba](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0625) has used multiple layers of obfuscation to avoid analysis, including its Base64 encoded payload.
[APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has used malware to drop encrypted CAB files.
A [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) tool can encrypt payloads using XOR.
[Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) malware is also obfuscated using Metasploit’s shikata_ga_nai encoder as well as compressed with LZNT1 compression.
[NOKKI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0353) uses Base64 encoding for strings.
[Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) uses encrypted Windows APIs and also encrypts data using the alternative base64+RC4 or the Caesar cipher.
[REvil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0496) has used encrypted strings and configuration files.
[Group5](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0043) disguised its malicious binaries with several layers of obfuscation, including encrypting the files.
[Kobalos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0641) encrypts all strings using RC4 and bundles all functionality into a single function call.
[jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283)’s Java payload is encrypted with AES.
Additionally, backdoor files are encrypted using DES as a stream cipher.
Later variants of [jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) also incorporated AV evasion methods such as Java bytecode obfuscation via the commercial Allatori obfuscation tool.

[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) has used multiple types of encryption and encoding for their payloads, including AES, Caracachs, RC4, XOR, Base64, and other tricks such as creating aliases in code for [Native API](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1106) function names.
[Mafalda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1060) has been obfuscated and contains encrypted functions.
[Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) is obfuscated using the open source ConfuserEx protector.
[Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) also obfuscates the name of created files/folders/mutexes and encrypts debug messages written to log files using the Rijndael cipher.
[Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) has encrypted configuration files.
[Drovorub](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0502) has used XOR encrypted payloads in WebSocket client to server messages.
A [RedLeaves](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0153) configuration file is encrypted with a simple XOR key, 0x53.
[FlawedGrace](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0383) encrypts its C2 configuration files with AES in CBC mode.
[Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) uses encrypted configuration blocks and writes encrypted files to disk.
For [Operation Spalax](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0005), the threat actors used XOR-encrypted payloads.
[SUNBURST](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0559) strings were compressed and encoded in Base64.
[SUNBURST](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0559)
also obfuscated collected system information using a FNV-1a + XOR algorithm.
[SHOTPUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0063) is obscured using XOR encoding and appended to a valid GIF file.
[Anchor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0504) has obfuscated code with stack strings and string encryption.
[Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) has used an XOR-based algorithm to encrypt payloads twice with different keys.
[Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) malware has used base64-encoded files and has also encrypted embedded strings with AES.
[KGH_SPY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0526) has used encrypted strings in its installer.
[Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) encrypts strings to make analysis more difficult.
[Windshift](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0112) has used string encoding with floating point calculations.
[ZeroT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0230) has encrypted its payload with RC4.
[metaMain](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1059)'s module file has been encrypted via XOR.
[BLUELIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0657) has a XOR-encoded payload.
[Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) downloads additional files that are base64-encoded and encrypted with another cipher.
[CARROTBAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0462) has the ability to download a base64 encoded payload.
[Mustang Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0129) has delivered initial payloads hidden using archives and encoding measures.
A [Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) variant is encoded using a simple XOR cipher.
[Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) has used Base64 encoding within malware variants.
[PcShare](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1050) has been encrypted with XOR using different 32-long Base16 strings and compressed with LZW algorithm.
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) encrypted a .dll payload using RTL and a custom encryption algorithm.
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007)
has also obfuscated payloads with base64, XOR, and RC4.
[InnaputRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0259)
uses an 8-byte XOR key to obfuscate API names and other strings contained in the payload.
[Higaisa](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0126) used Base64 encoded compressed payloads.
[SDBbot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0461) has the ability to XOR the strings for its installer component with a hardcoded 128 byte key.
[IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483) has utilzed encrypted binaries and base64 encoded strings.
[Sliver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0633) can encrypt strings at compile time.
[Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) has used XOR, RSA2, and RC4 encrypted files.
[TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) uses non-descriptive names to hide functionality and uses an AES CBC (256 bits) encryption algorithm for its loader and configuration files.
[IronNetInjector](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0581) can obfuscate variable names, encrypt strings, as well as base64 encode and Rijndael encrypt payloads.
[FatDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0512) can use base64 encoding, string stacking, and opaque predicates for obfuscation.
[Kessel](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0487)'s configuration is hardcoded and RC4 encrypted within the binary.
[CORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0137) obfuscates strings using a custom stream cipher.
[Blue Mockingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0108) has obfuscated the wallet address in the payload binary.
[Kerrdown](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0585) can encrypt, encode, and compress multiple layers of shellcode.
[HermeticWizard](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0698) has the ability to encrypt PE files with a reverse XOR loop.
[UBoatRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0333) encrypts instructions in the payload using a simple XOR cipher.
[ShimRatReporter](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0445) encrypted gathered information with a combination of shifting and XOR using a static key.
[MiniDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0051) can use control flow flattening to obscure code.
[Squirrelwaffle](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1030) has been obfuscated with a XOR-based algorithm.
[Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) encrypts some of its files with XOR.
[TEARDROP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0560) created and read from a file with a fake JPG header, and its payload was encrypted with a simple rotating XOR cipher.

Strings in [Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438)'s components are encrypted with a XOR cipher, using a hardcoded key and the configuration data, log files and plugins are encrypted using a hybrid encryption scheme of Blowfish-OFB combined with RSA.
[SoreFang](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0516) has the ability to encode and RC6 encrypt data sent to C2.
[Conti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0575) can use compiler-based obfuscation for its code, encrypt DLLs, and hide Windows API calls.
[HAWKBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0391) has encrypted the payload with an XOR-based algorithm.
[SysUpdate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0663) can encrypt and encode its configuration file.
[Turian](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0647) can use VMProtect for obfuscation.
[ISMInjector](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0189) is obfuscated with the off-the-shelf SmartAssembly .NET obfuscator created by red-gate.com.
[Metamorfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0455) has encrypted payloads and strings.
[PowerStallion](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0393) uses a XOR cipher to encrypt command output written to its OneDrive C2 server.
The [Clambling](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0660) executable has been obfuscated when dropped on a compromised host.
A [JPIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0201) uses a encrypted and compressed payload that is disguised as a bitmap within the resource section of the installer.
[DRATzarus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0694) can be partly encrypted with XOR.
[HTTPBrowser](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0070)'s code may be obfuscated through structured exception handling and return-oriented programming.
[Earth Lusca](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1006) used Base64 to encode strings.
[GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237) supports file encryption (AES with the key "lolomycin2017").
[PS1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0613) is distributed as a set of encrypted files and scripts.
[HiddenWasp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0394)
encrypts its configuration and payload.
The payload of [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046) is encrypted with simple XOR with a rotating key.
The [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046) configuration file has been encrypted with RC4 keys.
[AppleJeus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0584) has XOR-encrypted collected system information prior to sending to a C2.
[AppleJeus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0584) has also used the open source ADVObfuscation library for its components.
[Transparent Tribe](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0134) has dropped encoded executables on compromised hosts.
[StreamEx](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0142)
obfuscates some commands by using statically programmed fragments of strings when starting a DLL.
It also uses a one-byte xor against 0x91 to encode configuration data.
[PyDCrypt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1032)
has been compiled and encrypted with PyInstaller, specifically using the --key flag during the build phase.
Droppers used by [Putter Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0024) use RC4 or a 16-byte XOR key consisting of the bytes 0xA0 – 0xAF to obfuscate payloads.
[HyperBro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0398)
can be delivered encrypted to a compromised host.
[Flagpro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0696) has been delivered within ZIP or RAR password-protected archived files.
[OLDBAIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0138)
obfuscates internal strings and unpacks them at startup.
The [FIVEHANDS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0618) payload is encrypted with AES-128.
[Elderwood](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0066) has encrypted documents and malicious executables.
[PolyglotDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0518) can custom encrypt strings.
[WindTail](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0466) can be delivered as a compressed, encrypted, and encoded payload.
[menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has encoded strings in its malware with base64 as well as with a simple, single-byte XOR obfuscation using key 0x40.
[SodaMaster](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0627) can use "stackstrings" for obfuscation.
[BITTER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1002) has used a RAR SFX dropper to deliver malware.
[Matryoshka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0167) obfuscates API function names using a substitute cipher combined with Base64 encoding.
[DarkTortilla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1066)
has been obfuscated with the DeepSea .NET and ConfuserEx code obfuscators.
[EnvyScout](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0634)
can Base64 encode payloads.
[Fox Kitten](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0117) has base64 encoded payloads to avoid detection.
[Ecipekac](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0624) can use XOR, AES, and DES to encrypt loader shellcode.
[ThreatNeedle](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0665)
has been compressed and obfuscated using RC4, AES, or XOR.
[MCMD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0500) can Base64 encode output strings prior to sending to C2.
[Industroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0604) uses heavily obfuscated code in its Windows Notepad backdoor.
[ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) can encrypt data prior to exfiltration by using an RSA public key.
[AuditCred](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0347) encrypts the configuration.
[Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330)
encrypts strings with XOR.
[Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) also encrypts all configuration and settings in AES and RC4.
Some strings in [HOMEFRY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0232) are obfuscated with XOR x56.
[Metador](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1013) has encrypted their payloads.
[CoinTicker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0369) initially downloads a hidden encoded file.
[Goopy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0477)'s decrypter have been inflated with junk code in between legitimate API functions, and also included infinite loops to avoid analysis.
[DanBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1014)
can Base64 encode its payload.
[TajMahal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0467) has used an encrypted Virtual File System to store plugins.

During the [2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0025), [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) used heavily obfuscated code with [Industroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0604) in its Windows Notepad backdoor.
[Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) has used Base64-encoded shellcode strings.
[TA505](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092) has password-protected malicious Word documents.
[SpeakUp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0374) encodes its second-stage payload with Base64.
[APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) obfuscates strings and payloads.
[Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) has the ability to compress its components.
[RegDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0511)
can use control-flow flattening or the commercially available .NET Reactor for obfuscation.
[Sakula](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0074) uses single-byte XOR obfuscation to obfuscate many of its files.
[Ryuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0446) can use anti-disassembly and code transformation obfuscation techniques.
[Dridex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0384)'s strings are obfuscated using RC4.
[Remcos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0332)
uses RC4 and base64 to obfuscate data, including Registry entries and file paths.
[Inception](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0100) has encrypted malware payloads dropped on victim machines with AES and RC4 encryption.
[WhisperGate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0689) can Base64 encode strings, store downloaded files in reverse byte order, and use the Eazfuscator tool to obfuscate its third stage.
[Dark Caracal](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0070) has obfuscated strings in [Bandook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0234) by base64 encoding, and then encrypting them.
[Exaramel for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0401) uses RC4 for encrypting the configuration.
[Raindrop](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0565)
encrypted its payload using a simple XOR algorithm with a single-byte key.
[Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) uses basic obfuscation in the form of spaghetti code.
[ShimRat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0444) has been delivered as a package that includes compressed DLL and shellcode payloads within a .dat file.
During [Operation Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0006), the threat actors used Base64 to encode files with a custom key.
[GoldMax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0588) has written AES-encrypted and Base64-encoded configuration files to disk.
[Molerats](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0021) has delivered compressed executables within ZIP files to victims.
[Saint Bot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1018) has been obfuscated to help avoid detection.
[Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) encodes many of its artifacts and is encrypted (AES-128) when downloaded.
[SUNSPOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0562) encrypted log entries it collected with the stream cipher RC4 using a hard-coded key
It also uses AES128-CBC encrypted blobs for [SUNBURST](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0559) source code and data extracted from the SolarWinds Orion <MsBuild.exe" process.
[Amadey](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1025)
has obfuscated strings such as antivirus vendor names, domains, files, and others.
[ECCENTRICBANDWAGON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0593) has encrypted strings with RC4.
[BoomBox](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0635) can encrypt data using AES prior to exfiltration.
APIs and strings in some [TYPEFRAME](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0263) variants are RC4 encrypted.
Another variant is encoded with XOR.
[Denis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0354)
obfuscates its code and encrypts the API names.
[Rifdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0433) has encrypted strings with a single byte XOR algorithm.
[Shark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1019) can use encrypted and encoded files for C2 configuration.
[Bundlore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0482)
has obfuscated data with base64, AES, RC4, and bz2.
[Aria-body](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0456) has used an encrypted configuration file for its loader.
[RCSession](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0662) can compress and obfuscate its strings to evade detection on a compromised host.
[EKANS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0605) uses encoded strings in its process kill list.
[PUNCHBUGGY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0196)
has hashed most its code's functions and encrypted payloads with base64 and XOR.
[Out1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0594) has the ability to encode data.
[Penquin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0587) has encrypted strings in the binary for obfuscation.
[BoxCaon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0651) used the "StackStrings" obfuscation technique to hide malicious functionalities.
[DarkWatchman](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0673) has been delivered as compressed RAR payloads in ZIP files to victims.
[Bumblebee](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1039) has been delivered as password-protected zipped ISO files and used control-flow-flattening to obfuscate the flow of functions.
[PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012) hides any strings related to its own indicators of compromise.
[KillDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0607)
uses VMProtect to make reverse engineering the malware more difficult.
The [Grandoreiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0531) payload has been delivered encrypted with a custom XOR-based algorithm and also as a base64-encoded ZIP file.
[GrimAgent](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0632) has used Rotate on Right (RoR) and Rotate on Left (RoL) functionality to encrypt strings.
In one version of [KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387), string obfuscation routines were used to hide many of the critical values referenced in the malware.
[Pandora](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0664) has the ability to compress stings with QuickLZ.
[APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has performed code obfuscation, including encoding payloads using Base64 and using a framework called "Dont-Kill-My-Cat (DKMC).
[APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) also encrypts the library used for network exfiltration with AES-256 in CBC mode in their macOS backdoor.
[APT19](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0073) used Base64 to obfuscate payloads.
[BitPaymer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0570) has used RC4-encrypted strings and string hashes to avoid identifiable strings within the binary.
[Mofang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0103) has compressed the [ShimRat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0444) executable within malicious email attachments.
[Mofang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0103) has also encrypted payloads before they are downloaded to victims.
[Rocke](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0106) has modified UPX headers after packing files to break unpackers.
[Diavol](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0659) has Base64 encoded the RSA public key used for encrypting files.
[Dacls](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0497)
can encrypt its configuration file with AES CBC.
[P.A.S. Webshell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0598) can use encryption and base64 encoding to hide strings and to enforce access control once deployed.
[APT18](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0026) obfuscates strings in the payload.
During [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0002), threat actors used a DLL that included an XOR-encoded section.

[APT-C-36](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0099) has used ConfuserEx to obfuscate its variant of [Imminent Monitor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0434), compressed payload and RAT packages, and password protected encrypted email attachments to avoid detection.
The [DustySky](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0062) dropper uses a function to obfuscate the name of functions and other parts of the malware.
[Hildegard](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0601) has encrypted an ELF file.

[Small Sieve](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1035) has the ability to use a custom hex byte swapping encoding scheme combined with an obfuscated Base64 function to protect program strings and Telegram credentials.
[njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) has included a base64 encoded executable.
[Gallmaker](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0084) obfuscated shellcode used during execution.
[Seasalt](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0345) obfuscates configuration data.
[LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) encrypts its configuration files with AES-256.
[RainyDay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0629) has downloaded as a XOR-encrypted payload.
[Skidmap](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0468)
has encrypted it's main payload using 3DES.

During [Operation Dust Storm](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0016), the threat actors encoded some payloads with a single-byte XOR, both skipping the key itself and zeroing in an attempt to avoid exposing the key; other payloads were Base64-encoded.
[KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) is heavily obfuscated and includes encrypted configuration files.
[Remexi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0375) obfuscates its configuration data with XOR.
[More_eggs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0284)'s payload has been encrypted with a key that has the hostname and processor family information appended to the end.
[Pony](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0453) attachments have been delivered via compressed archive files.
[Pony](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0453) also obfuscates the memory flow by adding junk instructions when executing to make analysis more difficult.
Some data in [Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) is encrypted using RC5 in CBC mode, AES-CBC with a hardcoded key, RC4, or Salsa20.
Some data is also base64-encoded.
[Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168)
logs its actions into files that are encrypted with 3DES.
It also uses RSA to encrypt resources.
[Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256)’s installer is obfuscated with a custom crypter to obfuscate the installer.
[Winnti for Windows](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0141) has the ability to encrypt and compress its payload.
[APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has used base64 to encode payloads.
Some [Orz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0229) strings are base64 encoded, such as the embedded DLL known as MockDll.
[Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has obfuscated code using base64 and gzip compression.
[NETWIRE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0198) has used a custom obfuscation algorithm to hide strings including Registry keys, APIs, and DLL names.
The [WastedLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0612) payload includes encrypted strings stored within the .bss section of the binary file.
[Taidoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0011) can use encrypted string blocks for obfuscation.
[KEYPLUG](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1051) can use a hardcoded one-byte XOR encoded configuration file.
[Woody RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1065) has used Base64 encoded strings and scripts.
[StrongPity](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0491) has used encrypted strings in its dropper component.
[Avaddon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0640) has used encrypted strings.
[BendyBear](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0574) has encrypted payloads using RC4 and XOR.
Variants of [Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) encrypt payloads using various XOR ciphers, as well as a custom algorithm that uses the "srand" and "rand" functions.
[Valak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0476) has the ability to base64 encode and XOR encrypt strings.
[Heyoka Backdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1027) can encrypt its payload.

[FunnyDream](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1044) can Base64 encode its C2 address stored in a template binary with the "xyz0123456789ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZabcdefghijklmnopqrstuvw_-" or "xyz0123456789ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZabcdefghijklmnopqrstuvw_=" character sets.
[NanHaiShu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0228)
encodes files in Base64.
[Chrommme](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0667)
can encrypt sections of its code to evade detection.
[PipeMon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0501) modules are stored encrypted on disk.
[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) can hash functions to obfuscate calls to the Windows API and use a public/private key pair to encrypt Beacon session metadata.
[Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used an XOR-based algorithm to encrypt Tor clients dropped to disk.

[Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) droppers have also been delivered as password-protected zip files that execute base64 encoded [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) commands.
[Siloscape](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0623) itself is obfuscated and uses obfuscated API calls.
[Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335)
encrypts configuration files and tasks for the malware to complete using CAST-128 algorithm.
[DEADEYE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1052) has encrypted its payload.
[SVCReady](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1064)
can encrypt victim data with an RC4 cipher.
The [Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) config file is encrypted with RC4.
[DCSrv](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1033)'s configuration is encrypted.
[Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) heavily obfuscates its code to make analysis more difficult.
[PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) can use API hashing and modify the names of strings to evade detection.
[POSHSPY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0150) appends a file signature header (randomly selected from six file types) to encrypted data prior to upload or download.
[AvosLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1053)
has used XOR-encoded strings.
[NanoCore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0336)’s plugins were obfuscated with Eazfuscater.NET 3.3.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) obfuscates files or information to help evade defensive measures.
[BOOSTWRITE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0415) has encoded its payloads using a ChaCha stream cipher with a 256-bit key and 64-bit Initialization vector (IV) to evade detection.
[Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) has obfuscated code using RC4, XOR, and RSA.
[GreyEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0342)
encrypts its configuration files with AES-256 and also encrypts its strings.
[Winnti for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0430) can encode its configuration file with single-byte XOR encoding.
Most of the strings in [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) are encrypted with an XOR-based algorithm; some strings are also encrypted with 3DES and reversed.
API function names are also reversed, presumably to avoid detection in memory.
[Lokibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0447) has obfuscated strings with base64 encoding.
[OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0352)
encrypts its strings in RSA256 and encodes them in a custom base64 scheme and XOR.

During [Operation Dream Job](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0022), [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) encrypted malware such as [DRATzarus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0694) with XOR and DLL files with base64.
[TeamTNT](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0139) has encrypted its binaries via AES and encoded files using Base64.
[Pisloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0124) obfuscates files by splitting strings into smaller sub-strings and including "garbage" strings that are never used.
The malware also uses return-oriented programming (ROP) technique and single-byte XOR to obfuscate data.
[OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has encrypted and encoded data in its malware, including by using base64.
[OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) uses the Confuser protector to obfuscate an embedded .Net Framework assembly used for C2.
[OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) also encodes collected data in hexadecimal format before writing to files on disk and obfuscates strings.
[Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) has obfuscated its strings with a simple XOR encryption with a static key.
[HermeticWiper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0697) can compress 32-bit and 64-bit driver files with the Lempel-Ziv algorithm.
[SUPERNOVA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0578) contained Base64-encoded strings.
[CARROTBALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0465) has used a custom base64 alphabet to decode files.
[Carberp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0484) has used XOR-based encryption to mask C2 server locations within the trojan.
[YAHOYAH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0388) encrypts its configuration file using a simple algorithm.
[Waterbear](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0579) has used RC4 encrypted shellcode and encrypted functions.
[Comnie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0244) uses RC4 and Base64 to obfuscate strings.
[BackdoorDiplomacy](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0135) has obfuscated tools and malware it uses with VMProtect.
Some resources in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) are encrypted with a simple XOR operation or encoded with Base64.
[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) avoids analysis by encrypting all strings, internal files, configuration data and by using a custom executable format.
[STARWHALE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1037) has been obfuscated with hex-encoded strings.
[ShadowPad](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0596) has encrypted its payload, a virtual file system, and various files.
[Milan](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1015) can encode files containing information about the targeted system.

[Imminent Monitor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0434) has encrypted the spearphish attachments to avoid detection from email gateways; the debugger also encrypts information before sending to the C2.
[Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) has base64-encoded its portable executable and hidden itself under a JPG header.
[Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) can also embed information within document footers.
[Hi-Zor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0087) uses various XOR techniques to obfuscate its components.
[H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) uses multiple techniques to obfuscate strings, including XOR.
[Hancitor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0499) has used Base64 to encode malicious links.
[Hancitor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0499) has also delivered compressed payloads in ZIP files to victims.
[Avenger](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0473) has the ability to XOR encrypt files to be sent to C2.
[Bisonal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0268)'s DLL file and non-malicious decoy file are encrypted with RC4 and some function name strings are obfuscated.
[Conficker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0608) has obfuscated its code to prevent its removal from host machines.
[Zox](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0672) has been encoded with Base64.
[ZxxZ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1013) has been encoded to avoid detection from static analysis tools.
[PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has used a custom encryption scheme for communication between scripts.
[Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) contains base64-encoded strings.
[FoggyWeb](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0661) has been XOR-encoded.
[Ember Bear](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1003) has obfuscated malware to help avoid detection.
[Action RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1028)'s commands, strings, and domains can be Base64 encoded within the payload.
During [C0015](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0015), the threat actors used Base64-encoded strings.

During [C0017](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0017), [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) broke malicious binaries, including [DEADEYE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1052) and [KEYPLUG](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1051), into multiple sections on disk to evade detection.

A version of [XTunnel](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0117) introduced in July 2015 obfuscated the binary using opaque predicates and other techniques in a likely attempt to obfuscate it and bypass security products.
[FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182)
is heavily obfuscated in many ways, including through the use of spaghetti code in its functions in an effort to confuse disassembly programs.
It also uses a custom XOR algorithm to obfuscate code.
[Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) obfuscates the configuration with a custom Base64 and XOR.
[Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) has had its code obfuscated in an apparent attempt to make analysis difficult.
[Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) has used the Rijndael symmetric encryption algorithm to encrypt strings.
[Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) has delivered self-extracting 7z archive files within malicious document attachments.
[Sidewinder](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0121) has used base64 encoding and ECDH-P256 encryption for payloads.
[SombRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0615) can encrypt strings with XOR-based routines and use a custom AES storage format for plugins, configuration, C2 domains, and harvested data.
Many strings in [JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) are obfuscated with a XOR algorithm.
[FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) encrypts strings in the backdoor using a custom XOR algorithm.
Configuration data used by [Rising Sun](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0448) has been encrypted using an RC4 stream algorithm.
[QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) has hidden code within Excel spreadsheets by turning the font color to white and splitting it across multiple cells.
[TINYTYPHON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0131) has used XOR with 0x90 to obfuscate its configuration file.
[BlackOasis](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0063)'s first stage shellcode contains a NOP sled with alternative instructions that was likely designed to bypass antivirus tools.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has obfuscated binary strings including the use of XOR encryption and Base64 encoding.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has also modified the first byte of DLL implants targeting victims to prevent recognition of the executable file format.
[Green Lambert](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0690) has encrypted strings.
[DOGCALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0213) is encrypted using single-byte XOR.
[Torisma](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0678) has been Base64 encoded and AES encrypted.
[Smoke Loader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0226) uses a simple one-byte XOR method to obfuscate values in the malware.
[Donut](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0695) can generate encrypted, compressed/encoded, or otherwise obfuscated code modules.
[HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) has encrypted strings with single-byte XOR and base64 encoded RC4.
[Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) has used encrypted payload files and maintains an encrypted configuration structure in memory.
[Maze](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0449) has decrypted strings and other important information during the encryption process.
[Maze](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0449)
also calls certain functions dynamically to hinder analysis.

[GALLIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) used a modified version of [HTRAN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0040) in which they obfuscated strings such as debug messages in an apparent attempt to evade detection.
[LoudMiner](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0451) has encrypted DMG files.
Most strings in [USBStealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0136) are encrypted using 3DES and XOR and reversed.
[RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) strings, network data, configuration, and modules are encrypted with a modified RC4 algorithm.
[RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) has also been delivered to targets as various archive files including ZIP, 7-ZIP, and RAR.
[ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126)
has encrypted its virtual file system using AES-256 in XTS mode.
[Whitefly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0107) has encrypted the payload used for C2.
[Kevin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1020) has Base64-encoded its configuration file.
[StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380)
has obfuscated its module with an alphabet-based table or XOR encryption.
[AppleSeed](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0622) has the ability to Base64 encode its payload and custom encrypt API calls.
[Chinoxy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1041)
has encrypted its configuration file.
[Fysbis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0410)
has been encrypted using XOR and RC4.
[SamSam](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0370)
has been seen using AES or DES to encrypt payloads and payload components.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used VMProtected binaries in multiple intrusions.
[Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) can base64 encode and AES-128-CBC encrypt data prior to transmission.
[Moses Staff](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1009) has used obfuscated web shells in their operations.
[SynAck](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0242) payloads are obfuscated prior to compilation to inhibit analysis and/or reverse engineering.
[VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) is obfuscated using the obfuscation tool called ConfuserEx.
[Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081) encrypts several of its files, including configuration files.
[Pillowmint](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0517) has been compressed and stored within a registry key.
[Pillowmint](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0517) has also obfuscated the AES key used for encryption.
[PUNCHTRACK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0197)
is loaded and executed by a highly obfuscated launcher.
The [AADInternals](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0677) "Set-AADIntUserMFA" command can be used to disable MFA for a specified user.
[FIN4](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0085) has accessed and hijacked online email communications using stolen credentials.
[Dragonfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0035) has accessed email accounts using Outlook Web Access.

During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) collected emails from specific individuals, such as executives and IT staff, using "New-MailboxExportRequest" followed by "Get-MailboxExportRequest".
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has collected emails from victim Microsoft Exchange servers.
Some [SeaDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0053) samples have a module to extract email from Microsoft Exchange servers using compromised credentials.
[APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) uses two utilities, GETMAIL and MAPIGET, to steal email.
MAPIGET steals email still on Exchange servers that has not yet been archived.
[Valak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0476)
can collect sensitive mailing information from Exchange servers, including credentials and the domain certificate of an enterprise.
[Leafminer](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0077) used a tool called MailSniper to search through the Exchange server mailboxes for keywords.
[HAFNIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0125) has used web shells to export mailbox data.
[Chimera](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0114) has harvested data from remote mailboxes including through execution of "\\<hostname>\c$\Users\<username>\AppData\Local\Microsoft\Outlook*.ost".
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has used tools such as the MailFetch mail crawler to collect victim emails (excluding spam) from online services via IMAP.
[MailSniper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0413) can be used for searching through email in Exchange and Office 365 environments.
[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has collected emails from targeted mailboxes within a compromised Azure AD tenant.
[Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) has exported emails from compromised Exchange servers including through use of the cmdlet "New-MailboxExportRequest."
[LightNeuron](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0395) collects Exchange emails matching rules specified in its configuration.
[Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) has used compromised credentials and a .NET tool to dump data from Microsoft Exchange mailboxes.
[IceApple](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1022)
is an IIS post-exploitation framework, consisting of 18 modules that provide several functionalities.
[RGDoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0258) establishes persistence on webservers as an IIS module.
[OwaAuth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0072) has been loaded onto Exchange servers and disguised as an ISAPI filter (owaauth.dll).
The IIS w3wp.exe process then loads the malicious DLL.

During [Operation Dream Job](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0022), [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) targeted Windows servers running Internet Information Systems (IIS) to install C2 components.
The [NETWIRE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0198) client has been signed by fake and invalid digital certificates.
[BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) is sometimes signed with an invalid Authenticode certificate in an apparent effort to make it look more legitimate.
[WindTail](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0466) has been incompletely signed with revoked certificates.
[APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) has signed its malware with an invalid digital certificates listed as “Tencent Technology (Shenzhen) Company Limited.”
[Windshift](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0112) has used revoked certificates to sign malware.
[Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) has used unverified signatures on malicious DLLs.

[Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) stage 1 modules for 64-bit systems have been found to be signed with fake certificates masquerading as originating from Microsoft Corporation and Broadcom Corporation.
[PcShare](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1050) has used an invalid certificate in attempt to appear legitimate.
[LoudMiner](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0451) has used QEMU and VirtualBox to run a Tiny Core Linux virtual machine, which runs XMRig and makes connections to the C2 server for updates.

[Maze](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0449) operators have used VirtualBox and a Windows 7 virtual machine to run the ransomware; the virtual machine's configuration file mapped the shared network drives of the target company, presumably so [Maze](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0449) can encrypt files on the shared drives as well as the local machine.
[Ragnar Locker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0481
) has used VirtualBox and a stripped Windows XP virtual machine to run itself.

The use of a shared folder specified in the configuration enables [Ragnar Locker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0481) to encrypt files on the host operating system, including files on any mapped drives.
[OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used net.exe in a script with "net accounts /domain" to find the password policy of a domain.
[Chimera](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0114) has used the NtdsAudit utility to collect information related to accounts and passwords.
During [Operation CuckooBees](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0012), the threat actors used the "net accounts" command as part of their advanced reconnaissance.
[PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378)
can use "Get-PassPol" to enumerate the domain password policy.
The "net accounts" and "net accounts /domain" commands with [Net](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0039) can be used to obtain password policy information.
[CrackMapExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0488)
can discover the password policies applied to the target system.
[BloodHound](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0521)
can collect password policy information on the target environment.
[Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used "net accounts" and "net accounts /domain" to acquire password policy information.
[Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) collects password policy information with the command "net accounts".

[Green Lambert](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0690) can establish persistence on a compromised host through modifying the "profile", "login", and run command (rc) files associated with the "bash", "csh", and "tcsh" shells.
[Linux Rabbit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0362) maintains persistence on an infected machine through rc.local and .bashrc files.
[DarkHydrus](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0079) used [Template Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1221) to launch an authentication window for users to enter their credentials.
[EnvyScout](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0634) can use protocol handlers to coax the operating system to send NTLMv2 authentication responses to attacker-controlled infrastructure.

[Dragonfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0035) has gathered hashed user credentials over SMB using spearphishing attachments with external resource links and by modifying .LNK file icon resources to collect credentials from virtualized systems.
[Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002)'s "MISC::AddSid" module can appended any SID or user/group account to a user's SID-History.

[Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) also utilizes [SID-History Injection](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1134/005) to expand the scope of other components such as generated Kerberos Golden Tickets and DCSync beyond a single domain.
[Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) can add a SID-History to a user if on a domain controller.
[FIVEHANDS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0618)
can use an embedded NTRU public key to encrypt data for ransom.
[ThiefQuest](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0595) encrypts a set of file extensions on a host, deletes the original files, and provides a ransom note with no contact information.
[KillDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0607) has a ransomware component that encrypts files with an AES key that is also RSA-1028 encrypted.
[APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) has used Hermes ransomware to encrypt files with AES256.
[RobbinHood](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0400) will search for an RSA encryption key and then perform its encryption process on the system files.
[SamSam](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0370) encrypts victim files using RSA-2048 encryption and demands a ransom be paid in Bitcoin to decrypt those files.
[NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) encrypts user files and disk structures like the MBR with 2048-bit RSA.
[LockerGoga](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0372) has encrypted files, including core Windows OS files, using RSA-OAEP MGF1 and then demanded Bitcoin be paid for the decryption key.
[WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) encrypts user files and demands that a ransom be paid in Bitcoin to decrypt those files.
[REvil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0496) can encrypt files on victim systems and demands a ransom to decrypt the files.
[Egregor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0554) can encrypt all non-system files using a hybrid AES-RSA algorithm prior to displaying a ransom note.
[DCSrv](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1033) has encrypted drives using the core encryption mechanism from DiskCryptor.
[Cuba](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0625) has the ability to encrypt system data and add the ".cuba" extension to encrypted files.
[ProLock](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0654) can encrypt files on a compromised host with RC6, and encrypts the key with RSA-1024.
[Seth-Locker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0639) can encrypt files on a targeted system, appending them with the suffix .seth.
[Avaddon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0640)
encrypts the victim system using a combination of AES256 and RSA encryption schemes.
[WastedLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0612) can encrypt data and leave a ransom note.
During [C0018](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0018), the threat actors used [AvosLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1053) ransomware to encrypt files on the compromised network.

[Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) has used [Prestige](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1058) ransomware to encrypt data at targeted organizations in transportation and related logistics industries in Ukraine and Poland.
[SynAck](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0242) encrypts the victims machine followed by asking the victim to pay a ransom.

[BitPaymer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0570) can import a hard-coded RSA 1024-bit public key, generate a 128-bit RC4 key for each file, and encrypt the file in place, appending ".locked" to the filename.

[TA505](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092) has used a wide variety of ransomware, such as [Clop](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0611), Locky, Jaff, Bart, Philadelphia, and GlobeImposter, to encrypt victim files and demand a ransom payment.
[MegaCortex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0576) has used the open-source library, Mbed Crypto, and generated AES keys to carry out the file encryption process.
[FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) has encrypted virtual disk volumes on ESXi servers using a version of Darkside ransomware.
[Babuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0638) can use ChaCha8 and ECDH to encrypt data.
[DEATHRANSOM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0616) can use public and private key pair encryption to encrypt files for ransom payment.
[Diavol](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0659)
has encrypted files using an RSA key though the "CryptEncrypt" API and has appended filenames with ".lock64".
[Ryuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0446) has used a combination of symmetric (AES) and asymmetric (RSA) encryption to encrypt files.
Files have been encrypted with their own AES key and given a file extension of .RYK.
Encrypted directories have had a ransom note of RyukReadMe.txt written to the directory.
[Indrik Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0119)
has encrypted domain-controlled systems using [BitPaymer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0570).
[BlackCat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1068) has the ability to encrypt Windows devices, Linux devices, and VMWare instances.
[HELLOKITTY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0617) can use an embedded RSA-2048 public key to encrypt victim data for ransom.
[Pay2Key](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0556) can encrypt data on victim's machines using RSA and AES algorithms in order to extort a ransom payment for decryption.
[Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) has used BitLocker and DiskCryptor to encrypt targeted workstations.
[Prestige](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1058) has used the CryptoPP C++ library to encrypt files on target systems using AES and appended filenames with ".enc".
[Clop](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0611)
can encrypt files using AES, RSA, and RC4 and will add the ".clop" extension to encrypted files.
[Black Basta](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1070) can encrypt files with the ChaCha20 cypher and using a multithreaded process to increase speed.
[Netwalker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0457)
can encrypt files on infected machines to extort victims.
[JCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0389) has encrypted files and demanded Bitcoin to decrypt those files.
[AvosLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1053) has encrypted files and network resources using AES-256 and added an ".avos", ".avos2", or ".AvosLinux" extension to filenames.
[Ragnar Locker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0481) encrypts files on the local machine and mapped drives prior to displaying a note demanding a ransom.
[Pysa](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0583) has used RSA and AES-CBC encryption algorithm to encrypt a list of targeted file extensions.
[EKANS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0605) uses standard encryption library functions to encrypt files.

[XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) performs AES-CBC encryption on files under "~/Documents", "~/Downloads", and "~/Desktop" with a fixed key and renames files to give them a ".enc" extension.
Only files with sizes less than 500MB are encrypted.
During [C0015](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0015), the threat actors used [Conti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0575) ransomware to encrypt a compromised network.
[Maze](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0449)
has disrupted systems by encrypting files on targeted machines, claiming to decrypt files if a ransom payment is made.
[Maze](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0449)
has used the ChaCha algorithm, based on Salsa20, and an RSA algorithm to encrypt files.

[Conti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0575) can use "CreateIoCompletionPort()", "PostQueuedCompletionStatus()", and "GetQueuedCompletionPort()" to rapidly encrypt files, excluding those with the extensions of .exe, .dll, and .lnk.
It has used a different AES-256 encryption key per file with a bundled RAS-4096 public encryption key that is unique for each victim.
[Conti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0575) can use “Windows Restart Manager” to ensure files are unlocked and open for encryption.
[Royal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1073)
uses a multi-threaded encryption process that can partially encrypt targeted files with the OpenSSL library and the AES256 algorithm.
[Xbash](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0341) has maliciously encrypted victim's database systems and demanded a cryptocurrency ransom be paid.
[Bad Rabbit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0606) has encrypted files and disks using AES-128-CBC and RSA-2048.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used a ransomware called Encryptor RaaS to encrypt files on the targeted systems and provide a ransom note to the user.
[Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) has an operational mode for encrypting data instead of overwriting it.
[Axiom](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0001) has used digital certificates to deliver malware.
[OSX/Shlayer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0402) can escalate privileges to root by asking the user for credentials.
[Chaes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0631)
has used encryption for its C2 channel.
[BITTER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1002) has encrypted their C2 communications.
[RCSession](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0662) can use an encrypted beacon to check in with C2.
[NETWIRE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0198) can encrypt C2 communications.
[Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) has encrypted traffic with the C2 to prevent network detection.
[PowGoop](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1046) can receive encrypted commands from C2.
[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has used multiple layers of encryption within malware to protect C2 communication.
[Cryptoistic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0498) can engage in encrypted communications with C2.
[Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) has used an encrypted http proxy in C2 communications.
[gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) has encrypted TCP communications to evade detection.
[MacMa](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1016) has used TLS encryption to initialize a custom protocol for C2 communications.
[Lizar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0681) can support encrypted communications between the client and server.
[PowerLess](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1012) can use an encrypted channel for C2 communications.
[Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143) can use Windows Authentication Packages for persistence.

[Egregor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0554) has used regsvr32.exe to execute malicious DLLs.

[Ragnar Locker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0481) has used regsvr32.exe to execute components of VirtualBox.
[EVILNUM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0568) can run a remote scriptlet that drops a file and executes it via regsvr32.exe.
[Xbash](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0341) can use regsvr32 for executing scripts.
[Squirrelwaffle](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1030) has been executed using "regsvr32.exe".

[Hi-Zor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0087) executes using regsvr32.exe called from the [Registry Run Keys / Startup Folder](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1547/001) persistence mechanism.
[Blue Mockingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0108) has executed custom-compiled XMRIG miner DLLs using regsvr32.exe.
[AppleSeed](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0622) can call regsvr32.exe for execution.

[TA551](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0127) has used regsvr32.exe to load malicious DLLs.

Some [Orz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0229) versions have an embedded DLL known as MockDll that uses [Process Hollowing](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1055/012) and regsvr32 to execute another payload.
[More_eggs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0284) has used regsvr32.exe to execute the malicious DLL.
[Saint Bot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1018) has used "regsvr32" to execute scripts.
[QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650) can use Regsvr32 to execute malicious DLLs.
[Deep Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0009) has used regsvr32.exe to execute a server variant of [Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) in victim networks.
During [Operation Dream Job](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0022), [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) used "regsvr32" to execute malware.
[Valak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0476) has used "regsvr32.exe" to launch malicious DLLs.
[APT19](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0073) used Regsvr32 to bypass application control techniques.
[HermeticWizard](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0698) has used "regsvr32.exe /s /i" to execute malicious payloads.
[Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) has used regsvr32.exe to execute scripts.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has executed malware with "regsvr32s".
[Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) can be loaded through regsvr32.exe.
[RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270) uses regsvr32.exe to run a .sct file for execution.
[WIRTE](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0090) has used "regsvr32.exe" to trigger the execution of a malicious script.

[Andariel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0138) has inserted a malicious script within compromised websites to collect potential victim information such as browser type, system language, Flash Player version, and other data.

[Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) has researched software code to enable supply-chain operations, most notably for the 2017 [NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) attack.
[Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) also collected a list of computers using specific software as part of its targeting efforts.
[Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) has captured the user-agent strings from visitors to their phishing sites.
[APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has utilized tools to capture mouse movements.
[Chaes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0631) has a module to perform any API hooking it desires.

can collect mouse events.

has used a compromised SSH client to capture the hostname, port, username and password used to establish an SSH connection from the compromised host.

[metaMain](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1059) can log mouse events.

For [Operation Dream Job](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0022), [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) used LinkedIn to identify and target employees within a chosen organization.

[JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) has used COM hijacking to establish persistence by hijacking a class named MMDeviceEnumerator and also by registering the payload as a Shell Icon Overlay handler COM object ({3543619C-D563-43f7-95EA-4DA7E1CC396A}).

[ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) samples have been seen which hijack COM objects for persistence by replacing the path to shell32.dll in registry location "HKCU\Software\Classes\CLSID\{42aedc87-2188-41fd-b9a3-0c966feabec1}\InprocServer32".
[SVCReady](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1064) has created the "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Classes\CLSID\{E6D34FFC-AD32-4d6a-934C-D387FA873A19}" Registry key for persistence.
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has used COM hijacking for persistence by replacing the legitimate "MMDeviceEnumerator" object with a payload.
[KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) has modified ComSysApp service to load the malicious DLL payload.

[BBSRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0127) has been seen persisting via COM hijacking through replacement of the COM object for MruPidlList "{42aedc87-2188-41fd-b9a3-0c966feabec1}" or Microsoft WBEM New Event Subsystem "{F3130CDB-AA52-4C3A-AB32-85FFC23AF9C1}" depending on the system's CPU architecture.
[PcShare](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1050) has created the "HKCU\\Software\\Classes\\CLSID\\{42aedc87-2188-41fd-b9a3-0c966feabec1}\\InprocServer32" Registry key for persistence.
[Ferocious](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0679) can use COM hijacking to establish persistence.
Some variants of [ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) achieve persistence by registering the payload as a Shell Icon Overlay handler COM object.
[Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256) uses COM hijacking as a method of persistence.

[SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) can add a CLSID key for payload execution through "Registry.CurrentUser.CreateSubKey("Software\\Classes\\CLSID\\{" + clsid + "}\\InProcServer32")".

[WarzoneRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0670) can perform COM hijacking by setting the path to itself to the "HKCU\Software\Classes\Folder\shell\open\command" key with a "DelegateExecute" parameter.

) gathered credentials from two victims that they then attempted to validate across 75 different websites.

During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) gained initial network access to some victims via a trojanized update of SolarWinds Orion software.

contains modules that can discover and exploit unquoted path vulnerabilities.

can identify the system language on a compromised host.

[MarkiRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0652) can use the "GetKeyboardLayout" API to check if a compromised host's keyboard is set to Persian.
[Cuba](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0625) can check if Russian language is installed on the infected machine by using the function "GetKeyboardLayoutList".

[Flagpro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0696) can check whether the target system is using Japanese, Taiwanese, or English through detection of specific Windows Security and Internet Explorer dialog.
[Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) can perform a check to ensure that the operating system's keyboard and language settings are not set to Russian.
[Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) queries the system's keyboard mapping to determine the language used on the system.
It will terminate execution if it detects LANG_RUSSIAN, LANG_BELARUSIAN, LANG_KAZAK, or LANG_UKRAINIAN.

Some versions of [DEATHRANSOM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0616) have performed language ID and keyboard layout checks; if either of these matched Russian, Kazakh, Belarusian, Ukrainian or Tatar [DEATHRANSOM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0616) would exit.

[Clop](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0611) has checked the keyboard language using the GetKeyboardLayout() function to avoid installation on Russian-language or other Commonwealth of Independent States-language machines; it will also check the "GetTextCharset" function.
[Ryuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0446) has been observed to query the registry key "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Nls\Language" and the value "InstallLanguage".
If the machine has the value 0x419 (Russian), 0x422 (Ukrainian), or 0x423 (Belarusian), it stops execution.
[XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658) uses AppleScript to check the host's language and location with the command "user locale of (get system info)".
[SharpStage](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0546) has been used to target Arabic-speaking users and used code that checks if the compromised machine has the Arabic language installed.
[Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) has attempted to detect if a compromised host had a Japanese keyboard via the Windows API call "GetKeyboardType".

[Spark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0543) has checked the results of the "GetKeyboardLayoutList" and the language name returned by "GetLocaleInfoA" to make sure they contain the word “Arabic” before executing.
[REvil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0496)
can check the system language using "GetUserDefaultUILanguage" and "GetSystemDefaultUILanguage".
If the language is found in the list, the process terminates.
[Avaddon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0640)
checks for specific keyboard layouts and OS languages to avoid targeting Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) entities.
[SynAck](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0242) lists all the keyboard layouts installed on the victim’s system using "GetKeyboardLayoutList" API and checks against a hardcoded language code list.
If a match if found, SynAck sleeps for 300 seconds and then exits without encrypting files.
[S-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0085) has attempted to determine if a compromised system was using a Japanese keyboard via the "GetKeyboardType" API call.
[Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) has used implants to collect the system language ID of a compromised machine.
[GrimAgent](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0632)
has used "Accept-Language" to identify hosts in the United Kingdom, United States, France, and Spain.
[Maze](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0449)
has checked the language of the machine with function "GetUserDefaultUILanguage" and terminated execution if the language matches with an entry in the predefined list.

The ensuing connection is a plaintext C2 channel in which commands are specified by DWORDs.

[NETWIRE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0198)
can use TCP in C2 communications.

[Clambling](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0660) has the ability to use TCP and UDP for communication.
Some variants of [FakeM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0076) use SSL to communicate with C2 servers.
An [APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) downloader establishes SOCKS5 connections for its initial C2.
[RCSession](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0662) has the ability to use TCP and UDP in C2 communications.
[Cryptoistic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0498)
can use TCP in communications with C2.
[SUGARUSH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1049)
has used TCP for C2.
[Bandook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0234) has a command built in to use a raw TCP socket.

[Nebulae](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0630) can use TCP in C2 communications.
[BITTER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1002) has used TCP for C2 communications.
[PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) can be configured to use raw TCP or UDP for command and control.
[RainyDay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0629) can use TCP in C2 communications.
The [PipeMon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0501) communication module can use a custom protocol based on TLS over TCP.
[PLATINUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0068) has used the Intel® Active Management Technology (AMT) Serial-over-LAN (SOL) channel for command and control.
[Umbreon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0221) provides access to the system via SSH or any other protocol that uses PAM to authenticate.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used Metasploit Bind and Reverse TCP stagers.
[KEYPLUG](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1051) can use TCP and KCP (KERN Communications Protocol) over UDP for C2 communication.
[Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) binds to a raw socket on a random source port between 31800 and 31900 for C2.
[SombRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0615) has the ability to use TCP sockets to send data and ICMP to ping the C2 server.
[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) can be configured to use TCP, ICMP, and UDP for C2 communications.
During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), threat actors used a custom protocol for command and control.
[BUBBLEWRAP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0043) can communicate using SOCKS.
[WINDSHIELD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0155) C2 traffic can communicate via TCP raw sockets.
[Winnti for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0430) has used ICMP, custom TCP, and UDP in outbound communications.

[RARSTONE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0055) uses SSL to encrypt its communication with its C2 server.

[HiddenWasp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0394)
communicates with a simple network protocol over TCP.
[Metador](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1013) has used TCP for C2.
[BackdoorDiplomacy](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0135) has used EarthWorm for network tunneling with a SOCKS5 server and port transfer functionalities.
[PHOREAL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0158) communicates via ICMP for C2.
[Bisonal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0268)
has used raw sockets for network communication.
[AuTo Stealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1029) can use TCP to communicate with command and control servers.
[TSCookie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0436) can use ICMP to receive information on the destination server.
[Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) is capable of using ICMP, TCP, and UDP for C2.
[FunnyDream](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1044) can communicate with C2 over TCP and UDP.
[BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has used steganography in multiple operations to conceal malicious payloads.
[RDAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0495) can also embed data within a BMP image prior to exfiltration.
[Earth Lusca](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1006) has used steganography to hide shellcode in a BMP image file.
[Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439)'s payload is encrypted and embedded within its loader, or within a legitimate PNG file.
[Raindrop](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0565) used steganography to locate the start of its encoded payload within legitimate 7-Zip code.
[TA551](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0127) has hidden encoded data for malware DLLs in a PNG.
[MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has stored obfuscated JavaScript code in an image file named temp.jpg.
[LiteDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0513) has used image files to hide its loader component.
[Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has used steganography to hide stolen data inside other files stored on Github.
During [Operation Ghost](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0023), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used steganography to hide payloads inside valid images.
[Andariel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0138) has hidden malicious executables within PNG files.
[PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) uses steganography to hide backdoors in PNG files, which are also encrypted using the Tiny Encryption Algorithm (TEA).
[build_downer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0471) can extract malware from a downloaded JPEG.
[IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483) has embedded binaries within RC4 encrypted .png files.
[Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) has PE data embedded within JPEG files contained within Word documents.
[ABK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0469) can extract a malicious Portable Executable (PE) from a photo.
[PolyglotDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0518) can use steganography to hide C2 information in images.
[ProLock](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0654) can use .jpg and .bmp files to store its payload.
[BBK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0470)
can extract a malicious Portable Executable (PE) from a photo.
[Diavol](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0659) has obfuscated its main code routines within bitmap images as part of its anti-analysis techniques.
[RegDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0511) can hide data in images, including use of the Least Significant Bit (LSB).
[Bandook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0234) has used .PNG images within a zip file to build the executable.
[ObliqueRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0644) can hide its payload in BMP images hosted on compromised websites.

For [Operation Spalax](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0005), the threat actors used packers that read pixel data from images contained in PE files' resource sections and build the next layer of execution from the data.
[Invoke-PSImage](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0231) can be used to embed a PowerShell script within the pixels of a PNG file.
[Avenger](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0473)
can extract backdoor malware from downloaded images.
[APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) uses steganography to send images to users that are embedded with shellcode.
[Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) has used JPG files with encrypted payloads to mask their backdoor routines and evade detection.
[FALLCHILL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0181) uses fake Transport Layer Security (TLS) to communicate with its C2 server.

[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) can mimic the HTTP protocol for C2 communication, while hiding the actual data in either an HTTP header, URI parameter, the transaction body, or appending it to the URI.
[Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) generates a false TLS handshake using a public certificate to disguise C2 network communications.

During [C0017](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0017), [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) frequently configured the URL endpoints of their stealthy passive backdoor LOWKEY.PASSIVE to masquerade as normal web application traffic on an infected server.
[FakeM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0076) C2 traffic attempts to evade detection by resembling data generated by legitimate messenger applications, such as MSN and Yahoo! messengers.
Additionally, some variants of [FakeM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0076) use modified SSL code for communications back to C2 servers, making SSL decryption ineffective.
[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can mimic HTTP protocol with custom HTTP “verbs” HIDE, ZVVP, and NOP.

[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware also uses a unique form of communication encryption known as FakeTLS that mimics TLS but uses a different encryption method, potentially evading SSL traffic inspection/decryption.
[KeyBoy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0387) uses custom SSL libraries to impersonate SSL in C2 traffic.
[BADCALL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0245) uses a FakeTLS method during C2.
[HARDRAIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0246) uses FakeTLS to communicate with its C2 server.
[SUNBURST](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0559) masqueraded its network traffic as the Orion Improvement Program (OIP) protocol.
[Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) mimics HTTP protocol for C2 communication, while hiding the actual messages in the Cookie and Set-Cookie headers of the HTTP requests.
[Higaisa](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0126) used a FakeTLS session for C2 communications.
[TAINTEDSCRIBE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0586) has used FakeTLS for session authentication.
[Brave Prince](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0252) gathers information about the Registry.
