[APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050)'s backdoor can query the Windows Registry to gather system information.
[Denis](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0354)
queries the Registry for keys and values.
[Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) executes the "reg query" command to obtain information in the Registry.
[ADVSTORESHELL](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0045) can enumerate registry keys.
[DownPaper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0186) searches and reads the value of the Windows Update Registry Run key.
[JPIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0201) can enumerate Registry keys.
[CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) provides access to the Windows Registry, which can be used to gather information.
[Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438) has opened the registry and performed query searches.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has obtained specific Registry keys and values on a compromised host.
[PcShare](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1050) can search the registry files of a compromised host.
[Dragonfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0035) has queried the Registry to identify victim information.
[PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) contains a collection of Privesc-PowerUp modules that can query Registry keys for potential opportunities.

[Pillowmint](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0517) has used shellcode which reads code stored in the registry keys "\REGISTRY\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\DRM" using the native Windows API as well as read "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\Tcpip\Parameters\Interfaces" as part of its C2.
[ZxxZ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1013) can search the registry of a compromised host.
[Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used [Reg](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0075) to query the Registry for installed programs.
[SodaMaster](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0627) has the ability to query the Registry to detect a key specific to VMware.
[BitPaymer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0570) can use the RegEnumKeyW to iterate through Registry keys.
[WINDSHIELD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0155) can gather Registry values.

[Bisonal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0268) has used the RegQueryValueExA function to retrieve proxy information in the Registry.
A [Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) tool can read and decrypt stored Registry values.
[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can enumerate Registry values, keys, and data.
[Woody RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1065) can search registry keys to identify antivirus programs on an compromised host.
[FunnyDream](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1044) can check "Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings" to extract the "ProxyServer" string.
[Valak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0476) can use the Registry for code updates and to collect credentials.
[Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) checks the system for certain Registry keys.

[SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) can use the "GetRegValue" function to check Registry keys within "HKCU\Software\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\Installer\AlwaysInstallElevated" and "HKLM\Software\Policies\Microsoft\Windows\Installer\AlwaysInstallElevated".
It also contains additional modules that can check software AutoRun values and use the Win32 namespace to get values from HKCU, HKLM, HKCR, and HKCC hives.
[PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) can enumerate and query for information contained within the Windows Registry.
[TinyTurla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0668) can query the Registry for its configuration information.
[BabyShark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0414) has executed the "reg query" command for "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Terminal Server Client\Default".
[Reg](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0075) may be used to gather details from the Windows Registry of a local or remote system at the command-line interface.
[FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) queries the Registry for specific keys for potential privilege escalation and proxy information.
[FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) has also used WMI to query the Windows Registry.
[Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) can query "Windows\CurrentVersion\Uninstall" for installed applications.
[Saint Bot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1018) has used "check_registry_keys" as part of its environmental checks.
[SUNBURST](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0559) collected the registry value "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Cryptography\MachineGuid" from compromised hosts.

[LiteDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0513) can query the Registry to check for the presence of "HKCU\Software\KasperskyLab".
[Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344) can check for installed software on the system under the Registry key "Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Uninstall".
[Milan](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1015)
can query "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Cryptography MachineGuid" to retrieve the machine GUID.
[SynAck](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0242) enumerates Registry keys associated with event logs.

[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) can query "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Office\<Excel Version>\Excel\Security\AccessVBOM\" to determine if the security setting for restricting default programmatic access is enabled.
[ZIRCONIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0128) has used a tool to query the Registry for proxy settings.
[REvil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0496) can query the Registry to get random file extensions to append to encrypted files.
[Carberp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0484) has searched the Image File Execution Options registry key for "Debugger" within every subkey.
[WastedLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0612) checks for specific registry keys related to the "UCOMIEnumConnections" and "IActiveScriptParseProcedure32" interfaces.
[Shark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1019) can query "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Cryptography MachineGuid" to retrieve the machine GUID.
[DarkWatchman](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0673)
can query the Registry to determine if it has already been installed on the system.

During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), the threat actors executed "/c cd /d c:\windows\temp\ & reg query HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\<username>\PuTTY\Sessions\" to detect recent PuTTY sessions, likely to further lateral movement.
[Stealth Falcon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0038) malware attempts to determine the installed version of .NET by querying the Registry.
[Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) queries several Registry keys to identify hard disk partitions to overwrite.
[POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may query the Registry by running "reg query" on a victim.
[Sibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0589) has queried the registry for proxy server information.
[Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) checks the Registry key "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings" for proxy configurations information.

[Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115) can check the Registry for the presence of "HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\last_edate" to determine how long it has been installed on a host.
[Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) checks for the existence of a Registry key and if it contains certain values.
[SVCReady](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1064) can search for the "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\HARDWARE\DESCRIPTION\System" Registry key to gather system information.

[Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) contains watchdog functionality that periodically ensures "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\WindowsNT\CurrentVersion\Windows\Load" is set to point to its executable.
[OSInfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0165) queries the registry to look for information about Terminal Services.
[BACKSPACE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0031) is capable of enumerating and making modifications to an infected system's Registry.
[gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) has checked for the existence of a Service key to determine if it has already been installed on the system.
[ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412)
can query the netsvc group value data located in the svchost group Registry key.
[FatDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0512) can get user agent strings for the default browser from "HKCU\Software\Classes\http\shell\open\command".
[Bumblebee](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1039)
can check the Registry for specific keys.
[Mafalda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1060) can enumerate Registry keys with all subkeys and values.
[Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) uses the "rem reg query" command to obtain values from Registry keys.
[Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) surveys a system upon check-in to discover information in the Windows Registry with the "reg query" command.
[Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has also retrieved PowerShell payloads hidden in Registry keys as well as checking keys associated with null session named pipes .
[ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) can check the default browser by querying "HKCR\http\shell\open\command".
[Lucifer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0532) can check for existing stratum cryptomining information in "HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\spreadCpuXmr – %stratum info%".

A variant of [HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) hooks lsass.exe, and lsass.exe then checks the Registry for the data value 'rdpproto' under the key "SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Lsa Name".
[LitePower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0680)
can query the Registry for keys added to execute COM hijacking.
[RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) uses the command "reg query “HKCU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\InternetSettings”".
[Waterbear](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0579) can query the Registry key ""HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\MSDTC\MTxOCI"" to see if the value "OracleOcilib" exists.
[StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380)
has looked in the registry to find the default browser path.
[Clambling](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0660) has the ability to enumerate Registry keys, including "KEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Bitcoin\Bitcoin-Qt\strDataDir" to search for a bitcoin wallet.
[OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used "reg query “HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Terminal Server Client\Default”" on a victim to query the Registry.

[Proxysvc](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0238) gathers product names from the Registry key: "HKLM\Software\Microsoft\WindowsNT\CurrentVersion ProductName" and the processor description from the Registry key "HKLM\HARDWARE\DESCRIPTION\System\CentralProcessor\0 ProcessorNameString".
[Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) searches the Registry for indicators of security programs.

[ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240) can access the "HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\mssmbios\Data\SMBiosData" Registry key to obtain the System manufacturer value to identify the machine type.
[FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) queries Registry values as part of its anti-sandbox checks.
[BendyBear](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0574) can query the host's Registry key at "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Console\QuickEdit" to retrieve data.

[Chimera](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0114) has queried Registry keys using "reg query \\<host>\HKU\<SID>\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Terminal Server Client\Servers" and "reg query \\<host>\HKU\<SID>\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Internet Settings".
[CharmPower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0674) has the ability to enumerate "Uninstall" registry values.
[Bankshot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0239) searches for certain Registry keys to be configured before executing the payload.
[Gold Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0249)
enumerates registry keys with the command "regkeyenum" and obtains information for the Registry key "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run".

[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware IndiaIndia checks Registry keys within HKCU and HKLM to determine if certain applications are present, including SecureCRT, Terminal Services, RealVNC, TightVNC, UltraVNC, Radmin, mRemote, TeamViewer, FileZilla, pcAnyware, and Remote Desktop.
Another [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware sample checks for the presence of the following Registry key:"HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Bitcoin\Bitcoin-Qt".
[APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has used various strains of malware to query the Registry.
[Reaver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0172) queries the Registry to determine the correct Startup path to use for persistence.
[Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) enumerates values in the Registry.
[Industroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0604) has a data wiper component that enumerates keys in the Registry "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services".
[Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203)
creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can retrieve system information, such as CPU speed, from Registry keys.
[Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) is capable of enumerating Registry keys and values.
[Taidoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0011) can query the Registry on compromised hosts using "RegQueryValueExA".
[POWERSOURCE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0145) queries Registry keys in preparation for setting Run keys to achieve persistence.
[TEARDROP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0560) checked that "HKU\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\CTF" existed before decoding its embedded payload.
[Dtrack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0567) can collect the RegisteredOwner, RegisteredOrganization, and InstallDate registry values.
[njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) can read specific registry values.
[Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) actors have split RAR files for exfiltration into parts.
[AppleSeed](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0622) has divided files if the size is 0x1000000 bytes or more.
The [Rclone](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1040) "chunker" overlay supports splitting large files in smaller chunks during upload to circumvent size limits.
[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) will break large data sets into smaller chunks for exfiltration.
[Mythic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0699) supports custom chunk sizes used to upload/download files.
[Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) exfiltrates data in compressed chunks if a message is larger than 4096 bytes .
[OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264)
exfiltrates command output and collected files to its C2 server in 1500-byte blocks.
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has split archived exfiltration files into chunks smaller than 1MB.
[Helminth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0170) splits data into chunks up to 23 bytes and sends the data in DNS queries to its C2 server.
[ObliqueRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0644) can break large files of interest into smaller chunks to prepare them for exfiltration.
[Kevin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1020) can exfiltrate data to the C2 server in 27-character chunks.
[LuminousMoth](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1014) has split archived files into multiple parts to bypass a 5MB limit.
[POSHSPY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0150) uploads data in 2048-byte chunks.
[RDAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0495) can upload a file via HTTP POST response to the C2 split into 102,400-byte portions.
[RDAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0495) can also download data from the C2 which is split into 81,920-byte portions.
During [C0015](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0015), the threat actors limited [Rclone](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1040)'s bandwidth setting during exfiltration.
[Kessel](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0487)
can split the data to be exilftrated into chunks that will fit in subdomains of DNS queries.

During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used stolen cookies to access cloud resources and a forged "duo-sid" cookie to bypass MFA set on an email account.
During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), threat actors used domain credentials, including domain admin, for lateral movement and privilege escalation.
[Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) has used domain administrator accounts after dumping LSASS process memory.
[Ryuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0446) can use stolen domain admin accounts to move laterally within a victim domain.
[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) can use known credentials to run commands and spawn processes as a domain user account.
If [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) cannot access shares using current privileges
, it attempts access using hard coded, domain-specific credentials gathered earlier in the intrusion.
[Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) has used administrative accounts, including Domain Admin, to move laterally within a victim network.
During [Operation CuckooBees](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0012), the threat actors used compromised domain administrator credentials as part of their lateral movement.
[Chimera](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0114) has used compromised domain accounts to gain access to the target environment.
[Threat Group-1314](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0028) actors used compromised domain credentials for the victim's endpoint management platform, Altiris, to move laterally.
For [Operation Ghost](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0023), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used stolen administrator credentials for lateral movement on compromised networks.
[TA505](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092) has used stolen domain admin accounts to compromise additional hosts.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) uses valid accounts after gaining credentials for use within the victim domain.
[Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) attempts to access network resources with a domain account’s credentials.
[Naikon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0019) has used administrator credentials for lateral movement in compromised networks.
[Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) has used stolen credentials to access administrative accounts within the domain.
During [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0002), threat actors used domain accounts to gain further access to victim systems.
[Indrik Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0119) has collected credentials from infected systems, including domain accounts.

During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used domain administrators' accounts to help facilitate lateral movement on compromised networks.
[CreepySnail](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1024) can use stolen credentials to authenticate on target networks.
[Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) has dropped RegAsm.exe onto systems for performing malicious activity.

[Hikit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0009) uses "certmgr.exe -add GlobalSign.cer -c -s -r localMachine Root" and "certmgr.exe -add GlobalSign.cer -c -s -r localMachineTrustedPublisher" to install a self-generated certificate to the local trust store as a root CA and Trusted Publisher.
[RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) can add a certificate to the Windows store.

[certutil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0160) can be used to install browser root certificates as a precursor to performing [Adversary-in-the-Middle](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1557) between connections to banking websites.
Example command: "certutil -addstore -f -user ROOT ProgramData\cert512121.der".

[Dok](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0281) installs a root certificate to aid in [Adversary-in-the-Middle](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1557) actions using the command "add-trusted-cert -d -r trustRoot -k /Library/Keychains/System.keychain /tmp/filename".

[Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) temporarily disrupted service to Georgian government, non-government, and private sector websites after compromising a Georgian web hosting provider in 2019.
[OnionDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0052) has the capability to use a Denial of Service module.
[ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412) has a feature to perform SYN flood attack on a host.
[FoggyWeb](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0661)
can compile and execute source code sent to the compromised AD FS server via a specific HTTP POST.
[MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069) has used the .NET csc.exe tool to compile executables from downloaded C# code.
[njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385) has used AutoIt to compile the payload and main script into a single executable after delivery.
[DarkWatchman](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0673) has used the "csc.exe" tool to compile a C# executable.
[Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) and its watchdog component are compiled and executed after being delivered to victims as embedded, uncompiled source code.
[Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) has compiled the source code for a downloader directly on the infected system using the built-in "Microsoft.CSharp.CSharpCodeProvider" class.
[Rocke](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0106) has compiled malware, delivered to victims as .c files, with the GNU Compiler Collection (GCC).
[Amadey](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1025) does not run any tasks or install additional malware if the victim machine is based in Russia.
[QuasarRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0262) can determine the country a victim host is located in.
Before executing malicious code, [Ragnar Locker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0481) checks the Windows API "GetLocaleInfoW" and doesn't encrypt files if it finds a former Soviet country.
[SideCopy](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1008) has identified the country location of a compromised host.
[GrimAgent](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0632) can identify the country code on a compromised host.
[Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115) can identify the geographical location of a victim host.
[SDBbot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0461) can collected the country code of a compromised machine.
[Saint Bot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1018) has conducted system locale checks to see if the compromised host is in Russia, Ukraine, Belarus, Armenia, Kazakhstan, or Moldova.
[DarkWatchman](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0673)
can identity the OS locale of a compromised host.
[Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has used [BITSAdmin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0190) to download additional tools.
[APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has used the BITS protocol to exfiltrate stolen data from a compromised host.
[Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) has been downloaded via Windows BITS functionality.
[BITSAdmin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0190) can be used to create [BITS Jobs](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1197) to launch a malicious process.
[ProLock](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0654) can use BITS jobs to download its malicious payload.
A [JPIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0201) variant downloads the backdoor payload via the BITS service.
[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) can download a hosted "beacon" payload using [BITSAdmin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0190).
[Egregor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0554) has used BITSadmin to download and execute malicious DLLs.

[UBoatRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0333) takes advantage of the /SetNotifyCmdLine option in [BITSAdmin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0190) to ensure it stays running on a system to maintain persistence.
[MarkiRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0652) can use BITS Utility to connect with the C2 server.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used [BITSAdmin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0190) to download and install payloads.
[Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) has used BITS jobs to download malicious payloads.
[Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) can use built-in modules to abuse trusted utilities like MSBuild.exe.
During [Frankenstein](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0001), the threat actors used MSbuild to execute an actor-created file.
A version of [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) loads as shellcode within a .NET Framework project using msbuild.exe, presumably to bypass application control techniques.
[Mythic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0699) supports domain fronting via custom request headers.
[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) has the ability to accept a value for HTTP Host Header to enable domain fronting.
[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has used the meek domain fronting plugin for [Tor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0183) to hide the destination of C2 traffic.
[SMOKEDHAM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0649) has used a fronted domain to obfuscate its hard-coded C2 server domain.

[meek](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0175) uses Domain Fronting to disguise the destination of network traffic as another server that is hosted in the same Content Delivery Network (CDN) as the intended destination.
[LuminousMoth](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1014) has used ARP spoofing to redirect a compromised machine to an actor-controlled website.
[Cleaver](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0003) has used custom tools to facilitate ARP cache poisoning.
[Bumblebee](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1039)
can identify specific analytical tools based on running processes.
[Flame](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0143)
identifies security software such as antivirus through the Security module.
[Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) can identify the installed antivirus engine.

[ThiefQuest](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0595) uses the "kill_unwanted" function to get a list of running processes, compares each process with an encrypted list of “unwanted” security related programs, and kills the processes for security related programs.
[Skidmap](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0468) has the ability to check if "/usr/sbin/setenforce" exists.
This file controls what mode SELinux is in.
[POWRUNER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0184) may collect information on the victim's anti-virus software.
[Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091) searches for anti-malware services running on the victim’s machine and terminates itself if it finds them.
[SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) can determine if an anti-virus product is installed through the resolution of the service's virtual SID.
[Clop](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0611) can search for processes with antivirus and antimalware product names.
[FunnyDream](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1044)
can identify the processes for Bkav antivirus.
[PUNCHBUGGY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0196)
can gather AVs registered in the system.
[Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) can enumerate antivirus software on the target.
[Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) enumerates the currently running processes related to a variety of security products.
[Ferocious](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0679) has checked for AV software as part of its persistence process.
[Tasklist](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0057)
can be used to enumerate security software currently running on a system by process name of known products.
[POWERSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0223) has detected security tools.
The main [CozyCar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0046) dropper checks whether the victim has an anti-virus product installed.
If the installed product is on a predetermined list, the dropper will exit.
[Avenger](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0473) has the ability to identify installed anti-virus products on a compromised host.
[YAHOYAH](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0388) checks for antimalware solution processes on the system.
[Rocke](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0106) used scripts which detected and uninstalled antivirus software.
[Gold Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0249) checks for anti-malware products and processes.
[NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) determines if specific antivirus programs are running on an infected host machine.
[StrongPity](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0491) can identify if ESET or BitDefender antivirus are installed before dropping its payload.
[down_new](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0472) has the ability to detect anti-virus products and processes on a compromised host.
[Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has obtained information on security software, including security logging information that may indicate whether their malware has been detected.
[Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115) contains a command to collect information about anti-virus software on the victim.
[Carberp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0484)
has queried the infected system's registry searching for specific registry keys associated with antivirus products.
[MoleNet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0553)
can use WMI commands to check the system for firewall and antivirus software.
[BLUELIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0657) can collect a list of anti-virus products installed on a machine.
[Mafalda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1060) can search for a variety of security software programs, EDR systems, and malware analysis tools.
[PipeMon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0501) can check for the presence of ESET and Kaspersky security software.
[Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) checks for the presence of Avast antivirus in the "C:\Program\Files\" folder.
[Waterbear](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0579) can find the presence of a specific security software.
[FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) checks for installed security software like antivirus and firewall.
[Metamorfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0455) collects a list of installed antivirus software from the victim’s system.

[CookieMiner](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0492) has checked for the presence of "Little Snitch", macOS network monitoring and application firewall software, stopping and exiting if it is found.
[Windshift](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0112) has used malware to identify installed AV and commonly used forensic and malware analysis tools.
[Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) can detect EDR userland hooks.
[Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) checks to see if anti-virus, anti-spyware, or firewall products are installed in the victim’s environment.
[ZxxZ](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1013) can search a compromised host to determine if it is running Windows Defender or Kasperky antivirus.
[Naikon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0019) uses commands such as "netsh advfirewall firewall" to discover local firewall settings.
[Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) has used WMI to identify anti-virus products installed on a victim's machine.
[FlawedAmmyy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0381) will attempt to detect anti-virus products during the initial infection.
[Aquatic Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0143) has attempted to discover third party endpoint detection and response (EDR) tools on compromised systems.
[jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) can list security software, such as by using WMIC to identify anti-virus products installed on the victim’s machine and to obtain firewall details.
During [Frankenstein](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0001), the threat actors used WMI queries to determine if analysis tools were running on a compromised system.
[Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125)
has a plugin detect security products via active drivers.
[RogueRobin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0270)
enumerates running processes to search for Wireshark and Windows Sysinternals suite.
[SideCopy](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1008) uses a loader DLL file to collect AV product names from an infected host.
[ABK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0469) has the ability to identify the installed anti-virus product on the compromised host.
[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can check for the presence of network sniffers, AV, and BitDefender firewall.
[Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) can check for the presence of specific security products.
[Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) has searched for anti-malware strings and anti-virus processes running on the system.
[T9000](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0098) performs checks for various antivirus and security products during installation.
[Sidewinder](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0121) has used the Windows service "winmgmts:\\.\root\SecurityCenter2" to check installed antivirus products.
During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), threat actors used scripts to detect security software.
[Cobalt Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0080) used a JavaScript backdoor that is capable of collecting a list of the security solutions installed on the victim's machine.
[Valak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0476)
can determine if a compromised host has security products installed.
[RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) can obtain information about security software on the victim.
[XCSSET](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0658)
searches firewall configuration files located in "/Library/Preferences/" and uses "csrutil status" to determine if System Integrity Protection is enabled.
[xCaon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0653) has checked for the existence of Kaspersky antivirus software on the system.

[Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) scanned the “Program Files” directories for a directory with the string “Total Security” (the installation path of the “360 Total Security” antivirus tool).
[build_downer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0471) has the ability to detect if the infected host is running an anti-virus process.
[Comnie](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0244) attempts to detect several anti-virus products.
[WhisperGate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0689) can recognize the presence of monitoring tools on a target system.
[LiteDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0513) has the ability to check for the presence of Kaspersky security software.
[JPIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0201)
checks for the presence of certain security-related processes and deletes its installer/uninstaller component if it identifies any of them.
[Mosquito](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0256)'s installer searches the Registry and system to see if specific antivirus tools are installed on the system.
[Meteor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0688) has the ability to search for Kaspersky Antivirus on a victim's machine.
[APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) has identified security software, configurations, defensive tools, and sensors installed on a compromised system.
[QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650)
can identify the installed antivirus product on a targeted system.
[AuTo Stealer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1029)
has the ability to collect information about installed AV products from an infected host.
[Micropsia](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0339) searches for anti-virus software and firewall products installed on the victim’s machine using WMI.

[The White Company](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0089) has checked for specific antivirus products on the target’s computer, including Kaspersky, Quick Heal, AVG, BitDefender, Avira, Sophos, Avast!, and ESET.
[Lizar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0681) can search for processes associated with an anti-virus product from list.
[BadPatch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0337)
uses WMI to enumerate installed security products in the victim’s environment.
[FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) probes the system to check for antimalware processes.
[EVILNUM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0568) can search for anti-virus products on the system.
[netsh](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0108) can be used to discover system firewall settings.
[Woody RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1065) can detect Avast Software, Doctor Web, Kaspersky, AVG, ESET, and Sophos antivirus programs.
[Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176) checks for the presence of Bitdefender security software.
[StreamEx](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0142) has the ability to scan for security tools such as firewalls and antivirus tools.
A module in [Prikormka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0113) collects information from the victim about installed anti-virus software.
[DarkTortilla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1066)
can check for the Kaspersky Anti-Virus suite.
[MarkiRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0652)
can check for running processes on the victim’s machine to look for Kaspersky and Bitdefender antivirus products.
[VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) uses WMI to check for anti-virus software installed on the system.
[FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has used Registry keys to detect and avoid executing in potential sandboxes.
[MuddyWater](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0069)
has used malware to check running processes against a hard-coded list of security tools often used by malware researchers.
[TajMahal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0467) has the ability to identify which anti-virus products, firewalls, and anti-spyware products are in use.
[Amadey](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1025)
has checked for a variety of antivirus products.
[CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) checks for antivirus and forensics software.

[Action RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1028) can identify AV products on an infected host using the following command: "cmd.exe WMIC /Node:localhost /Namespace:\\root\SecurityCenter2 Path AntiVirusProduct Get displayName /Format:List".
[DustySky](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0062) checks for the existence of anti-virus.
[Netwalker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0457)
can detect and terminate active security software-related processes on infected systems.
[Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) can search for anti-virus software running on the system.
[Felismus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0171) checks for processes associated with anti-virus vendors.
[More_eggs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0284) can obtain information on installed anti-malware programs.
[EvilBunny](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0396)
has been observed querying installed antivirus software.
[DarkWatchman](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0673)
can search for anti-virus products on the system.
[SUNBURST](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0559) checked for a variety of antivirus/endpoint detection agents prior to execution.
[SpicyOmelette](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0646) can check for the presence of 29 different antivirus tools.
[Kasidet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0088) has the ability to identify any anti-virus installed on the infected system.
[LitePower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0680) can identify installed AV software.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has checked for the presence of antivirus software with "powershell Get-CimInstance -Namespace root/securityCenter2 – classname antivirusproduct".
[Grandoreiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0531)
can list installed security products including the Trusteer and Diebold Warsaw GAS Tecnologia online banking protections.
[StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380) can check for antivirus and antimalware programs.
[TeamTNT](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0139) has searched for security products on infected machines.
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has used the WindowStyle parameter to conceal [PowerShell](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1059/001) windows.
[StrongPity](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0491) has the ability to hide the console window for its document search module from the user.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has used an information gathering module that will hide an AV software window from the victim.
[Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) droppers have used COM properties to execute malware in hidden windows.
[Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047) has used "hidcon" to run batch files in a hidden console window.

During [Operation Dream Job](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0022), [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) targeted specific individuals within an organization with tailored job vacancy announcements.

[Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386) has used encoded data in HTTP URLs for C2.
[Mythic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0699) provides various transform functions to encode and/or randomize C2 data.
After encrypting C2 data, [BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) converts it into a hexadecimal representation and then encodes it into base64.
[Linux Rabbit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0362) sends the payload from the C2 server as an encoded URL parameter.
[H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) obfuscates C2 traffic with an altered version of base64.
[Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) can insert itself into the address space of other applications using the AppInit DLL Registry key.
[APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has used malware to set "LoadAppInit_DLLs" in the Registry key "SOFTWARE\Microsoft\WindowsNT\CurrentVersion\Windows" in order to establish persistence.

If a victim meets certain criteria, [T9000](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0098) uses the AppInit_DLL functionality to achieve persistence by ensuring that every user mode process that is spawned will load its malicious DLL, ResN32.dll.

It does this by creating the following Registry keys: "HKLM\Software\Microsoft\WindowsNT\CurrentVersion\Windows\AppInit_DLLs – %APPDATA%\Intel\ResN32.dll" and "HKLM\Software\Microsoft\WindowsNT\CurrentVersion\Windows\LoadAppInit_DLLs – 0x1".

Some variants of [Cherry Picker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0107) use AppInit_DLLs to achieve persistence by creating the following Registry key: "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\WindowsNT\CurrentVersion\Windows "AppInit_DLLs"="pserver32.dll""

[Green Lambert](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0690) can create a [Launch Agent](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1543/001) with the "RunAtLoad" key-value pair set to "true", ensuring the "com.apple.GrowlHelper.plist" file runs every time a user logs in.
[ThiefQuest](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0595) installs a launch item using an embedded encrypted launch agent property list template.
The plist file is installed in the "~/Library/LaunchAgents/" folder and configured with the path to the persistent binary located in the "~/Library/" folder.

The [Komplex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0162) trojan creates a persistent launch agent called with "$HOME/Library/LaunchAgents/com.apple.updates.plist" with "launchctl load -w ~/Library/LaunchAgents/com.apple.updates.plist".
[MacMa](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1016) installs a "com.apple.softwareupdate.plist" file in the "/LaunchAgents" folder with the "RunAtLoad" value set to "true".
Upon user login, [MacMa](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1016) is executed from "/var/root/.local/softwareupdate" with root privileges.
Some variations also include the "LimitLoadToSessionType" key with the value "Aqua", ensuring the [MacMa](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1016) only runs when there is a logged in GUI user.

An [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) loader Trojan uses a cmd.exe and batch script to run its payload.

[Carbanak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0030) has a command to create a reverse shell.

creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can open a command line interface.

[Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) is capable of providing shell functionality to the attacker to execute commands.

can launch a remote shell to execute commands on the victim’s machine.

[Ryuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0446) has used "cmd.exe" to create a Registry entry to establish persistence.
[KEYMARBLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0271) can execute shell commands using cmd.exe.
[cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106) is used to execute programs and other actions at the command-line interface.
[DarkWatchman](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0673) can use "cmd.exe" to execute commands.

[TDTESS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0164) provides a reverse shell on the victim.
[DnsSystem](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1021) can use "cmd.exe" for execution.
[StreamEx](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0142) has the ability to remotely execute commands.
[Remcos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0332) can launch a remote command line to execute commands on the victim’s machine.

can use its implementation of [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) to obtain and use silver tickets.

[MCMD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0500) has the ability to remove set Registry Keys, including those used for persistence.

can use a .NET compiled module named exchgrabber to enumerate credentials from the Credential Manager.

[KillDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0607) deletes system files to make the OS unbootable.

also targets and deletes files with 35 different file extensions.
[RawDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0364
) was used in [Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) to write to protected system locations such as the MBR and disk partitions in an effort to destroy data.

[HermeticWiper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0697) can recursively wipe folders and files in "Windows", "Program Files", "Program Files(x86)", "PerfLogs", "Boot, System", "Volume Information", and "AppData" folders using "FSCTL_MOVE_FILE".

Newer variants of [BACKSPACE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0031) will encode C2 communications with a custom system.

During [C0010](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0010), UNC3890 actors likely established a watering hole that was hosted on a login page of a legitimate Israeli shipping company that was active until at least November 2021.
[Earth Lusca](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1006) has performed watering hole attacks.

[Elderwood](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0066) has delivered zero-day exploits and malware to victims by injecting malicious code into specific public Web pages visited by targets within a particular sector.
[APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067)
has used strategic web compromises, particularly of South Korean websites, to distribute malware.
The group has also used torrent file-sharing sites to more indiscriminately disseminate malware to victims.
As part of their compromises, the group has used a Javascript based profiler called RICECURRY to profile a victim's web browser and deliver malicious code accordingly.
[Bundlore](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0482) has been spread through malicious advertisements on websites.
[Bad Rabbit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0606) spread through watering holes on popular sites by injecting JavaScript into the HTML body or a ".js" file.

[Transparent Tribe](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0134) has used websites with malicious hyperlinks and iframes to infect targeted victims with [Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115), [njRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0385), and other malicious tools.
[Dark Caracal](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0070) used a watering hole to serve up malicious code.
[Grandoreiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0531)
has used compromised websites and Google Ads to bait victims into downloading its installer.
[BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) compromised three Japanese websites using a Flash exploit to perform watering hole attacks.
[Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0095) has distributed [Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) through a fake blog website.
[Andariel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0138) has used watering hole attacks, often with zero-day exploits, to gain initial access to victims within a specific IP range.
[RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0048) has distributed its malware via the RIG and SUNDOWN exploit kits, as well as online advertising network "Yandex.Direct".
[Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) has used watering holes to deliver files with exploits to initial victims.
[Windshift](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0112) has used compromised websites to register custom URL schemes on a remote system.
[REvil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0496)
has infected victim machines through compromised websites and exploit kits.
[Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has infected victims using watering holes.
[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) delivered [RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) and other malicious code to victims via a compromised legitimate website.
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has compromised targets via strategic web compromise utilizing custom exploit kits.
[APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has infected victims by tricking them into visiting compromised watering hole websites.
[KARAE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0215) was distributed through torrent file-sharing websites to South Korean victims, using a YouTube video downloader application as a lure.
[Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has extensively used strategic web compromises to target victims.
[Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) has conducted watering-hole attacks through media and magazine websites.
[APT19](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0073) performed a watering hole attack on forbes.com in 2014 to compromise targets.
[Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has infected victims using watering holes.
[POORAIM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0216)
has been delivered through compromised sites acting as watering holes.
[Axiom](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0001) has used watering hole attacks to gain access.
[PLATINUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0068) has sometimes used drive-by attacks against vulnerable browser plugins.

During [Operation Dust Storm](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0016), the threat actors used a watering hole attack on a popular software reseller to exploit the then-zero-day Internet Explorer vulnerability CVE-2014-0322.
[Windigo](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0124) has distributed Windows malware via drive-by downloads.
[Dragonfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0035) has compromised targets via strategic web compromise (SWC) utilizing a custom exploit kit.
In 2016, [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) conducted a distributed denial of service (DDoS) attack against the World Anti-Doping Agency.
[Lucifer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0532) can execute TCP, UDP, and HTTP denial of service (DoS) attacks.
[AADInternals](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0677) can execute commands on Azure virtual machines using the VM agent.
[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has used Azure Run Command and Azure Admin-on-Behalf-of (AOBO) to execute code on virtual machines.

During [AppleJeus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0584)'s installation process, it uses "postinstall" scripts to extract a hidden plist from the application's "/Resources" folder and execute the "plist" file as a [Launch Daemon](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1543/004) with elevated permissions.
[TeamTNT](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0139) has scanned specific lists of target IP addresses.
[Dragonfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0035) has injected SMB URLs into malicious Word spearphishing attachments to initiate [Forced Authentication](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1187).
During [Operation Dream Job](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0022), [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) used DOCX files to retrieve a malicious document template/DOTM file.
[WarzoneRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0670) has been install via template injection through a malicious DLL embedded within a template RTF in a Word document.
During [Frankenstein](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0001), the threat actors used trojanized documents that retrieved remote templates from an adversary-controlled website.
[Confucius](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0142) has used a weaponized Microsoft Word document with an embedded RTF exploit.

[DarkHydrus](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0079) used an open-source tool, Phishery, to inject malicious remote template URLs into Microsoft Word documents and then sent them to victims to enable [Forced Authentication](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1187).

[Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) delivered malicious documents with the XLSX extension, typically used by OpenXML documents, but the file itself was actually an OLE (XLS) document.
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) used weaponized Microsoft Word documents abusing the remote template function to retrieve a malicious macro.

[Chaes](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0631) changed the template target of the settings.xml file embedded in the Word document and populated that field with the downloaded URL of the next payload.
[Inception](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0100) has used decoy documents to load malicious remote payloads via HTTP.
[Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047)
has used DOCX files to download malicious DOT document templates and has used RTF template injection to download malicious payloads.
[Gamaredon Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0047)
can also inject malicious macros or remote templates into documents already present on compromised systems.
[iKitten](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0278) adds an entry to the rc.common file for persistence.
[Cyclops Blink](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0687) has the ability to execute on device startup, using a modified RC script named S51armled.
[Green Lambert](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0690) can add "init.d" and "rc.d" files in the "/etc" folder to establish persistence.
[HiddenWasp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0394) installs reboot persistence by adding itself to "/etc/rc.local".
[Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) can use [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194)'s "Invoke-TokenManipulation" to manipulate access tokens.
[PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) can use Invoke-TokenManipulation for manipulating tokens.
[Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) can use token manipulation to bypass UAC on Windows7 systems.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used has used Metasploit’s named-pipe impersonation technique to escalate privileges.
[Ryuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0446) has attempted to adjust its token privileges to have the "SeDebugPrivilege".
[SUNSPOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0562) modified its security token to grants itself debugging privileges by adding "SeDebugPrivilege".

[HermeticWiper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0697) can use "AdjustTokenPrivileges" to grant itself privileges for debugging with "SeDebugPrivilege", creating backups with "SeBackupPrivilege", loading drivers with "SeLoadDriverPrivilege", and shutting down a local system with "SeShutdownPrivilege".
[AppleSeed](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0622) can gain system level privilege by passing "SeDebugPrivilege" to the "AdjustTokenPrivilege" API.
[Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) examines running system processes for tokens that have specific system privileges.
If it finds one, it will copy the token and store it for later use.
Eventually it will start new processes with the stored token attached.
It can also steal tokens to acquire administrative privileges.
[BlackCat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1068) has the ability modify access tokens.
[Mafalda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1060) can use "AdjustTokenPrivileges()" to elevate privileges.
[PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194)'s "Invoke-TokenManipulation" Exfiltration module can be used to manipulate tokens.
[SslMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0058) contains a feature to manipulate process privileges and tokens.
[Sliver](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0633) has the ability to manipulate user tokens on targeted Windows systems.
[Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203)
creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can adjust token privileges.

During [C0017](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0017), [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used a ConfuserEx obfuscated BADPOTATO exploit to abuse named-pipe impersonation for local "NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM" privilege escalation.
[KillDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0607) has attempted to get the access token of a process by calling "OpenProcessToken".
If [KillDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0607) gets the access token, then it attempt to modify the token privileges with "AdjustTokenPrivileges".
[MegaCortex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0576)
can enable "SeDebugPrivilege" and adjust token privileges.
[Blue Mockingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0108) has used JuicyPotato to abuse the "SeImpersonate" token privilege to escalate from web application pool accounts to NT Authority\SYSTEM.
[Cuba](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0625) has used "SeDebugPrivilege" and "AdjustTokenPrivileges" to elevate privileges.
[Chimera](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0114) has registered alternate phone numbers for compromised users to intercept 2FA codes sent via SMS.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has used a proprietary tool to intercept one time passwords required for two-factor authentication.
[LAPSUS$](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1004) has replayed stolen session token and passwords to trigger simple-approval MFA prompts in hope of the legitimate user will grant necessary approval.
During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), threat actors used a custom collection method to intercept two-factor authentication soft tokens.

[Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) is known to contain functionality that enables targeting of smart card technologies to proxy authentication for connections to restricted network resources using detected hardware tokens.
[HotCroissant](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0431) has used the open source UPX executable packer.
[TA505](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092) has used UPX to obscure malicious code.
[SysUpdate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0663) has been packed with VMProtect.
[OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) uses the SmartAssembly obfuscator to pack an embedded .Net Framework assembly used for C2.
[NETWIRE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0198) has used .NET packer tools to evade detection.
[Elderwood](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0066) has packed malware payloads before delivery to victims.
[Aoqin Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1007) has used the Themida packer to obfuscate malicious payloads.
[HyperBro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0398) has the ability to pack its payload.
[Tomiris](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0671) has been packed with UPX.
During [C0017](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0017), [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used VMProtect to slow the reverse engineering of malicious binaries.

During the [2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0025), [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) used UPX to pack a copy of [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002).
[Squirrelwaffle](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1030) has been packed with a custom packer to hide payloads.
[jRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0283) payloads have been packed.
[DRATzarus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0694)'s dropper can be packed with UPX.
[Ember Bear](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1003) has packed malware to help avoid detection.
[GALLIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0093) packed some payloads using different types of packers, both known and custom.
[Spark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0543) has been packed with Enigma Protector to obfuscate its contents.
[Dark Caracal](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0070) has used UPX to pack [Bandook](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0234).
Versions of [Babuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0638) have been packed.
[Saint Bot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1018) has been packed using a dark market crypter.
[APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) has used several code packing methods such as Themida, Enigma, VMProtect, and Obsidium, to pack their implants.
[SDBbot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0461) has used a packed installer file.
[Misdat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0083) was typically packed using UPX.
For [Operation Dust Storm](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0016), the threat actors used UPX to pack some payloads.
[KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) has been packed for obfuscation.
[AppleSeed](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0622) has used UPX packers for its payload DLL.
[Rocke](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0106)'s miner has created UPX-packed files in the Windows Start Menu Folder.
A [FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) variant uses a custom packer.
[Dok](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0281) is packed with an UPX executable packer.
[SeaDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0053) has been packed with the UPX packer.
[Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367)
has used custom packers to protect its payloads.
[H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) uses a custom packing algorithm.
[Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) has been packed with NSIS.
[GreyEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0342) is packed for obfuscation.
[The White Company](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0089)
has obfuscated their payloads through packing.
[Torisma](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0678) has been packed with Iz4 compression.
[VERMIN](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0257) is initially packed.
[Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251)'s Delphi variant was packed with UPX.
[OSX_OCEANLOTUS.D](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0352) has a variant that is packed with UPX.
[Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) uses a software packer called Pe123\RPolyCryptor.
[Egregor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0554)'s payloads are custom-packed, archived and encrypted to prevent analysis.
[Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024) has been delivered with encrypted resources and must be unpacked for execution.
[GoldMax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0588) has been packed for obfuscation.
A version of [Daserf](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0187) uses the MPRESS packer.
Some [S-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0085) samples have been packed with UPX.
[Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) has a variant with a packed payload.
[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used UPX to pack files.
[Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has packed malware and tools, including using VMProtect.
[TeamTNT](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0139) has used UPX and Ezuri packer to pack its binaries.
[Lokibot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0447) has used several packing methods for obfuscation.
[APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has packed tools with UPX, and has repacked a modified version of [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) to thwart anti-virus detection.
[Cuba](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0625)
has a packed payload when delivered.
[IcedID](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0483)
has packed and encrypted its loader module.
[LiteDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0513) has been packed with multiple layers of encryption.
Some [ZeroT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0230) DLL files have been packed with UPX.
[Valak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0476) has used packed DLL payloads.
[Mongall](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1026) has been packed with Themida.
[Lucifer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0532) has used UPX packed binaries.
[Trojan.Karagany](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0094) samples sometimes use common binary packers such as UPX and Aspack on top of a custom Delphi binary packer.
During [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0002), threat actors used software packing in its tools.
[APT3](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0022) has been known to pack their tools.
[Uroburos](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0022) uses a custom packer.
[QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650)
can encrypt and pack malicious payloads.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has packed malware with UPX.

[Melcoz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0530) has been packed with VMProtect and Themida.

[FYAnti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0628) has used ConfuserEx to pack its .NET module.
[CSPY Downloader](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0527) has been packed with UPX.
For [Operation Spalax](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0005), the threat actors used a variety of packers, including CyaX, to obfuscate malicious executables.
During [Operation Dream Job](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0022), [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) packed malicious .db files with Themida to evade detection.

[Anchor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0504) has come with a packed payload.
[yty](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0248) packs a plugin with UPX.
A [Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) payload was packed with UPX.

[TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266)
uses a custom packer to obfuscate its functionality.
[Metamorfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0455)
has used VMProtect to pack and protect files.
[Clop](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0611) has been packed to help avoid detection.

has been regularly repacked by its operators to create large binaries and evade detection.
[CostaBricks](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0614) can implement a custom-built virtual machine mechanism to obfuscate its code.
[Donut](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0695) can generate packed code modules.

) uses HTTP requests for C2.

uses HTTP for C2.

[Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) can ping or traceroute a remote host.

During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), threat actors used "nbtscan" and "ping" to discover remote systems, as well as "dsquery subnet" on a domain controller to retrieve all subnets in the Active Directory.

[HermeticWizard](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0698) can find machines on the local network by gathering known local IP addresses through "DNSGetCacheDataTable", "GetIpNetTable","WNetOpenEnumW(RESOURCE_GLOBALNET, RESOURCETYPE_ANY)","NetServerEnum","GetTcpTable", and "GetAdaptersAddresses."
[Rocke](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0106) has looked for IP addresses in the known_hosts file on the infected system and attempted to SSH into them.
[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) uses the native Windows Network Enumeration APIs to interrogate and discover targets in a Windows Active Directory network.
[Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) has used network scanning and enumeration tools, including [Ping](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0097).
During [C0015](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0015), the threat actors used the commands "net view /all /domain" and "ping" to discover remote systems.
They also used PowerView's PowerShell Invoke-ShareFinder script for file share enumeration.
[Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) can enumerate remote systems using " Net View".

[Earth Lusca](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1006) used the command "powershell “Get-EventLog -LogName security -Newest 500 | where {$_.EventID -eq 4624} | format-list - property * | findstr “Address””" to find the network information of successfully logged-in accounts to discovery addresses of other machines.
[Earth Lusca](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1006) has also used multiple scanning tools to discover other machines within the same compromised network.
[Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) uses [Windows Management Instrumentation](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1047) to enumerate all systems in the network.

[Aria-body](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0456) has the ability to download additional payloads from C2.

has downloaded additional files, including an exploit for used privilege escalation.
[Skidmap](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0468) has the ability to download files on an infected host.
[Kevin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1020) can download files to the compromised host.
[Volgmer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0180) can download remote files and additional payloads to the victim's machine.
[Neoichor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0691)
can download additional files onto a compromised host.
[BITSAdmin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0190) can be used to create [BITS Jobs](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1197) to upload and/or download files.
During [C0010](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0010), UNC3890 actors downloaded tools and malware onto a compromised host.
During [Frankenstein](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0001), the threat actors downloaded files and tools onto a victim machine.

[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has used a compromised global administrator account in Azure AD to backdoor a service principal with "ApplicationImpersonation" rights to start collecting emails from targeted mailboxes.
[Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) granted compromised email accounts read access to the email boxes of additional targeted accounts.
The group then was able to authenticate to the intended victim's OWA (Outlook Web Access) portal and read hundreds of email communications for information on Middle East organizations.

During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) added their own devices as allowed IDs for active sync using "Set-CASMailbox", allowing it to obtain copies of victim mailboxes.
It also added additional permissions (such as Mail.Read and Mail.ReadWrite) to compromised Application or Service Principals.
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has used a Powershell cmdlet to grant the "ApplicationImpersonation" role to a compromised account.

During [Operation Dream Job](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0022), [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) used code signing certificates issued by Sectigo RSA for some of its malware and tools.
[Ember Bear](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1003) has stolen legitimate certificates to sign malicious payloads.
[BlackTech](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0098) has used stolen code-signing certificates for its malicious payloads.
[Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) has obtained stolen valid certificates, including from VMProtect and the Chinese instant messaging application Youdu, for their operations.
[Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) obtained a code signing certificate signed by Digicert for some of its malware.
[MegaCortex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0576)
has used code signing certificates issued to fake companies to bypass security controls.

[Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) can hash then resolve API calls at runtime.

[AvosLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1053) has used obfuscated API calls that are retrieved by their checksums.
[Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) can call and dynamically resolve hashed APIs.

[Imminent Monitor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0434) has a module for performing remote desktop access.
[Revenge RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0379) has a plugin to perform RDP access.

During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used RDP sessions from public-facing systems to internal servers.

has used Remote Desktop Protocol for lateral movement.

An [APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) loader Trojan adds the Registry key "HKCU\Environment\UserInitMprLogonScript" to establish persistence.

[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can create hidden system directories.

[CoinTicker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0369) downloads the following hidden files to evade detection and maintain persistence: /private/tmp/.info.enc, /private/tmp/.info.py, /private/tmp/.server.sh, ~/Library/LaunchAgents/.espl.plist, ~/Library/Containers/.[random string]/[random string].

[Carberp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0484) has created a hidden file in the Startup folder of the current user.

) saves itself with a leading "." so that it's hidden from users by default.

saves itself with a leading "." to make it a hidden file.

[ThiefQuest](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0595) hides a copy of itself in the user's "~/Library" directory by using a "." at the beginning of the file name followed by 9 random characters.
[Rocke](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0106) downloaded a file "libprocesshider", which could hide files on the target system.

SecretsDump and [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) modules within [Impacket](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0357) can perform credential dumping to obtain account and password information from NTDS.dit.
[Chimera](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0114) has gathered the SYSTEM registry and ntds.dit files from target systems.
[Chimera](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0114)

specifically has used the NtdsAudit tool to dump the password hashes of domain users via "msadcs.exe "NTDS.dit" -s "SYSTEM" -p RecordedTV_pdmp.txt --users-csv RecordedTV_users.csv" and used ntdsutil to copy the Active Directory database.
[Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) can gather hashed passwords by gathering domain controller hashes from NTDS.
[Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) has used "ntdsutil.exe" to back up the Active Directory database, likely for credential access.
[menuPass](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0045) has used Ntdsutil to dump credentials.
[Fox Kitten](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0117) has used Volume Shadow Copy to access credential information from NTDS.
[HAFNIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0125) has stolen copies of the Active Directory database (NTDS.DIT).
[LAPSUS$](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1004) has used Windows built-in tool "ntdsutil" to extract the Active Directory (AD) database.
[Mustang Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0129) has used vssadmin to create a volume shadow copy and retrieve the NTDS.dit file.
[Mustang Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0129) has also used "reg save" on the SYSTEM file Registry location to help extract the NTDS.dit file.
[Dragonfly](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0035) has dropped and executed SecretsDump to dump password hashes.
They also obtained ntds.dit from domain controllers.
[Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) has gained access to credentials via exported copies of the ntds.dit Active Directory database.

[esentutl](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0404) can use Volume Shadow Copy to copy locked files such as ntds.dit.
[Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) has used NTDSDump and other password dumping tools to gather credentials.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used Metasploit’s [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) NTDSGRAB module to obtain a copy of the victim's Active Directory database.
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has used the ntdsutil.exe utility to export the Active Directory database for credential access.
