[FIN4](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0085) has lured victims to click malicious links delivered via spearphishing emails (often sent from compromised accounts).
[Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) can gain execution after a user clicks on a malicious link to decoy landing pages hosted on Google Docs.
[Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) has relied upon users clicking on a malicious link delivered through spearphishing.
During [C0011](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0011), [Transparent Tribe](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0134) relied on student targets to click on a malicious link sent via email.
[OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has delivered malicious links to achieve execution on the target system.
[Melcoz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0530) has gained execution through victims opening malicious links.
[Pony](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0453) has attempted to lure targets into clicking links in spoofed emails from legitimate banks.
[Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has sent spearphishing email links attempting to get a user to click.
[Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used spearphishing via a link to get users to download and run their malware.
[Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) has tricked unwitting recipients into clicking on malicious hyperlinks within emails crafted to resemble trustworthy senders.
[Kerrdown](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0585) has gained execution through victims opening malicious links.
[Grandoreiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0531) has used malicious links to gain execution on victim machines.
During [C0021](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0021), the threat actors lured users into clicking a malicious link which led to the download of a ZIP archive containing a malicious .LNK file.
[APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has lured targets to download a Cobalt Strike beacon by including a malicious link within spearphishing emails.
[NETWIRE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0198) has been executed through convincing victims into clicking malicious links.
[SMOKEDHAM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0649) has relied upon users clicking on a malicious link delivered through phishing.
During [Operation Spalax](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0005), the threat actors relied on a victim to click on a malicious link distributed via phishing emails.
[APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has sent spearphishing emails in an attempt to lure users to click on a malicious link.
[Hancitor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0499) has relied upon users clicking on a malicious link delivered through phishing.

During [Operation Dream Job](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0022), [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) lured users into executing a malicious link to disclose private account information or provide initial access.
During [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0002), threat actors enticed users to click on links in spearphishing emails to download malware.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has lured victims into clicking malicious links.
[Bumblebee](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1039) has relied upon a user downloading a file from a OneDrive link for execution.
[Javali](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0528) has achieved execution through victims clicking links to malicious websites.
[KOCTOPUS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0669) has relied on victims clicking on a malicious link delivered via email.
[Molerats](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0021) has sent malicious links via email trick users into opening a RAR archive and running an executable.
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has used several malicious applications that abused OAuth access tokens to gain access to target email accounts, including Gmail and Yahoo Mail.

During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used compromised service principals to make changes to the Office 365 environment.
[Peirates](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0683) can use stolen service account tokens to perform its operations.
It also enables adversaries to switch between valid service accounts.
[CreepyDrive](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1023) can use legitimate OAuth refresh tokens to authenticate with OneDrive.
[Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176) drops a malicious file (sspisrv.dll) alongside a copy of lsass.exe, which is used to register a service that loads sspisrv.dll as a driver.
The payload of the malicious driver (located in its entry-point function) is executed when loaded by lsass.exe before the spoofed service becomes unstable and crashes.
[Pasam](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0208) establishes by infecting the Security Accounts Manager (SAM) DLL to load a malicious DLL dropped to disk.
[Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) utilizes [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) to help propagate itself across a network.
[Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) uses [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) to execute a payload or commands on a remote host.
[HermeticWizard](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0698) can use "OpenRemoteServiceManager" to create a service.
The "net start" and "net stop" commands can be used in [Net](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0039) to execute or stop Windows services.
[WhisperGate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0689) can download and execute AdvancedRun.exe via "sc.exe".
[ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412)
can create a new service for execution.
[Proxysvc](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0238) registers itself as a service on the victim’s machine to run as a standalone process.
[StrongPity](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0491) can install a service to execute itself as a service.
[BBSRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0127) can start, stop, or delete services.
During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), threat actors created services on remote systems for execution purposes.
[Blue Mockingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0108) has executed custom-compiled XMRIG miner DLLs by configuring them to execute via the "wercplsupport" service.
[Mafalda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1060)
can create a remote service, let it run once, and then delete it.
[PoshC2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0378) contains an implementation of [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) for remote execution.
[Hydraq](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0203) uses svchost.exe to execute a malicious DLL included in a new service group.
[HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has used svchost.exe to execute a malicious DLL .
[Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) can use [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) to execute a payload on a remote host.

[Net Crawler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0056) uses [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) to perform remote service manipulation to execute a copy of itself as part of lateral movement.
[Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) has used services.exe to execute scripts and executables during lateral movement within a victim network.
[Chimera](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0114) has used [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) to deploy beacons on compromised systems.
[Silence](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0091) has used [Winexe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0191) to install a service on the remote system.
[Pandora](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0664) has the ability to install itself as a Windows service.
[SysUpdate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0663) can manage services and processes.
[Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) has used a tool known as RemoteExec (similar to [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029)) to remotely execute batch scripts and binaries.
Operators deploying [Netwalker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0457) have used psexec and certutil to retrieve the [Netwalker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0457) payload.
[LoudMiner](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0451) started the cryptomining virtual machine as a service on the infected machine.
[xCmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0123) can be used to execute binaries on remote systems by creating and starting a service.
[Wingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0176) uses services.exe to register a new autostart service named "Audit Service" using a copy of the local lsass.exe file.
[SLOTHFULMEDIA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0533) has the capability to start services.
[APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050)'s backdoor has used Windows services as a way to execute its malicious payload.
[Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439)'s loader can create a new service named NtmsSvc to execute the payload.
[APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) has used post-exploitation tools including RemCom and the Non-sucking Service Manager (NSSM) to execute processes.
[TinyTurla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0668) can install itself as a service on compromised machines.
[Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) can run a command on another machine using [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029).
[Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) creates a new service named “ntssrv” to execute the payload.
[Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) can also spread via [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029).
[APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) has created new services or modified existing ones to run executables, commands, or scripts.
Microsoft Sysinternals [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) is a popular administration tool that can be used to execute binaries on remote systems using a temporary Windows service.
[HyperBro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0398) has the ability to start and stop a specified service.
[Ragnar Locker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0481) has used sc.exe to execute a service that it creates.
[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) can use [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) to execute a payload on a remote host.
It can also use Service Control Manager to start new services.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has created Windows services to execute encoded PowerShell commands.
[Clambling](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0660) can create and start services on a compromised host.
[NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) can use [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) to help propagate itself across a network.
[Winexe](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0191) installs a service on the remote system, executes the command, then uninstalls the service.
[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) has used Windows services as a way to execute its malicious payload.
[Impacket](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0357
) contains various modules emulating other service execution tools such as [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029).
[Anchor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0504)
can create and execute services to load its payload.
[Winnti for Windows](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0141) can run as a service using svchost.exe.

During [Operation Honeybee](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0006), threat actors ran "sc start" to start the COMSysApp as part of the service hijacking and "sc stop" to stop and reconfigure the COMSysApp.
[HermeticWiper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0697) can create system services to aid in executing the payload.
[WastedLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0612) can execute itself as a service.
[gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) can execute its service if the Service key exists.
If the key does not exist, [gh0st RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0032) will create and run the service.
[Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) can create Windows system services for execution.
[Pysa](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0583) has used [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) to copy and execute the ransomware.
[Attor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0438)'s dispatcher can be executed as a service.

[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used svchost.exe and [Net](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0039) to execute a system service installed to launch a [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) BEACON loader.
[Bad Rabbit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0606) drops a file named "infpub.dat"into the Windows directory and is executed through SCManager and "rundll.exe".
[RemoteCMD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0166)
can execute commands remotely by creating a new service on the remote system.
[APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has used compromised Office 365 accounts in tandem with [Ruler](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0358) in an attempt to gain control of endpoints.

During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used a compromised O365 administrator account to create a new Service Principal.
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has used compromised Office 365 service accounts with Global Administrator privileges to collect email from user inboxes.
[Ke3chang](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0004) has used compromised credentials to sign into victims’ Microsoft 365 accounts.
[LAPSUS$](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1004) has used compromised credentials to access cloud assets within a target organization.
[ROADTools](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0684) uses valid cloud credentials to perform enumeration operations using the internal Azure AD Graph API.
[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has gained access to a global administrator account in Azure AD.
[Peirates](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0683) can use stolen service account tokens to perform its operations.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096)
has encrypted payloads using the Data Protection API (DPAPI), which relies on keys tied to specific user accounts on specific machines.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096)
has also environmentally keyed second stage malware with an RC5 key derived in part from the infected system's volume serial number.

[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can use Data Protection API to encrypt its components on the victim’s computer, to evade detection, and to make sure the payload can only be decrypted and loaded on one specific compromised computer.
[Equation](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0020) has been observed utilizing environmental keying in payload delivery.
[PowerPunch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0685) can use the volume serial number from a target host to generate a unique XOR key for the next stage payload.
[ROKRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0240)
relies on a specific victim hostname to execute and decrypt important strings.

The [Winnti for Windows](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0141) dropper component can verify the existence of a single command line parameter and either terminate if it is not found or later use it as a decryption key.
[S-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0085) primarily uses port 80 for C2, but falls back to ports 443 or 8080 if initial communication fails.
[FatDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0512) has used several C2 servers per targeted organization.
[Linfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0211)
creates a backdoor through which remote attackers can change C2 servers.

[Mis-Type](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0084) first attempts to use a Base64-encoded network protocol over a raw TCP socket for C2, and if that method fails, falls back to a secondary HTTP-based protocol to communicate to an alternate C2 server.
[NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) will attempt to detect if the infected host is configured to a proxy.
If so, [NETEAGLE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0034) will send beacons via an HTTP POST request; otherwise it will send beacons via UDP/6000.
[Machete](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0409) has sent data over HTTP if FTP failed, and has also used a fallback server.
[Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) has the ability to generate new C2 domains.
[BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089)
has the capability to communicate over a backup channel via plus.google.com.
[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) has been configured with several servers available for alternate C2 communications.
[HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376) has multiple C2 channels in place in case one fails.
[RDAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0495)
has used HTTP if DNS C2 communications were not functioning.

[JHUHUGIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0044) tests if it can reach its C2 server by first attempting a direct connection, and if it fails, obtaining proxy settings and sending the connection through a proxy, and finally injecting code into a running browser if the proxy method fails.
[QUADAGENT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0269) uses multiple protocols (HTTPS, HTTP, DNS) for its C2 server as fallback channels if communication with one is unsuccessful.
[BISCUIT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0017) malware contains a secondary fallback command and control server that is contacted after the primary command and control server.
[Valak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0476)
can communicate over multiple C2 hosts.
[Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) has the ability to use an alternative C2 server if the primary server fails.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used the Steam community page as a fallback mechanism for C2.
[WinMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0059) is usually configured with primary and backup domains for C2 communications.
[AppleSeed](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0622)
can use a second channel for C2 when the primary channel is in upload mode.
[Kevin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1020) can assign hard-coded fallback domains for C2.

[TAINTEDSCRIBE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0586) can randomly pick one of five hard-coded IP addresses for C2 communication; if one of the IP fails, it will wait 60 seconds and then try another IP address.
[ShimRat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0444)
has used a secondary C2 location if the first was unavailable.
[Crutch](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0538) has used a hardcoded GitHub repository as a fallback channel.
[CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) can switch to a new C2 channel if the current one is broken.
[DustySky](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0062) has two hard-coded domains for C2 servers; if the first does not respond, it will try the second.
[Bumblebee](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1039) can use backup C2 servers if the primary server fails.
[Cardinal RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0348) can communicate over multiple C2 host and port combinations.
[Shark](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1019) can update its configuration to use a different C2 server.
[TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266)
can use secondary C2 servers for communication after establishing connectivity and relaying victim information to primary C2 servers.
[Kwampirs](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0236) uses a large list of C2 servers that it cycles through until a successful connection is established.
[Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) can use multiple domains and protocols in C2.
[Anchor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0504) can use secondary C2 servers for communication after establishing connectivity and relaying victim information to primary C2 servers.
[OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) malware ISMAgent falls back to its DNS tunneling mechanism if it is unable to reach the C2 server over HTTP.
[MiniDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0051) uses Google Search to identify C2 servers if its primary C2 method via Twitter is not working.
[SslMM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0058) has a hard-coded primary and backup C2 string.
[Mythic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0699) can use a list of C2 URLs as fallback mechanisms in case one IP or domain gets blocked.
[Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) has implemented a fallback mechanism to begin using a DGA when the attacker hasn't connected to the infected system for three days.
[Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) uses a backup communication method with an HTTP beacon.
[PipeMon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0501) can switch to an alternate C2 domain when a particular date has been reached.
[SideTwist](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0610) has primarily used port 443 for C2 but can use port 80 as a fallback.
[Exaramel for Linux](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0401) can attempt to find a new C2 server if it receives an error.
[CharmPower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0674) can change its C2 channel once every 360 loops by retrieving a new domain from the actors’ S3 bucket.
[Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) can accept multiple URLs for C2 servers.
[RainyDay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0629) has the ability to switch between TCP and HTTP for C2 if one method is not working.
During [Night Dragon](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0002), threat actors used company extranet servers as secondary C2 servers.

[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware SierraAlfa sends data to one of the hard-coded C2 servers chosen at random, and if the transmission fails, chooses a new C2 server to attempt the transmission again.
[FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046)'s Harpy backdoor malware can use DNS as a backup channel for C2 if HTTP fails.
The C2 server used by [XTunnel](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0117) provides a port number to the victim to use as a fallback in case the connection closes on the currently used port.
[TinyTurla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0668) can go through a list of C2 server IPs and will try to register with each until one responds.
[Valak](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0476) has the ability save and execute files as alternate data streams (ADS).
[Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) can abuse alternate data streams (ADS) to store content for malicious payloads.
[WastedLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0612) has the ability to save and execute files as an alternate data stream (ADS).
[APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) used NTFS alternate data streams to hide their payloads.
[esentutl](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0404) can be used to read and write alternate data streams.
[Expand](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0361) can be used to download or copy a file into an alternate data stream.
[BitPaymer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0570)
has copied itself to the ":bin" alternate data stream of a newly created file.
Some variants of the [Zeroaccess](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0027) Trojan have been known to store data in Extended Attributes.
[PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139)
hides many of its backdoor payloads in an alternate data stream (ADS).
[LoJax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0397)
has loaded an embedded NTFS DXE driver to be able to access and write to NTFS partitions.
The [Regin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0019) malware platform uses Extended Attributes to store encrypted executables.

If the victim is using PowerShell 3.0 or later, [POWERSOURCE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0145) writes its decoded payload to an alternate data stream (ADS) named kernel32.dll that is saved in "%PROGRAMDATA%\Windows\".
The DEADEYE.EMBED variant of [DEADEYE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1052) can embed its payload in an alternate data stream of a local file.
[Gazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0168) stores configuration items in alternate data streams (ADSs) if the Registry is not accessible.
[Anchor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0504) has used NTFS to hide files.
[PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194)'s "Invoke-Kerberoast" module can request service tickets and return crackable ticket hashes.
[Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363)
uses [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194)'s "Invoke-Kerberoast" to request service tickets and return crackable ticket hashes.
[Impacket](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0357) modules like GetUserSPNs can be used to get Service Principal Names (SPNs) for user accounts.
The output is formatted to be compatible with cracking tools like John the Ripper and Hashcat.
[Rubeus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1071) can use the "KerberosRequestorSecurityToken.GetRequest" method to request kerberoastable service tickets.

During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), threat actors used [PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194)'s "Invoke-Kerberoast" module to request encrypted service tickets and bruteforce the passwords of Windows service accounts offline.
[SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) contains a module to conduct Kerberoasting.

During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) obtained Ticket Granting Service (TGS) tickets for Active Directory Service Principle Names to crack offline.
[Brute Ratel C4](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1063) can decode Kerberos 5 tickets and convert it to hashcat format for subsequent cracking.
[Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) has used Rubeus, MimiKatz Kerberos module, and the Invoke-Kerberoast cmdlet to steal AES hashes.
[FIN7](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0046) has used Kerberoasting for credential access and to enable lateral movement.
[Earth Lusca](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1006) has used a "DCSync" command with [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) to retrieve credentials from an exploited controller.

During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used privileged accounts to replicate directory service data with domain controllers.

During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), threat actors used [Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002)'s DCSync to dump credentials from the memory of the targeted system.

[Mimikatz](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0002) performs credential dumping to obtain account and password information useful in gaining access to additional systems and enterprise network resources.
It contains functionality to acquire information about credentials in many ways, including from DCSync/NetSync.
[LAPSUS$](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1004) has used DCSync attacks to gather credentials for privilege escalation routines.
[Crimson](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0115) has the ability to determine the date and time on a compromised host.
[Chimera](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0114) has used "time /t" and "net time \\ip/hostname" for system time discovery.

[GoldMax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0588) can check the current date-time value of the compromised system, comparing it to the hardcoded execution trigger and can send the current timestamp to the C2 server.
[build_downer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0471) has the ability to determine the local time to ensure malware installation only happens during the hours that the infected system is active.
[Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) can collect the timestamp from the victim’s machine.
[AppleSeed](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0622)
can pull a timestamp from the victim's machine.
[FunnyDream](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1044)
can check system time to help determine when changes were made to specified files.
[NOKKI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0353) can collect the current timestamp of the victim's machine.
A Destover-like implant used by [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) can obtain the current system time and send it to the C2 server.
[BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has used "net time" to check the local time on a target system.
[SombRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0615)
can execute "getinfo" to discover the current time on a compromised host.
[Epic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0091)
uses the "net time" command to get the system time from the machine and collect the current date and time zone information.
During [Operation CuckooBees](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0012), the threat actors used the "net time" command as part of their advanced reconnaissance.
During [C0015](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0015), the threat actors used the command "net view /all time" to gather the local time of a compromised network.
During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), threat actors used the "time" command to retrieve the current time of a compromised system.
[EvilBunny](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0396)
has used the API calls NtQuerySystemTime, GetSystemTimeAsFileTime, and GetTickCount to gather time metrics as part of its checks to see if the malware is running in a sandbox.
[Metamorfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0455) uses JavaScript to get the system time.
[StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380)
can obtain the current date and time of the victim machine.
[ShadowPad](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0596) has collected the current date and time of the victim system.
[SVCReady](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1064) can collect time zone information.
[Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) surveys a system upon check-in to discover the system time by using the "net time" command.
[ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) has checked the victim system's date and time to perform tasks during business hours (9 to 5, Monday to Friday).
[Okrum](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0439) can obtain the date and time of the compromised system.
[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) gathers the local system time from the victim’s machine.
[Torisma](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0678) can collect the current time on a victim machine.
[Conficker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0608)
uses the current UTC victim system date for domain generation and connects to time servers to determine the current date.
[Bazar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0534) can collect the time on the compromised host.
[Egregor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0554) contains functionality to query the local/system time.
[Green Lambert](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0690) can collect the date and time from a compromised host.
[SHARPSTATS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0450) has the ability to identify the current date and time on the compromised host.
[AvosLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1053) has checked the system time before and after encryption.
[MoonWind](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0149) obtains the victim's current time.
As part of the data reconnaissance phase, [Proxysvc](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0238) grabs the system time to send back to the control server.
[RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) can obtain the victim time zone.
[Grandoreiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0531)
can determine the time on the victim machine via IPinfo.
[Taidoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0011) can use "GetLocalTime" and "GetSystemTime" to collect system time.
[Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) collects the timestamp from the infected machine.
[TAINTEDSCRIBE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0586) can execute "GetLocalTime" for time discovery.
[ccf32](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1043) can determine the local time on targeted machines.
[Azorult](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0344)
can collect the time zone information from the system.
[Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) obtains the system time and will only activate if it is greater than a preset date.
[UPPERCUT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0275) has the capability to obtain the time zone information and current timestamp of the victim’s machine.
[DarkWatchman](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0673) can collect the time zone information from the system.
[OopsIE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0264) checks to see if the system is configured with "Daylight" time and checks for a specific region to be set for the timezone.
[DRATzarus](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0694) can use the "GetTickCount" and "GetSystemTimeAsFileTime" API calls to inspect system time.
[KEYPLUG](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1051) can obtain the current tick count of an infected computer.
[HOPLIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0376)
has been observed collecting system time from victim machines.
[Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) collects the current system time (UTC) and sends it back to the C2 server.
[Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) uses the command "net time \\127.0.0.1" to get information the system’s time.
[Cannon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0351)
can collect the current time zone information from the victim’s machine.
[BLUELIGHT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0657) can collect the local time on a compromised host.
[PowerDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0139) has commands to get the time the machine was built, the time, and the time zone.
[Sidewinder](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0121) has used tools to obtain the current system time.
[T9000](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0098) gathers and beacons the system time during installation.
[Darkhotel](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0012) malware can obtain system time from a compromised host.
[Higaisa](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0126) used a function to gather the current time.
[The White Company](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0089)
has checked the current date on the victim system.
[Clambling](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0660) can determine the current time.
[DCSrv](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1033) can compare the current time on an infected host with a configuration value to determine when to start the encryption process.
[BendyBear](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0574) has the ability to determine local time on a compromised host.
[WindTail](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0466) has the ability to generate the current date and time.
[GRIFFON](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0417) has used a reconnaissance module that can be used to retrieve the date and time of the system.
[PipeMon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0501)
can send time zone information from a compromised host to C2.
[Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) collects the time and date of a system when it is infected.
[FELIXROOT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0267) gathers the time zone information from the victim’s machine.
[ZIRCONIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0128) has used a tool to capture the time on a compromised host in order to register it with C2.
[TajMahal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0467) has the ability to determine local time on a compromised host.
[QakBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0650)
can identify the system time on a targeted host.
[Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) gathers the current time zone and date information from the system.
[SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) can collect start time information from a compromised host.
[StrifeWater](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1034)
can collect the time zone from the victim's machine.
[GravityRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0237)
can obtain the date and time of a system.
The "net time" command can be used in [Net](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0039) to determine the local or remote system time.
[Bisonal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0268)
can check the system time set on the infected host.

[APT18](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0026) actors used the native [at](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0110) Windows task scheduler tool to use scheduled tasks for execution on a victim network.
[BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060) has used [at](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0110) to register a scheduled task to execute malware during lateral movement.
[CrackMapExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0488) can set a scheduled task on the target system to execute commands remotely using [at](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0110).
[MURKYTOP](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0233) has the capability to schedule remote AT jobs.
[at](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0110)
can be used to schedule a task on a system to be executed at a specific date or time.

[Threat Group-3390](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0027) actors use [at](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0110) to schedule tasks to run self-extracting RAR archives, which install [HTTPBrowser](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0070) or [PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) on other victims on a network.
[Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) has injected malicious DLLs into memory with read, write, and execute permissions.
[PipeMon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0501) can inject its modules into various processes using reflective DLL loading.
[BackdoorDiplomacy](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0135) has dropped legitimate software onto a compromised host and used it to execute malicious DLLs.

[IronNetInjector](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0581) has the ability to inject a DLL into running processes, including the [IronNetInjector](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0581) DLL into explorer.exe.

The [FunnyDream](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1044) FilepakMonitor component can inject into the Bka.exe process using the "VirtualAllocEx", "WriteProcessMemory" and "CreateRemoteThread" APIs to load the DLL component.
[Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125) can perform DLL injection.
[DarkTortilla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1066)
can use a .NET-based DLL named "RunPe6" for process injection.
[Koadic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0250) can perform process injection by using a reflective DLL.
[SombRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0615) can execute "loadfromfile", "loadfromstorage", and "loadfrommem" to inject a DLL from disk, storage, or memory respectively.
[Emissary](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0082) injects its DLL file into a newly spawned Internet Explorer process.
If running in a Windows environment, [Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) saves a DLL to disk that is injected into the explorer.exe process to execute the payload.
[Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) can also be configured to inject and execute within specific processes.
[Dyre](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0024) injects into other processes to load modules.
[PoisonIvy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0012)
can inject a malicious DLL into a process.
[Pupy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0192) can migrate into another process using reflective DLL injection.
[Sykipot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0018) injects itself into running instances of outlook.exe, iexplore.exe, or firefox.exe.
The [Bumblebee](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1039) loader can support the "Dij" command which gives it the ability to inject DLLs into the memory of other processes.
[TajMahal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0467) has the ability to inject DLLs for malicious plugins into running processes.
[FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) injects itself into various processes depending on whether it is low integrity or high integrity.
[Elise](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0081) injects DLL files into iexplore.exe.
During [C0015](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0015), the threat actors used a DLL named "D8B3.dll" that was injected into the Winlogon process.
[Conti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0575) has loaded an encrypted DLL into memory and then executes it.
[Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has used Metasploit to perform reflective DLL injection in order to escalate privileges.
[RATANKBA](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0241) performs a reflective DLL injection using a given pid.
[Ramsay](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0458) can use "ImprovedReflectiveDLLInjection" to deploy components.
[Leviathan](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0065) has utilized techniques like reflective DLL loading to write a DLL into memory and load a shell that provides backdoor access to the victim.
[Lizar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0681) has used the PowerKatz plugin that can be loaded into the address space of a PowerShell process through reflective DLL loading.
[SDBbot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0461) has the ability to inject a downloaded DLL into a newly created rundll32.exe process.
The [Netwalker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0457) DLL has been injected reflectively into the memory of a legitimate running process.
[Carberp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0484)'s bootkit can inject a malicious DLL into the address space of running processes.
[MegaCortex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0576) loads "injecthelper.dll" into a newly created "rundll32.exe" process.
[Aria-body](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0456) has the ability to inject itself into another process such as rundll32.exe and dllhost.exe.
[Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367)
has been observed injecting in to Explorer.exe and other processes.
[BlackEnergy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0089)
injects its DLL component into svchost.exe.
[Mongall](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1026) can inject a DLL into "rundll32.exe" for execution.
[Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335) has a command to inject code into a process.
[Get2](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0460) has the ability to inject DLLs into processes.
[Socksbot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0273)
creates a suspended svchost process and injects its DLL into it.
[Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) has injected a DLL backdoor into dllhost.exe and svchost.exe.
[Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) injects an entire DLL into an existing, newly created, or preselected trusted process.
[ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412)
is injected into a shared SVCHOST process.
[Heyoka Backdoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1027) can inject a DLL into rundll32.exe for execution.
[Derusbi](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0021) injects itself into the secure shell (SSH) process.
[ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) has injected its orchestrator DLL into explorer.exe.

[ComRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0126) has also injected its communications module into the victim's default browser to make C2 connections appear less suspicious as all network connections will be initiated by the browser process.

An executable dropped onto victims by [Putter Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0024) aims to inject the specified DLL into a process that would normally be accessing the network, including Outlook Express (msinm.exe), Outlook (outlook.exe), Internet Explorer (iexplore.exe), and Firefox (firefox.exe).
[Maze](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0449)
has injected the malware DLL into a target process.
[Metamorfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0455) has injected a malicious DLL into the Windows Media Player process (wmplayer.exe).
[Gelsemium](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0666) has the ability to inject DLLs into specific processes.
[Saint Bot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1018) has injected its DLL component into "EhStorAurhn.exe".
[ShadowPad](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0596) has injected a DLL into svchost.exe.
[Matryoshka](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0167) uses reflective DLL injection to inject the malicious library and execute the RAT.
[PowerSploit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0194) contains a collection of CodeExecution modules that inject code (DLL, shellcode) into a process.
A [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware sample performs reflective DLL injection.
[TA505](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0092) has been seen injecting a DLL into winword.exe.
[HIDEDRV](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0135) injects a DLL for [Downdelph](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0134) into the explorer.exe process.
[Taidoor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0011)
can perform DLL loading.
[PS1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0613) can inject its payload DLL Into memory.
[Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) will inject itself into different processes to evade detection.

The selection of the target process is influenced by the security software that is installed on the system (Duqu will inject into different processes depending on which security suite is installed on the infected host).
After decrypting itself in memory, [RARSTONE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0055) downloads a DLL file from its C2 server and loads it in the memory space of a hidden Internet Explorer process.
This “downloaded” file is actually not dropped onto the system.
[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) has the ability to load DLLs via reflective injection.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has obtained exploit code for various CVEs.
[Ebury](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0377) can intercept private keys using a trojanized "ssh-add" function.
[Kessel](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0487) has trojanized the <sode>ssh_login" and "user-auth_pubkey" functions to steal plaintext credentials.
[SILENTTRINITY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0692) can create a backdoor in KeePass using a malicious config file and in TortoiseSVN using a registry hook.
[PLATINUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0068) is capable of using Windows hook interfaces for information gathering such as credential access.
[ZxShell](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0412)
hooks several API functions to spawn system threads.
[TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) has the ability to capture RDP credentials by capturing the "CredEnumerateA" API
[NOKKI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0353) uses the Windows call SetWindowsHookEx and begins injecting it into every GUI process running on the victim's machine.
[Zeus Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0330) hooks processes by using its own IAT hooked functions.
[RDFSNIFFER](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0416)
hooks several Win32 API functions to hijack elements of the remote system management user-interface.
[Carberp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0484) has hooked several Windows API functions to steal credentials.
[Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) contains some modules that use API hooking to carry out tasks, such as netripper.
[Ursnif](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0386)
has hooked APIs to perform a wide variety of information theft, such as monitoring traffic from browsers.

[Zebrocy](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0251) installs an application-defined Windows hook to get notified when a network drive has been attached, so it can then use the hook to call its RecordToFile file stealing method.
[FinFisher](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0182) hooks processes by modifying IAT pointers to CreateWindowEx.
[Bad Rabbit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0606) has used an executable that installs a modified bootloader to prevent normal boot-up.
[TrickBot](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0266) module "Trickboot" can write or erase the UEFI/BIOS firmware of a compromised device.
[FIVEHANDS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0618)
has the ability to delete volume shadow copies on compromised hosts.
[MegaCortex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0576) has deleted volume shadow copies using "vssadmin.exe".

[Prestige](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1058) can delete the backup catalog from the target system using: "c:\Windows\System32\wbadmin.exe delete catalog -quiet" and can also delete volume shadow copies using: "\Windows\System32\vssadmin.exe delete shadows /all /quiet".
[ProLock](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0654) can use vssadmin.exe to remove volume shadow copies.

[BlackCat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1068) can delete shadow copies using "vssadmin.exe delete shadows /all /quiet" and "wmic.exe Shadowcopy Delete"; it can also modify the boot loader using "bcdedit /set {default} recoveryenabled No".
[Pysa](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0583) has the functionality to delete shadow copies.
[Diavol](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0659) can delete shadow copies using the "IVssBackupComponents" COM object to call the "DeleteSnapshots" method.
[Conti](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0575) can delete Windows Volume Shadow Copies using "vssadmin".
[Ragnar Locker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0481) can delete volume shadow copies using "vssadmin delete shadows /all /quiet".
[DarkWatchman](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0673) can delete shadow volumes using "vssadmin.exe".
[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can can remove all system restore points.

[Ryuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0446) has used "vssadmin Delete Shadows /all /quiet" to to delete volume shadow copies and "vssadmin resize shadowstorage" to force deletion of shadow copies created by third-party applications.
[Clop](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0611)
can delete the shadow volumes with "vssadmin Delete Shadows /all /quiet" and can use bcdedit to disable recovery options.
[DEATHRANSOM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0616) can delete volume shadow copies on compromised hosts.
[Netwalker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0457)
can delete the infected system's Shadow Volumes to prevent recovery.
[Conficker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0608) resets system restore points and deletes backup files.
[Babuk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0638) has the ability to delete shadow volumes using "vssadmin.exe delete shadows /all /quiet".
[REvil](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0496) can use vssadmin to delete volume shadow copies and bcdedit to disable recovery features.
[BitPaymer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0570) attempts to remove the backup shadow files from the host using "vssadmin.exe Delete Shadows /All /Quiet".
[Avaddon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0640)
deletes backups and shadow copies using native system tools.
[Maze](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0449)
has attempted to delete the shadow volumes of infected machines, once before and once after the encryption process.
[RobbinHood](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0400) deletes shadow copies to ensure that all the data cannot be restored easily.

[Meteor](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0688) can use "bcdedit" to delete different boot identifiers on a compromised host; it can also use "vssadmin.exe delete shadows /all /quiet" and "C:\\Windows\\system32\\wbem\\wmic.exe shadowcopy delete".

[Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) uses the native Windows utilities "vssadmin", "wbadmin", and "bcdedit" to delete and disable operating system recovery features such as the Windows backup catalog and Windows Automatic Repair.
[Royal](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1073) can delete shadow copy backups with vssadmin.exe using the command "delete shadows /all /quiet".
[HELLOKITTY](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0617) can delete volume shadow copies on compromised hosts.
[EKANS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0605) removes backups of Volume Shadow Copies to disable any restoration capabilities.
[Black Basta](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1070) can delete shadow copies using vssadmin.exe.
[WannaCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0366) uses "vssadmin", "wbadmin", "bcdedit", and "wmic" to delete and disable operating system recovery features.
[HermeticWiper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0697)
can disable the VSS service on a compromised host using the service control manager.
[WastedLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0612) can delete shadow volumes.
[JCry](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0389) has been observed deleting shadow copies to ensure that data cannot be restored easily.
[H1N1](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0132) disable recovery options and deletes shadow copies from the victim.
[netsh](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0108) can be used as a persistence proxy technique to execute a helper DLL when netsh.exe is executed.
[Windshift](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0112) has used fake personas on social media to engage and target victims.

During [Operation Dream Job](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0022), [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) sent victims spearphishing messages via LinkedIn concerning fictitious jobs.
[OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has used LinkedIn to send spearphishing links.
[APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) has used the legitimate mailing service Constant Contact to send phishing e-mails.
[EXOTIC LILY](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1011) has used the e-mail notification features of legitimate file sharing services for spearphishing.
[Dark Caracal](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0070) spearphished victims via Facebook and Whatsapp.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has used fake job advertisements sent via LinkedIn to spearphish targets.
[Ajax Security Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0130) has used various social media channels to spearphish victims.
[CURIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1012) has used social media to deliver malicious files to victims.
[Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) used various social media channels (such as LinkedIn) as well as messaging services (such as WhatsApp) to spearphish victims.
[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) has used social media platforms, including LinkedIn and Twitter, to send spearphishing messages.
[Higaisa](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0126) discovered system proxy settings and used them if available.
The [Winnti for Windows](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0141) HTTP/S C2 mode can make use of a local proxy.
[Hikit](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0009) supports peer connections.

During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used SSH port forwarding capabilities on public-facing systems, and configured at least one instance of [Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) to use a network pipe over SMB.
[InvisiMole](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0260) can function as a proxy to create a server that relays communication between the client and C&C server, or between two clients.
[CHOPSTICK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0023) used a proxy server between victims and the C2 server.
[Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) installs an RPC server for P2P communications.
[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) can be configured to have commands relayed over a peer-to-peer network of infected hosts.
This can be used to limit the number of egress points, or provide access to a host without direct internet access.
The "ZJ" variant of [BACKSPACE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0031) allows "ZJ link" infections with Internet access to relay traffic from "ZJ listen" to a command server.
[metaMain](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1059) can create a named pipe to listen for and send data to a named pipe-based C2 server.
[FatDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0512)
can used pipes to connect machines with restricted internet access to remote machines via other infected hosts.
[Mafalda](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1060) can create a named pipe to listen for and send data to a named pipe-based C2 server.
[Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has compromised internal network systems to act as a proxy to forward traffic to C2.
[Kazuar](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0265) has used internal nodes on the compromised network for C2 communications.
[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) has used a compromised router to serve as a proxy between a victim network's corporate and restricted segments.

[Strider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0041) has used local servers with both local network and Internet access to act as internal proxy nodes to exfiltrate data from other parts of the network without direct Internet access.
[Drovorub](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0502) can use a port forwarding rule on its agent module to relay network traffic through the client module to a remote host on the same network.
[Duqu](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0038) can be configured to have commands relayed over a peer-to-peer network of infected hosts if some of the hosts do not have Internet access.
[APT39](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0087) used custom tools to create SOCK5 and custom protocol proxies between infected hosts.
[MiniDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0051) can can use a named pipe to forward communications from one compromised machine with internet access to other compromised machines.
[Mythic](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0699) can use a peer-to-peer C2 profile between agents.
[Pay2Key](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0556) has designated machines in the compromised network to serve as reverse proxy pivot points to channel communications with C2.
During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), threat actors proxied traffic through multiple infected systems.

During [C0017](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0017), [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used dead drop resolvers on two separate tech community forums for their [KEYPLUG](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1051) Windows-version backdoor; notably [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) updated the community forum posts frequently with new dead drop resolvers during the campaign.
[Astaroth](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0373) can store C2 information on cloud hosting services such as AWS and CloudFlare and websites like YouTube and Facebook.
[Patchwork](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0040) hides base64-encoded and encrypted C2 server locations in comments on legitimate websites.
[Rocke](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0106) has used Pastebin to check the version of beaconing malware and redirect to another Pastebin hosting updated malware.
[BLACKCOFFEE](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0069)
uses Microsoft’s TechNet Web portal to obtain a dead drop resolver containing an encoded tag with the IP address of a command and control server.
[RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) has used an RSS feed on Livejournal to update a list of encrypted C2 server names.
[RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0148) has also hidden [Pony](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0453) C2 server IP addresses within transactions on the Bitcoin and Namecoin blockchain.
[BADNEWS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0128) collects C2 information via a dead drop resolver.
[PlugX](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0013) uses Pastebin to store C2 addresses.
[BRONZE BUTLER](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0060)'s MSGET downloader uses a dead drop resolver to access malicious payloads.
The [KEYPLUG](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1051) Windows variant has retrieved C2 addresses from encoded data in posts on tech community forums.
[Xbash](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0341) can obtain a webpage hosted on Pastebin to update its C2 domain list.
[Javali](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0528) can read C2 information from Google Documents and YouTube.
[APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) used legitimate websites for C2 through dead drop resolvers (DDR), including GitHub, Pastebin, and Microsoft TechNet.
[Grandoreiro](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0531) can obtain C2 information from Google Docs.
[CharmPower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0674) can retrieve C2 domain information from actor-controlled S3 buckets.
[PolyglotDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0518)
can use Twitter, Reddit, Imgur and other websites to get a C2 URL.
Some [MiniDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0051) components use Twitter to initially obtain the address of a C2 server or as a backup if no hard-coded C2 server responds.
[Metamorfo](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0455)
has used YouTube to store and hide C&C server domains.
[RTM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0048) has used an RSS feed on Livejournal to update a list of encrypted C2 server names.
[Mori](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1047)
has obfuscated the FML.dll with 200MB of junk data.
[TrailBlazer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0682) has used random identifier strings to obscure its C2 operations and result codes.
[P8RAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0626) can send randomly-generated data as part of its C2 communication.
[WellMess](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0514) can use junk data in the Base64 string for additional obfuscation.
[P2P ZeuS](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0016) added junk data to outgoing UDP packets to peer implants.
[SUNBURST](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0559) added junk bytes to its C2 over HTTP.
[PLEAD](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0435) samples were found to be highly obfuscated with junk code.
[GrimAgent](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0632) can pad C2 messages with random generated values.
[Kevin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1020) can generate a sequence of dummy HTTP C2 requests to obscure traffic.
[GoldMax](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0588) has used decoy traffic to surround its malicious network traffic to avoid detection.
[Turian](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0647) can insert pseudo-random characters into its network encryption setup.
[BendyBear](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0574)
has used byte randomization to obscure its behavior.
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) added "junk data" to each encoded string, preventing trivial decoding without knowledge of the junk removal algorithm.
Each implant was given a "junk length" value when created, tracked by the controller software to allow seamless communication but prevent analysis of the command protocol on the wire.

[Downdelph](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0134) inserts pseudo-random characters between each original character during encoding of C2 network requests, making it difficult to write signatures on them.
[Peirates](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0683)
can query the Kubernetes API for secrets.
For the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) compromised domains to use for C2.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has compromised legitimate sites and used them to distribute malware.

For [Operation Dream Job](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0022), [Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) compromised domains in Italy and other countries for their C2 infrastructure.
[Transparent Tribe](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0134) has compromised domains for use in targeted malicious campaigns.
[APT1](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0006) hijacked FQDNs associated with legitimate websites hosted by hop points.
[SideCopy](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G1008) has compromised domains for some of their infrastructure, including for C2 and staging malware.
For [C0021](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0021), the threat actors used legitimate but compromised domains to host malicious payloads.
During [C0010](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0010), UNC3890 actors likely compromised the domain of a legitimate Israeli shipping company.
[Magic Hound](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0059) has used compromised domains to host links targeted to specific phishing victims.
During the [2016 Ukraine Electric Power Attack](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0025), [Sandworm Team](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0034) used various MS-SQL stored procedures.
[Stuxnet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0603) used xp_cmdshell to store and execute SQL code.
[SYNful Knock](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0519) has the capability to add its own custom backdoor password when it modifies the operating system of the affected network device.
[StoneDrill](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0380)
can wipe the accessible physical or logical drives of the infected machine.
[BlackCat](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1068) has the ability to wipe VM snapshots on compromised networks.
[MegaCortex](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0576) can wipe deleted data from all drives using "cipher.exe".
[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) has used malware like WhiskeyAlfa to overwrite the first 64MB of every drive with a mix of static and random buffers.
A similar process is then used to wipe content in logical drives and, finally, attempt to wipe every byte of every sector on every drive.
WhiskeyBravo can be used to overwrite the first 4.9MB of physical drives.
WhiskeyDelta can overwrite the first 132MB or 1.5MB of each drive with random data from heap memory.
[RawDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0364)
has been used to directly access the hard disk to help overwrite arbitrarily sized portions of disk content.
[WhisperGate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0689) can overwrite sectors of a victim host's hard drive at periodic offsets.
[HermeticWiper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0697) has the ability to corrupt disk partitions and obtain raw disk access to destroy data.
[Rclone](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1040) can exfiltrate data over FTP or HTTP, including HTTP via WebDAV.
[Remsec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0125)
can exfiltrate data via a DNS tunnel or email, separately from its C2 channel.
[KONNI](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0356) has used FTP to exfiltrate reconnaissance data out.
[APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050)'s backdoor can exfiltrate data by encoding it in the subdomain field of DNS packets.

Some [Brave Prince](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0252) variants have used South Korea's Daum email service to exfiltrate information, and later variants have posted the data to a web server via an HTTP post command.
[PoetRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0428) has used [ftp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0095) for exfiltration.
[Dok](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0281) exfiltrates logs of its execution stored in the "/tmp" folder over FTP using the "curl" command.
[Agent Tesla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0331) has routines for exfiltration over SMTP, FTP, and HTTP.
[FIN8](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0061) has used FTP to exfiltrate collected data.
[WindTail](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0466) has the ability to automatically exfiltrate files using the macOS built-in utility /usr/bin/curl.
[Thrip](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0076) has used WinSCP to exfiltrate data from a targeted organization over FTP.
[CosmicDuke](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0050) exfiltrates collected files over FTP or WebDAV.
Exfiltration servers can be separately configured from C2 servers.
[APT33](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0064) has used FTP to exfiltrate files (separately from the C2 channel).
[OilRig](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0049) has exfiltrated data over FTP separately from its primary C2 channel over DNS.
[Wizard Spider](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0102) has exfiltrated victim information using FTP.
[Cherry Picker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0107) exfiltrates files over FTP.
[BITSAdmin](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0190) can be used to create [BITS Jobs](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1197) to upload files from a compromised host.
[ftp](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0095) may be used to exfiltrate data separate from the main command and control protocol.
[CharmPower](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0674) can send victim data via FTP with credentials hardcoded in the script.
[Kessel](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0487) can exfiltrate credentials and other information via HTTP POST request, TCP, and DNS.

During [C0017](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0017), [APT41](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0096) exfiltrated victim data via DNS lookups by encoding and prepending it as subdomains to the attacker-controlled domain.
[FIN6](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0037) has sent stolen payment card data to remote servers via HTTP POSTs.
[CORALDECK](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0212) has exfiltrated data in HTTP POST headers.
[CookieMiner](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0492) has used the "curl --upload-file" command to exfiltrate data over HTTP.
[ccf32](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1043) can upload collected data and files to an FTP server.
[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) malware SierraBravo-Two generates an email message via SMTP containing information about newly infected victims.
[Carbon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0335)
uses HTTP to send data to the C2 server.
[Empire](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0363) has a dylib hijacker module that generates a malicious dylib given the path to a legitimate dylib of a vulnerable application.
[Emotet](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0367) can brute force a local admin password, then use it to facilitate lateral movement.
[Kimsuky](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0094) has used a tool called GREASE to add a Windows admin account in order to allow them continued access via RDP.
[Umbreon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0221)
creates valid local users to provide access to the system.
During [Operation Wocao](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0014), threat actors used local account credentials found during the intrusion for lateral movement and privilege escalation.
[PROMETHIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0056) has created admin accounts on a compromised host.
[Turla](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0010) has abused local accounts that have the same password across the victim’s network.
[HAFNIUM](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0125) has used the NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM account to create files on Exchange servers.
[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) can use known credentials to run commands and spawn processes as a local user account.
During the [SolarWinds Compromise](https://attack.mitre.org/campaigns/C0024), [APT29](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0016) used compromised local accounts to access victims' networks.
[NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) can use valid credentials with [PsExec](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0029) or "wmic" to spread itself to remote systems.
[FIN10](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0051) has moved laterally using the Local Administrator account.
[APT32](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0050) has used legitimate local admin account credentials.
[Tropic Trooper](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0081) has used known administrator account credentials to execute the backdoor directly.
[APT28](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0007) has used CVE-2015-4902 to bypass security features.
[WhisperGate](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0689) can shutdown a compromised host through execution of "ExitWindowsEx" with the "EXW_SHUTDOWN" flag.
[NotPetya](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0368) will reboot the system one hour after infection.
[HermeticWiper](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0697)
can initiate a system shutdown.
[DCSrv](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1033) has a function to sleep for two hours before rebooting the system.
[Maze](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0449)
has issued a shutdown command on a victim machine that, upon reboot, will run the ransomware within a VM.
[KillDisk](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0607) attempts to reboot the machine by terminating specific processes.
[APT37](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0067) has used malware that will issue the command "shutdown /r /t 1" to reboot a system after wiping its MBR.
[APT38](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0082) has used a custom MBR wiper named BOOTWRECK, which will initiate a system reboot after wiping the victim's MBR.
[AvosLocker](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1053)’s Linux variant has terminated ESXi virtual machines.
[Olympic Destroyer](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0365) will shut down the compromised system after it is done modifying system configuration settings.
[LockerGoga](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0372)
has been observed shutting down infected systems.
[Shamoon](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0140) will reboot the infected system once the wiping functionality has been completed.
[Lazarus Group](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0032) has rebooted systems after destroying files and wiping the MBR on infected systems.
[LookBack](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0582) can shutdown and reboot the victim machine.
[SombRAT](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0615) has the ability to modify its process memory to hide process command-line arguments.
[Cobalt Strike](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0154) can use spoof arguments in spawned processes that execute beacon commands.

[Blue Mockingbird](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0108) has used wmic.exe and Windows Registry modifications to set the COR_PROFILER environment variable to execute a malicious DLL whenever a process loads the .NET CLR.
[DarkTortilla](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S1066) can detect profilers by verifying the "COR_ENABLE_PROFILING" environment variable is present and active.
